{{good article}} {{US income}} In the United States, despite the efforts of equality proponents, [[income inequality in the United States|income inequality]] persists among races<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Darity Jr. | first1 = William A. | author1-link =Sandy Darity, Jr. | title = The Human Capital Approach to Black-White Earnings Inequality: Some Unsettled Questions. | journal = The Journal of Human Resources | volume = 17 | issue = 1 | pages = 72–93 | year = 1982 | jstor=145525}}</ref> and ethnicities. [[Asian Americans]] have the highest average income, followed by [[white Americans]], [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Latino Americans]], [[African Americans]], and [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]]s.<ref name="byrace">{{cite web|url=https://factfinder.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml?src=bkmk|title=Median Household Income in the Past 12 Months (in 2016 inflation-adjusted dollars) |author= |date=2016 |work=American Community Survey |publisher=United States Census Bureau |accessdate=3 December 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6gpGlyhlr?url=http://factfinder.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml?src=bkmk |archivedate=17 April 2016 |df= }}</ref> A variety of explanations for these differences have been proposed—such as differing access to education, two parent home family structure (70% of African American children are born out of wedlock), high school dropout rates and experience of discrimination—and the topic is highly controversial.
When the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]] was passed, it became illegal for employers to [[Discrimination in the United States|discriminate]] based on race;<ref name=Coleman>{{cite journal | last1 = Coleman | first1 = Major G. | title = Job Skill and Black Male Wage Discrimination | journal = Social Science Quarterly | volume = 84 | issue = 4 | pages = 892–906 | year = 2003 | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.0038-4941.2003.08404007.x/full | doi=10.1046/j.0038-4941.2003.08404007.x}}</ref> however, income disparities have not flattened out.<ref name=Council>{{cite journal |last1 = Council of Economic Advisers for the President's Initiative on Race |title = Economic Report of the President: Changing America Indicators of Social and Economic Well-Being by Race and Hispanic Origin: Changing America's Indicators of Social and Economic Well-Being by Race and Hispanic Origin. |journal = GPO Access |year = 2009 |url = http://www.gpoaccess.gov/eop/ca/index.html |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120128134418/http://www.gpoaccess.gov/eop/ca/index.html |archivedate = 2012-01-28 |df = }}</ref><ref name = Waters>{{cite journal | last1 = Waters | first1 = Mary C. | author1-link = Mary C. Waters | last2 = Eschbach | first2 = Karl | title = Immigration and Ethnic and Racial Inequality in the United States | journal = Annual Review of Sociology | volume = 21 | issue = 1 | pages = 419–46 | year = 1995 | url = http://dash.harvard.edu/bitstream/handle/1/3203265/Waters_ImmigrationEthnic.pdf?sequence=1 | doi=10.1146/annurev.so.21.080195.002223}}</ref><ref name=Campbell>{{cite journal | last1 = Campbell | first1 = L. | last2 = Kaufman | first2 = R. | title = Racial Differences in Household Wealth: Beyond Black and White. | journal = Research in Social Stratification and Mobility | volume = 24 | issue = 2 | pages = 131–52 | year = 2006 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0276562406000205 | doi=10.1016/j.rssm.2005.06.001}}</ref> After the passage of the act, the wage gap for minority groups narrowed, both in absolute difference with white wages and as a percentage of white wages, until the mid-1970s; at this time, progress for many racial minorities slowed, stopped, or reversed.<ref name=Waters/> As of 2009, the median weekly wage for [[African American]] and [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanic]] workers was about 65 percent and 61 percent that of white workers, respectively. Asian workers' median wage was about 110 percent that of white workers.<ref>{{cite web | title = Table 701. Median Income of People in Constant (2009) Dollars by Sex, Race, and Hispanic Origin: 1990 to 2009 | url=ftp://ftp.census.gov/library/publications/2011/compendia/statab/131ed/tables/12s0701.pdf | accessdate = 17 Jan 2018 }}</ref> Overall, minority women's wages in comparison to those of white women are better than minority men's wages when compared to those of white men.<ref name=Waters/>
Wages from the labor market are the primary source of income for most families in America,<ref name=Waters/> and income is a socio-demographic status indicator that is important in understanding the building of [[wealth]].<ref name=Campbell/>
== History of the Racial Wage Gap ==
The documented history of the Racial Wage Gap in the United States goes back before the Civil Rights Act, where many modern causes of racial wage inequity, such as educational disparities and discrimination, stem from were even more prevalent. Public state records from the 1930s indicate white owned schools in the south spent approximately $61 dollars per student, or $1,074.14 in 2018 dollars when adjusted for inflation, compared to just $9 per student, or $158.48 in 2018 dollars. Simultaneously, the same schools saw a discrepancy in school time, with white schools in sessions for 156 days on average, compared to 123 days on average for black schools.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal |last1=Carruthers |first1=Celeste K. |last2=Wanamaker |first2=Marianne H. |title=Separate and Unequal in the Labor Market: Human Capital and the Jim Crow Wa...: EBSCOhost |journal=Journal of Labor Economics |date=Jul 2017 |volume=35 |issue=3 |pages=655–696 |url=http://web.b.ebscohost.com/ehost/detail/detail?vid=0&sid=2c848bd4-070a-4154-83d2-202f3bbeac38%40pdc-v-sessmgr05&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWhvc3QtbGl2ZQ%3d%3d#db=bth&AN=123370528 |language=en}}</ref>
However, aside from statistics of wage discrepancy between black individuals and their white counterparts, much is still unknown of wage inequity due to a lack of literature with solid empirical data to link data with an accurate model of wage discrimination.<ref name=":0" /> Subject to debate during the 1970s and 80s in the scholarly community was the link between geographical location and wage inequality. Following urban-dominated studies and shifting research based on evolved conceptual and study driven thinking, sociologists determined that the racial composition of a local population means for a key element in racial wage inequality. Among other factors, studies performed by Leslie Mcall<ref name=":1">{{cite journal |last1=McCall |first1=Leslie |title=Sources of Racial Wage Inequality in Metropolitan Labor Markets: Racial, Ethnic, and Gender Differences |journal=American Sociological Review |date=August 2001 |volume=66 |issue=4 |pages=520 |doi=10.2307/3088921}}</ref> indicate immigration population density as one of the leading factors in racial wage inequality. While black immigrant earnings do not deviate from the already substandard average earnings, numbers on Hispanic and Asian immigrant earnings suggest more extensive negative effects, especially in areas of high immigration density. Hispanic and Asian women, in particular, are shown to be most affected; Hispanic and Asian women are shown to fill less skilled, domestic service jobs where the concentration of their black and white counterparts are lower. Such barriers such as language show that such large dominance of immigrant population in such sectors only breed competition between lower-earning groups, further lowering average wages for such families.<ref name=":1" /> Since 1980, studies have found that, conversely, such low earning labor may actually boost the economy as a whole, keeping many corporations and higher level jobs afloat with cheap skilled work, boosting the salaries of native born hispanics and whites alike.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Parks |first1=Virginia |title=The Uneven Geography of Racial and Ethnic Wage Inequality: Specifying Local Labor Market Effects |journal=Annals of the Association of American Geographers |date=May 2012 |volume=102 |issue=3 |pages=700–725 |doi=10.1080/00045608.2011.600198}}</ref>
Historically, there have been links in the discrepancies between not only earnings from labor, but in the benefits received voluntarily from employers as well. Benefits include health care, pensions, holiday and vacation days, among other government mandated and voluntary benefits. Studies done by Tali Kristal and Yinon Cohen show the link between such wage inequality and benefits received, with empirical evidence showing a steady degradation of benefits received for those of different ethnic groups. As of 2015, 32% of workers received benefits - including both mandatory and voluntary - from their employers, up from 28% in 1980. As of 2015, 44% of white employees received pension benefits, compared 36% for blacks and 28% for Hispanic employees. Health care showed similar trends, as the 2015 health coverage rates for white, black, and hispanic employees sit at 60%, 55%, and 46%, respectively.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Kristal |first1=Tali |last2=Cohen |first2=Yinon |last3=Navot |first3=Edo |title=Benefit Inequality among American Workers by Gender, Race, and Ethnicity, 1982-2015 |journal=Sociological Science |date=2018 |volume=5 |pages=461–488 |doi=10.15195/v5.a20}}</ref>
==Causes== *Studies of the wage gap for various minority races in the United States have revealed a number of factors that contribute to the differences in wages observed between white Americans and Americans of other races. The factors contributing to the wage gaps for various races and the degree to which they affect each race varies,<ref name=Gwartney>{{cite journal | last1 = Gwartney | first1 = James D. | last2 = Long | first2 = James E. | title = The Relative Wage Earnings of Blacks and Other Minorities | journal = Industrialized Labor Relations Review | volume = 31 | issue = 3 | pages = 336–46 | year = 1978 | jstor=2522905}} </ref> but many factors are common to most or all races.
===Educational disparities=== {{Further|Racial achievement gap in the United States|Race and intelligence}}
[[Education in the United States|Education]] being one of the leading determinants of wage,<ref name=Couch>{{cite journal | last1 = Couch | first1 = Kenneth | last2 = Daly | first2 = Mary C. | title = Black-White Wage Inequality in the 1990s: a Decade of Progress | journal = Economic Inquiry | volume = 40 | issue = 1 | pages = 31–41 | year = 2002 | url = http://www2.econ.iastate.edu/classes/econ321/rosburg/Couch%20and%20Daly%20-%20Black-White%20wage%20inequality%20in%20the%201990s-%20Decade%20of%20progress.pdf | doi=10.1093/ei/40.1.31}}</ref> contributes in a similar manner to the racial wage gap. Varying education levels among races lead to different wages for various racial groups. Education affects wages because it allows access to occupations of higher status that offer greater earnings.<ref name=Campbell/> [[Mary C. Waters]] and Karl Eschbach studied the decrease in the black-white wage gap from the 1940s through the 1970s and found the primary reason for the decrease in the wage gap to be the narrowing of the [[Achievement gap in the United States|education gap]] between blacks and whites.<ref name=Waters/>
When the education of different groups becomes more equal, wage gaps decrease, though they do not disappear. A 2017 study found that the boost to earnings from legal education was lower for minorities than for whites, although all groups typically benefited from additional education.<ref name="Race">{{cite journal|last1=McIntyre|first1=Frank|last2=Simkovic|first2=Michael|title=Are law degrees as valuable to minorities?|journal=International Review of Law & Economics|doi=10.1016/j.irle.2017.09.004 |url=https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3037749|year=2017}}</ref>
===Occupational distribution disparities=== [[File:US occpuational distribution.png|thumb|350px|alt=Distribution of US occupations by race.|The occupation distribution of employed persons in the United States, 1997.<ref name=Council/>]]
The way in which races are distributed throughout occupations affects the racial wage gap. White and Asian Americans, who have the highest median incomes,<ref name=CensusAbstract>{{cite web | last = U.S. Census Bureau | title = Statistical Abstract of the United States: 2012 | url= https://www.census.gov/prod/2011pubs/12statab/income.pdf | accessdate = 30 Dec 2011}}</ref> are concentrated more in professional, executive, and managerial occupations than blacks, Hispanics, or American Indians.<ref name=Council/><ref name=Campbell/> Black and Hispanic workers are not only more likely to work in blue-collar or service jobs, but they tend to be concentrated in the lower-wage/skilled jobs, such as operators, fabricators, and laborers, rather than higher-paying precision production and craft jobs within those categories.<ref name=Council/><ref name=Campbell/> Even at similar levels of education, minorities might work in less prestigious roles. For example, among law school graduates, minorities are about 10 percent less likely than whites to practice law.<ref name="Race"/>
Occupational distribution varies for women of various races as well. White and Asian women are more likely to work in managerial and professional occupations, while black, Hispanic, and [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|American Indian Women]] are more likely to work in service occupations.<ref name=Council/> Thus, because certain races are more likely to have lower-paying jobs, gaps in median incomes between races arise.
A study conducted by Kenneth Couch and Mary Daly found that the occupational distribution between blacks and white improved between 1970 and the 1990s.<ref name=Couch/> In 1968, a black male was only 20 percent as likely to be employed as a manager as a white male and only 40 percent as likely to work in a professional occupation. In 1998, the percentages increased to 50% and 70 percent, respectively.<ref name=Couch/> Despite this improvement, however, occupational distribution differences still exist between blacks and whites. In 1998, a black male was still more likely than a white male to work in lower-skills jobs and less likely than a white male to work in high-paying jobs.<ref name=Couch/>
===Globalization=== The [[globalization]] of the United States' economy in the 1970s and 1980s caused a shift in the U.S. income distribution.<ref name=Massey>{{Citation | first = Douglas S. | last = Massey | editor-last = Henry | editor-first = Michael C. | contribution = The new geography of inequality in urban America | contribution-url = https://books.google.com/books?id=_DmN-Zq-WPIC&pg=PR5 | year = 2004 | pages = 173–187 | publisher = Yale University Press}}</ref> As the United States joined the global market economy, three outcomes occurred. Those who possessed financial and [[human capital]], such as education, succeeded in the new economy because the money and skills they had to offer were in short supply. Those who possessed only labor did not fare well because cheap, physical labor was in oversupply in the global market.<ref name=Massey/>
In the new globalized economy that formed, much of the United States' manufacturing was exported, which affected most adversely the group of Americans in the lowest section of the education distribution, a section in which minority groups are overrepresented.<ref name=Waters/> The increase in overall wage inequality created by the new economy's lower demand for physical labor disproportionately affected minorities as well.<ref name=Couch/> The economic restructuring also served to create structural barriers to improvement for those with the least education and skills.<ref name=Waters/> Thus, the United States' shift to a globalized economy lead to greater income disparity between education groups, which, because of the uneven distribution of minorities in jobs and an overall increase in wage inequality, led to the wage gap between whites and minorities to increase.
===Geographic distribution=== The distance between jobs and the location of minorities' homes affects the ability of minorities to find profitable work. Saskia Sassen found that the redistribution of manufacturing jobs out of central cities in the 1980s negatively affected the wage gap between blacks and whites because most blacks live in cities.<ref name=Waters/>
===Foreign birth=== A person of a minority race that is not born in the United States fares worse than those who are native born in terms of wages.<ref name=Gwartney/> The worst affected are men and women from Japan and China and Filipino women. However, a study by Gwartney and Long (1978) found that there is a positive effect on economic outcomes for [[Immigrant generations|second generation immigrants]], or the children of immigrants who are foreign born, which they believe means that there are specific traits of immigrant parents that are beneficial to the economic success of their children.<ref name=Gwartney/>
===Client channeling=== When wage gaps in occupations for blacks and whites are compared, it is observed that occupations that depend on social networking for success tend to have the largest racial disparities, while occupations in which success does not depend on the type of clients served tend to have the least racial disparities.<ref name=Grodsky>{{cite journal | last1 = Grodsky | first1 = Eric | last2 = Pager | first2 = Devah | title = The Structure of Disadvantage: Individual and Occupational Determinants of the Black-White Wage Gap | journal = American Sociological Review | volume = 66 | issue = 4 | pages = 542–67 | year = 2001 | url = http://www.ssc.wisc.edu/cde/cdewp/99-28.pdf | doi=10.2307/3088922}}</ref> This difference has been attributed to employee channeling, or the assignment by white employers of minority employees to serve minority clients.<ref name=Grodsky/> The implications of employee channeling for a black real estate agent, for example, would be that they disproportionately served black clients and neighborhoods, resulting in lower sales commissions. In this way, employee channeling, identified as a social form of discrimination, contributes to the wage gap.<ref name=Grodsky/>
===Discrimination=== {{See also|Discrimination in the United States}}
When human capital, skills, and other factors contributing to the racial wage gap are taken into account, many researchers find that there is still a portion of the racial wage gap that is unexplained. Many attribute this to another factor: [[Race and ethnicity in the United States|race]]. Differences in wages due solely to race is racial [[Discrimination in the United States|discrimination]]. Through the use of statistical controls, sociologists and economists "ask whether a given person with the same background characteristics, such as level of education, region of residence, gender, marital characteristics, has the same earnings as a statistically equivalent person from a different racial/ethnic group".<ref name=Waters/> Differences that emerge are taken as evidence of racial discrimination. Research has found wage and employment discrimination against blacks, Native Americans, Hispanics, and Asians; however, discrimination has been found to be a much larger contributing factor for black wages than wages of other races.<ref name=Waters/>
A study conducted by Grodsky & [[Devah Pager|Pager]] (2001) found that individual attributes, such as human capital and region, account for just more than half of the black-white wage gap, and an additional 20 percent is due to different occupational distributions between blacks and whites.<ref name=Grodsky/> The remaining portion of the wage gap not accounted for by individual and occupational distribution factors is thought to be due, at least in part, to discrimination.<ref name=Grodsky/>
Discrimination based on race has been found in other research as well. Seventy-four percent of employers in one study were found to be racially biased against blacks, and blacks have been found to make lower wages than whites working in the same industry.<ref name=Coleman/> [[White Hispanic and Latino Americans|White Latinos]] earn higher wages than nonwhite Latinos, regardless of whether they are native or immigrant, suggesting possible discrimination based on skin color.<ref name=Coleman/> Additionally, many employers openly admit to discriminating against blacks and workers in the inner city, as one study by Kirschenman and Neckerman (1991) found.<ref name=Coleman/> Hiring audits have also found discrimination in the labor market. Blacks and whites who have the same credentials receive jobs at a rate of 3:1.<ref name=Coleman/>
==Specific races== Wage gaps have been identified for many races within the United States; however, research has found that the size and causes of the wage gap differs by race.<ref name=Gwartney/> For instance, the median black male worker earns 74 percent as much as the median white male worker, while the median Hispanic male worker earns only 63 percent as much.<ref name=Council/> To understand more fully and accurately the subject of the racial wage gap in the United States, it is useful to look at different races individually to understand the causes and outcomes that are unique to them.
[[File:Racial Earnings Comparison.png|thumb|300px|alt=Comparison of earnings by race, 1970 and 1997.|Black and Hispanic Male Earnings as a Percentage of White Male Earnings, 1979 and 1997.<ref name=Council/>]]
[[File:Weekly Earnings.png|thumb|300px|alt=Comparison of weekly earnings by race, 1965-1995.|Comparison of weekly earnings by race, 1965-1995.<ref name=Council/>]]
===Black=== The history of Black Americans in the United States is one characterized by social control and domination. The [[Wealth inequality in the United States#Racial disparities|disparity in wealth between Black and White America]] has a history as long as the relationship between the two groups. Across the country, white Americans benefitted from not being required to pay [[Slavery in the United States|enslaved Africans for two centuries]], and after slavery was abolished racist groups like the Ku Klux Klan led mobs to engage in boycotts at the least and outright violence against Black businesses ([[Tulsa race riot|1921 Tulsa Race Riot]]), churches ([[16th Street Baptist Church bombing]]), schools, and other pillars of Black society at worst. Though these individuals have since died, their wealth has been passed down until the present in the form of inheritance and historical business investment.
The [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]], which forbade employers from discriminating on the basis of race,<ref name=Coleman/> was one of the earliest and greatest influences on the black-white wage gap. The act, along with the [[post–World War II economic expansion|economic prosperity of the 1960s]], contributed to rising black wages, increased education for blacks, and increased returns to education.<ref name=Waters/> Indeed, in 1940, weekly wages of the average black male were only 48.4 percent that of the average white male. In 1990, that had risen to 75 percent, a 60 percent improvement over five decades.<ref name=Chandra>{{cite journal | last1 = Chandra | first1 = Amitabh | title = Labor-Market Dropouts and the Racial Wage Gap: 1940–1990 | journal = American Economic Review | volume = 90 | issue = 2 | pages = 333–38 | year = 2000 | url = http://www.hks.harvard.edu/fs/achandr/AER_LaborMktDropoutRacialWageGap_2000.pdf. | doi=10.1257/aer.90.2.333}}</ref>
From the ending of legal [[Racial segregation in the United States|segregation]] through the mid-1970s, the black-white wage gap continued to narrow. However, from the mid-1970s until almost 1990, progress in wage equality greatly slowed.<ref name=Waters/> From 1968-1979, the black-white wage gap decreased by an average of 1.2 percent each year. During the 80s, however, it increased .24 percent each year. During the 1990s, the black-white wage gap decreased .59 percent each year.<ref name=Couch/> This proportional decrease was also accompanied by a decrease in the absolute difference of black and white wages.<ref name=CensusAbstract/>
Analyses have uncovered some of the underlying influences in the improvements of the black-white wage gap. During the decades of progress (the 1970s and 1990s), 30 percent of the wage gap convergence can be attributed to changes in black education and experience.<ref name=Couch/> More equalization in employment distribution also influenced the convergence during those decades. Factors identified as contributing to decreases in wage gap convergence include "shifts in industry demand, greater occupational crowding, relative deterioration of unobservable skills in blacks, and rising overall male wage inequality".<ref name=Couch/>
The decline of the black-white wage gap in the 1990s was greatest for those who have less than 10 years of potential experience, for whom it decreased 1.40 percent per year.<ref name=Couch/> Kenneth Couch and Mary C. Daly report in their 2002 study on black-white wage inequality that these decreases are the result of greater occupational diversity and reductions in unobserved or residual differences.<ref name=Couch/> In the first decade of the twenty-first century, the wage gap has fluctuated in terms of the ratio between black and white wages: 67.7 percent in 2000, 64.0 percent in 2005, 67.5 percent in 2008, and 64.5 percent in 2009.<ref name=CensusAbstract/> The absolute difference in black and white wages, however, has decreased over this period.<ref name=CensusAbstract/>
Black Americans now number 36 million, 12.9% of the total population.<ref>{{cite web |last=U.S. Census Bureau |title=The US Census Black Population:2010 |url=http://2010.census.gov/2010census/ |accessdate=30 Dec 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100320084325/http://2010.census.gov/2010census/ |archivedate=2010-03-20 |df= }} </ref> As of 2009, the median black male income was $23,738, compared to the median white non-Hispanic male income of $36,785.<ref name=CensusAbstract/>
While progress in wage inequality for blacks has been made since the passage of the 1964 Civil Rights Acts, inequality and discrimination still exist. A study conducted by Major G. Coleman (2003) reports that as black and white men have more similar competitive performance ratings, racial wage differences increase rather than decrease. He also found that black wages are less than white wages in the same industry.<ref name=Coleman/> When no factors other than race are considered, Coleman predicts the black hourly wage to be $7.49 and the white hourly wage to be $8.92, 19 percent higher than the black hourly wage. When Coleman controlled for human capital, such as education and skills, the difference decreased to 11 percent. Coleman attributed this 11 percent difference to racial discrimination.<ref name=Coleman/>
Grodsky and [[Devah Pager|Pager]] also calculated wage differences, and found blacks to make $3.65 less per hour than whites in the private sector and $2.85 less in the public sector.<ref name=Grodsky/> Using statistical regressions, they found that human capital, region, and marital status account for 55 percent of the wage gap difference. An additional 20 percent of the wage gap was attributed to differences in occupational distributions between blacks and whites. Thus, 25 percent of the wage gap was unaccounted for by their model.<ref name=Grodsky/>
Black women experience more wage equality in comparison to white women than black men do to white men. By the mid-1970s, wages for black and white women were almost equal; however, since then, black women's wages have decreased about 10 percent relative to white women's wages.<ref name=Council/> This difference that emerged has been attributed to the increase of white women in the labor force following the mid-1970s.<ref name=Waters/>
It has been suggested that when more white women began working, the advantages of black women from unmeasured differences in labor force attachment disappeared, revealing a racial wage gap. While an overall wage gap appeared between black and white women, by 1980, the earnings of black women with college degrees surpassed those of white women with college degrees.<ref name=Waters/> An understanding of the earnings of black women has recently become recognized as an important area of research due to role that black women traditionally have in terms of family income: black married couples typically have relied more on women's earnings than other races and the percentage of single-parent, female-maintained families is highest among the black population.<ref name=Council/>
===Hispanic=== The [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanic]] minority group in the United States, composed of 50.3 million individuals in 2010,<ref name=Quick>{{cite web |last=U.S. Census Bureau |title=U.S. Census Bureau: State and County QuickFacts 2010. Current Population Reports |url=http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/00000.html |accessdate=30 Dec 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080421034031/http://www.beliefnet.com/politics/religiousaffiliation.html |archivedate=2008-04-21 |df= }} </ref> consists of much variance within itself with regard to wages, though all groups' wages are lower than those of non-Hispanic whites.<ref name=Borjas>{{cite journal | last1 = Borjas | first1 = George J. | title = The Earnings of Male Hispanic Immigrants in the United States | journal = Industrial and Labor Relations Review | volume = 35 | issue = 3 | pages = 343–53 | year = 1982 | url = http://www.hks.harvard.edu/fs/gborjas/publications/journal/Earnings_of_Male_Hispanic.pdf | doi=10.2307/2522814| jstor = 2522814 }} </ref> In 2007, the largest Hispanic group, consisting of 29.2 million people, were individuals of [[Mexican American|Mexican]] origin, followed by 4.1 million people of [[Puerto Ricans in the United States|Puerto Rican]] origin and 1.6 million people of [[Cuban American|Cuban]] origin.<ref>{{cite web | last = Pew Research Center | title = Demographic Profiles of U.S. Hispanics by Country of Origin | url=http://pewresearch.org/pubs/1344/demographic-profiles-american-hispanics-mexican-cuban-puerto-rican-salvadoran-dominican | accessdate = 30 Dec 2011 }}</ref> By 2009, the median income of Hispanics was lower than that of Whites and Asians, but much higher than the median wages of African-Americans; $38,039, compared to $32,584 for African-Americans and $49,777 for the general population.<ref name=CensusAbstract>{{cite web | last = U.S. Census Bureau | title = Statistical Abstract of the United States: 2012 | url= https://www.census.gov/prod/2011pubs/12statab/income.pdf | accessdate = 30 Dec 2011}}</ref> While their relative wages have fallen since 1979, this has been attributed to a demand for more educated workers and a gap in educational attainment, supported by the fact that college-educated Hispanic men's relative wages have changed little over time.<ref name=Council/>
Unlike research findings for the black minority, it has been a converging finding that largest contributing factor to the wage gap of Hispanics is observable skill characteristics, especially education.<ref name=Council/><ref name=Waters/><ref name=Borjas/> Thus, increased education has been seen to contribute to a decreased wage gap. College-educated Hispanic men have wages that are approximately 80 percent of those earned by college-educated white males and are 10 percent higher than wages earned by college-educated black males.<ref name=Council/> College-educated Hispanic women earn approximately 90 percent of what college-educated white women earn, which is slightly more than the earnings of college-educated black women.<ref name=Council/>
Despite the improvement in wages made by educational attainment, less educated Hispanic men still have less return to education than non-Hispanic men that are statistically comparable. A study conducted using 1980 census data on income that controlled for age, education, English language ability, nativity, and State/Metro residence, found a wage gap of 10 percent still existed for Hispanics compared to non-Hispanics. Additionally, discrimination against Hispanic men and women was found in an audit study of employers in San Diego and Chicago.<ref name=Waters/>
Because skills and educational attainment is the major contributing factor to the wage gap for Hispanics, differences in the education levels of the various Hispanic subgroups has been used to explain differences in their wages. The typical trend in wages for Hispanic subgroups is that Cubans do the best while Puerto Ricans do the worst, being severely disadvantaged even in comparison to blacks and American Indians. [[George Borjas|George J. Borjas]] attributes these group differences to two factors: 1. The nature of the [[Immigration to the United States|migration]] decision (whether individuals migrated to the United States for political or economic reasons) and 2. The incentives for immigrants to adapt to the U.S. labor market.<ref name=Borjas/>
When Hispanic persons immigrate to the United States, neither their physical nor human capital specific to their country of origin is easily transferred to the United States' labor market; human capital investments must be made in the United States in order to assimilate into the labor market.<ref name=Borjas/> Borjas argues that the Hispanic groups that immigrate to the United States for economic reasons, rather than political reasons, have more incentive to acquire human capital in the United States and therefore do so faster than other groups. This faster acquisition of human capital results in better economic progress and higher wages.<ref name=Borjas/>
Thus, the relative success of Cubans can be attributed to the fact that they invest in United States education and labor market skills faster and to a greater degree than other Hispanic groups. Borjas recognizes that one of the main reasons for Hispanic migration to the United States is political reasons, and he argues that political refugees have less incentive to assimilate and acquire human capital than those who migrate for economic reasons. This lower incentive leads to the education gaps seen between Hispanics and whites and therefore greatly contributes to the observed wage gap.<ref name=Borjas/> Based on an analysis of Hispanic wages over the past six decades, Borjas concludes that, due to differing incentives to assimilate and other factors, Puerto Rican immigrants will wait twenty-five years before the assimilation process is reflected in their wages and Mexican immigrants will wait fifteen years.<ref name=Borjas/>
Hispanic women, like black women, have experienced greater success in wage equality relative to males of their race. As of 1995, Hispanic women of all education levels, except for those without high school diplomas or associate degrees, had parity in earnings with white women.<ref name=Waters/> While this information is positive, a broader examination of Hispanic women's wages reveals that inequality still exists. In the 1990s, Hispanic women's full-time earnings fell in real terms. This difference is attributed mainly to differences in educational attainment.<ref name=Council/> As of 2017, the average Hispanic woman in the United States made 87.4% of what their male counterparts earned, 75.8% of what white women white made, and only 62.1% of what white, American males earned annually.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fontenot|first=Kayla|date=September 12, 2018|title=Income and Poverty in the United States: 2017|url=https://www.census.gov/library/publications/2018/demo/p60-263.html|journal=Current Population Survey Annual Social and Economic Supplements (CPS ASEC)|volume=|pages=|via=U.S Census Bureau}}</ref>
===Asian=== As of 2010, 14,011,000 [[Asian American|Asians]] of all ethnicities were living in America.<ref name=Asian>{{cite web | last = U.S. Census Bureau | title = . Race Data: Population by Sex and Age, for Asian Alone and White Alone, Not Hispanic: 2010 | url= https://www.census.gov/population/www/socdemo/race/ppl-aa10.html | archive-url= https://archive.is/20110622072209/http://www.census.gov/population/www/socdemo/race/ppl-aa10.html | dead-url= yes | archive-date= 2011-06-22 | accessdate = 2012-01-04 }}</ref> Asian Americans are the only minority in the United States whose median income is higher than whites, assuming Pacific Islanders are not counted as a separate race. In 2009, the median income for Asian males was $37,330, compared to the median income for non-Hispanic white males of $36,785.<ref name=CensusAbstract/> In 2015, Asian American men were the highest earning racial group at $24/hour. Asian American men earned 117% as much as white American men ($21/hour) and have been out earning their white Americans counterparts since about 2000. Similarly, in 2015 Asian American women earned 106% as much as white American women.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Patten|first1=Eileen|title=Racial, gender wage gaps persist in U.S. despite some progress|url=http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/07/01/racial-gender-wage-gaps-persist-in-u-s-despite-some-progress/|website=Pew Research Center|publisher=Pew Research Center|accessdate=2 July 2016}}</ref>
However, not all Asian groups in the United States have such high wages; certain Asian groups have fared better than others in the United States labor market. East Asians from Hong Kong,Taiwan, China, Japan, and Korea have higher median wages and household income than Southeast Asian refugees from Laos and Vietnam, though all these groups still have median income above non-Hispanic whites. Cambodians and Hmong, on the other hand, do not, though their median income is still quite close to the national average and above that of blacks and Hispanics. [[Indian Americans]] currently have the highest median household income of any ethnic group in the United States, while Bhutanese Americans have the lowest.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml?pid=ACS_10_SF4_B19013&prodType=table |title=Median houseland income in the past 12 months (in 2010 inflation-adjusted dollars) |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |year=2010 |work=2006-2010 American Community Survey |publisher=United States Census Bureau |accessdate=22 April 2013}}</ref>
Part of the explanation for Asians' higher wages is their greater-than-average educational attainment: in the 1990s, 23.3 percent of the total U.S. male population had at least a college degree, while 48.7 percent of Asian Indian men, 41.6 percent of Filipino men, and 35 percent of Chinese men had at least a college degree.<ref name=Waters/> The higher educational attainment of Asians masks the fact that a wage gap exists between Asians and whites of the same occupations. Whites earn more than Asians in almost all occupational categories when other factors are controlled.<ref name=Waters/> Asians still make 8% less than whites in comparable jobs except for Asians who have been in the United States for one and a half generations, whom have reached full parity in income.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://doi.org/10.1177/0003122410388501|title=Have Asian American Men Achieved Labor Market Parity with White Men?|first1=ChangHwan|last1=Kim|first2=Arthur|last2=Sakamoto|date=1 December 2010|publisher=|journal=American Sociological Review|volume=75|issue=6|pages=934–957|via=SAGE Journals|doi=10.1177/0003122410388501}}</ref>
===Native Americans===
The [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] minority has been less studied than other minority groups in the United States. In 1990, the median family income for American Indians was $21,750, approximately 62 percent of the $35,225 median family income for all families.<ref name=CensusAbstract/> By 2010, the median household income for Native Americans was $38,806, compared to $51,914 for the total population, making them the second poorest race on average after African-Americans ($35,341).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml?pid=ACS_10_SF4_B19013&prodType=table |title=Median Household Income in the Past 12 Months (in 2010 inflation-adjusted dollors) |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2010 |work=2006-2010 American Community Survey |publisher=United States Census Bureau |accessdate=22 April 2013}}</ref> However, Native Americans are the poorest ethnic group when measured by per capita income. <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ethnic_groups_in_the_United_States_by_per_capita_income#> The wage gap has been attributed by some to "human capital differences." There is debate as to whether discrimination affects the wage gap.<ref name=Waters/> However, most sociologists understand existing wealth and income differences among minorities as the outcome of historical discrimination dating to colonization, forced migration, and slavery.
==Private vs. public sector employment==
The racial wage gap for blacks and whites has been observed to be lower in the [[Public sector|public]] sector than the [[Private sector|private]] sector.<ref name="Race"/> In a 2001 analysis, a $3.65 difference per hour was found between blacks and whites in the private sector, a 34 percent difference.<ref name=Grodsky/> In contrast, a smaller difference of $2.85 per hour was found in the public sector, a 21 percent difference.<ref name=Grodsky/> For the 23 percent of blacks that work in the public sector, evidence suggests that wages are based primary on individual qualifications, but for the 77 percent of blacks employed in the private sector, this assertion has not been found to be as valid.<ref name=Grodsky/>
Additionally, a larger percentage of the wage gap was found to be accounted for by the human capital characteristics of educational attainment and potential years of experience in the public than private sector.<ref name=Grodsky/> Also, an effect encountered in the private sector in which black males have higher absolute wages as they increase in status but lower wages relative to whites of the same status, has not been found in the public sector.<ref name=Grodsky/>
==Policy discussion== Though solutions to eliminate the racial wage gap have been proposed, there is no one prescription that will eliminate it for all races, or even one race. Research has identified different wage gaps and sources of wage gaps for different minorities, suggesting that public policies will affect different minorities in different ways and that effective strategies must take into account the unique circumstances of each race group.<ref name=Gwartney/> Sociologist [[Douglas Massey]] offers two solutions to alleviate wage inequality: greater investments in education and elimination of racial segregation. He notes that, in a globalized economy, those with only physical labor to offer suffer.<ref name=Massey/>
He argues that investments in education, especially higher education, will result in higher rates of economic growth and lower [[Income inequality in the United States|income inequality]]. By eliminating racial segregation, Massey argues that many divides between races that exist would be broken down, including income segregation. To accomplish the abolition of racial segregation, Massey argues, simple enforcement of legislation already in place, such as the [[Fair Housing Act]], the [[Home Mortgage Disclosure Act]], and the [[Community Reinvestment Act]], is required.<ref name=Massey/> For more group-specific policies, focus on education and language inequalities could be helpful in equalizing employment opportunities, but other more specific policies are dependent on further research on wage gaps for various groups.<ref name=Gwartney/>
To tackle wage inequality specifically in companies, random job audits at the national, state, and local levels have been suggested. Audits have been used to study and find wage inequality in the past and could be used as way to actively monitor the presence of the racial wage gap in companies.<ref name=Coleman/>
==Limitations and criticisms of the racial wage gap== Evaluating and understanding the causes and consequences of the racial wage gap for various races is an important part of understanding [[racial inequality in the United States]]; however, the wage gap does not encompass all aspects of inequality and therefore is useful when understood in conjunction with other types of inequalities. For example, sociologists Mary C. Waters and Karl Eschbach note that other types of inequalities are important for a holistic understanding of inequality in the United States, "including health and demographic measures, such as infant mortality rates, life expectancy, morbidity, and disability.<ref name=Waters/>
Ethnic and racial groups also differ in rates of [[Homeownership in the United States|homeownership]], [[residential segregation]], overall wealth, exposure to crime and toxic pollutants, and in access to power in the upper reaches of our society".<ref name=Waters/> Thus, the racial wage gap is just one aspect of inequality in the United States.
A criticism of the racial wage gap has been noted by a few scholars: the racial wage gap fails to account for the number of people of a specific race that are [[Unemployment in the United States|unemployed]].<ref name=Waters/><ref name=Chandra/> Examining median incomes does not reflect the growing racial disparity in joblessness.<ref name=Waters/> The Butler-[[James Heckman|Heckman]] hypothesis states that the least-skilled members of society are also the ones who are most likely to be not working,<ref name=Chandra/> suggesting that the wage gap does not account for the overall difference in wages between races. An analysis of the black-white wage gap which accounted for unemployment found that when unemployment was included in the calculation of the weekly wages convergence from 1950 to 2000, the convergence percentage went from 13 percent to only 3 percent.<ref name=Chandra/>

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{rape}} {{Violence against women}} Since the onset of the [[insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir]] in 1988, rape has been used as a weapon of war by Indian security forces; comprising the [[Indian Army]],Chinkin, Christine. "Rape and sexual abuse of women in international law." ''[[European Journal of International Law]]'' 5.3 (1994): 327. ''Numerous incidents of women raped in other international and internal armed conflicts can be cited to illustrate this point...women in Kashmir who have suffered rape and death under the administration of the Indian army.'' [[Central Reserve Police Force]] (CRPF) and [[Border Security Force|Border Security personnel]], against the [[Kashmiris|Kashmiri]] population.Inger Skjelsbæk (2001) [[doi:10.1080/13533310108413896|Sexual violence in times of war: A new challenge for peace operations?]], International Peacekeeping, 8:2, 75–76.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=gU-6CgAAQBAJ&pg=PT101 | title = Rape: Weapon of Terror | publisher = World Scientific | year = 2001 | isbn = 978-981-4350-95-2 | pages = 101– | author = Sharon Frederick }}[https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF "RAPE IN KASHMIR: A Crime of War"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904012347/http://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF |date=4 September 2012 }} (PDF). ''Asia Watch & Physicians for Human Rights A Division of Human Rights Watch''. '''5''' (9): 6. The frequent rape of [[Kashmiri Muslim]] women by Indian state security forces routinely goes unpunished.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=SupcBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA683 | title = The Oxford Handbook of Transnational Feminist Movements | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 2015 | isbn = 978-0-19-994349-4 | pages = 683– | author1 = Rawwida Baksh | author2 = Wendy Harcourt }} Many women have become victims of rape and sexual assault in the conflict. According to scholar Seema Kazi, separatist militants have also committed rape to some extent, although not comparable in scale with that by the Indian state forces.Kazi, Seema. [http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t343/e0165?_hi=0&_pos=1 ''Gender and Militarization in Kashmir'']. ''Oxford Islamic Studies Online''. Oxford University Press. Sordid and gruesome as the militant record of violence against Kashmiri women and civilians is, it does not compare with the scale and depth of abuse by Indian State forces for which justice has yet to be done. There have been events of [[mass rape]] also in the history of [[Kashmir conflict]], which include the ones carried out by [[Dogra dynasty|Dogra]] troops as well as Hindu and Sikh mobs,{{cite book | author1 = Amritjit Singh | author2 = Nalini Iyer | author3 = Rahul K. Gairola | title = Revisiting India's Partition: New Essays on Memory, Culture, and Politics | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=tmA0DAAAQBAJ&pg=PA149%7Cdate | date = 15 June 2016 | publisher = Lexington Books | isbn = 978-1-4985-3105-4 | pages = 149– }}{{cite book | author = Ayesha Jalal | title = Self and Sovereignty: Individual and Community in South Asian Islam Since 1850 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Sa6CAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA558%7Cdate | date = 4 January 2002 | publisher = Routledge | isbn = 978-1-134-59937-0 | pages = 558– }} and by Pakistani armed tribesmen when the conflict broke out in 1947. == History of the conflict == {{See also|Violence against women during the partition of India}} There have been many incidents of rape in the [[Jammu and Kashmir (princely state)|princely state of Jammu and Kashmir]]. A large number of Muslim women were abducted and raped in the [[Jammu Division|Jammu region]] of the state, during the [[1947 Jammu massacres]] in October–November 1947, which were carried out by extremist [[Hindu]]s and [[Sikh]]s, aided and abetted by the forces of the [[Dogra dynasty|Dogra]] State headed by the [[Maharaja of Jammu and Kashmir|Maharaja]] [[Hari Singh]].{{Cite web | url = http://www.kashmirlife.net/jammu-1947-issue-35-vol-07-89728/ | title = Jammu 1947 | last = [[Ved Bhasin]] | website = Kashmir Life | access-date = 9 May 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170222115536/http://www.kashmirlife.net/jammu-1947-issue-35-vol-07-89728/ | archive-date = 22 February 2017 | dead-url = no | df = }}{{Cite web | url = http://www.kashmirlife.net/circa-1947-a-long-story-67652/ | title = circa 1947: A Long Story | last = Khalid Bashir Ahmad | website = Kashmir Life | access-date = 9 May 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170407122130/http://www.kashmirlife.net/circa-1947-a-long-story-67652/ | archive-date = 7 April 2017 | dead-url = no | df = }} In October 1947, armed [[Pashtuns|Pashtun]] tribesmen from Pakistan, who had support from the Pakistani administration and Army, invaded Kashmir and committed atrocities such as raping and looting the locals during the beginning of [[First Kashmir War]]. They took place in and around [[Muzaffarabad]] and [[Baramulla]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=JXwhX8JZ-68C&pg=PR7&dq=pakistani+tribesmen+invaded+kashmir+1947 Kashmir: The Case for Freedom] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170424085218/https://books.google.com/books?id=JXwhX8JZ-68C&pg=PR7&dq=pakistani+tribesmen+invaded+kashmir+1947 |date=24 April 2017 }}, p. vii, Verso Books, by Arundhati Roy, Pankaj Mishra, Hilal Bhatt, Angana P. Chatterji, Tariq Ali[https://books.google.com/books?id=5amKCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA174&dq= Understanding Kashmir and Kashmiris], pp. 173, 174; Christopher Snedden, Oxford University Press, 15 September 2015 Mass rape was also reported in the [[New Mirpur City|Mirpur]] region of today's [[Azad Kashmir]] during the [[1947 Mirpur Massacre]] which was carried out against the Hindu and Sikh refugees, by the tribesmen from Pakistan. Many women were also abducted.{{Cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=5amKCwAAQBAJ&pg=167&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false | title = Understanding Kashmir and Kashmiris | last = Snedden | first = Christopher | date = 15 September 2015 | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = | isbn = 978-1-84904-621-3 | location = | pages = 167 | language = en }}{{Cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ItY3BAAAQBAJ&redir_esc=y | title = Across the Line of Control: Inside Azad Kashmir | last = Puri | first = Luv | date = 21 February 2012 | publisher = Columbia University Press | year = | isbn = 978-0-231-80084-6 | location = | pages = 28 | language = en }}{{Cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=65I98RN-qzUC | title = A Story of Bungling in Kashmir | last = Madhok | first = Balraj | date = 1 January 1972 | publisher = Young Asia Publications | year = | isbn = | location = | pages = 67 | language = en }} == Rape by Indian forces (post-1988) == {{Human rights abuses in Jammu and Kashmir}} === Background === In the aftermath of the rigged [[Jammu and Kashmir Legislative Assembly election, 1987|1987 elections]] in the state of Jammu and Kashmir, where Islamic parties were prevented from winning several seats in the State Assembly,Amin, Tahir; Schofield, Victoria. [http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t236/e0433?_hi=3&_pos=48 Kashmir]. The Oxford Encyclopedia of the Islamic World. Oxford University Press. ''The current phase of resistance against Indian rule began in 1987 when an alliance of several Islamic parties, the Muslim United Front (MUF), was expected to win several important seats in the state assembly elections but failed to win more than four seats, allegedly because of massive rigging. These elections proved the catalyst for a new phase of armed struggle against Indian rule. '' a popular [[Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir|anti-Indian separatist movement and militancy]] gained momentum in the [[Kashmir Valley]], a territory disputed between India and Pakistan since 1947. To counter the insurgency, India militarised the Valley, deploying a huge number of troops in the region. Opponents of Indian military occupation in the valley maintain that 600,000 troops are stationed throughout the state, according to which the region possesses the highest ratio of troops to civilians in the world.[https://books.google.com/books?id=rkTetMfI6QkC Schofield, Kashmir in Conflict 2003], p. 168. Since January 1990, Indian forces committed a number of human rights violations against civilians, including mass rape. === Rape as a weapon of war === According to a 1993 [[Human Rights Watch]] (HRW) report, the security forces use rape as a method of retaliation against Kashmiri civilians during reprisal attacks after militant ambushes.Littlewood, Roland. "Military Rape." ''[[Anthropology Today]]'', vol. 13, no. 2, 1997, pp. 7–16. Most rape cases, according to the same report, have occurred during cordon-and-search operations.[https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF "Rape in Kashmir: A Crime of War"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904012347/http://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF |date=4 September 2012 }} (PDF). ''Asia Watch & Physicians for Human Rights A Division of Human Rights Watch''. '''5''' (9): 1. According to a 1996 HRW report, security personnel in Kashmir have used "rape as a counterinsurgency tactic".{{cite web | title = India's Secret Army in Kashmir | url = https://www.hrw.org/reports/1996/India2.htm | publisher = [[Human Rights Watch]] | accessdate = 15 August 2017 }} Scholar [[Inger Skjelsbæk|Inger Skhjelsbaek]] states that the pattern of rape in Kashmir is that soldiers enter the homes of civilians, kill or evict the men and then rape the women present. Scholar Shubh Mathur calls rape an essential element of the Indian military strategy in Kashmir.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=PeYdCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT60 | title = The Human Toll of the Kashmir Conflict: Grief and Courage in a South Asian Borderland | last = Mathur | first = Shubh | date = 1 February 2016 | publisher = Palgrave Macmillan US | isbn = 978-1-137-54622-7 | pages = 60– }} According to Seema Kazi, the motive of rape in Kashmir is no different to the rapes which were committed in Rwanda and the Balkans.Kazi, Seema. [http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t343/e0165?_hi=3&_pos=8 ''Kashmir, Gender and Militarization in''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211082042/http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t343/e0165?_hi=3&_pos=8 |date=11 February 2017 }}. Oxford University Press. In this respect the motive and intent of rape in Kashmir was no different from the Balkans and Rwanda, where rape functioned as a cultural weapon of war against women and against the community at large (Kesic, 2000)...Rape and sexual abuse is an integral part of the Indian counteroffensive in Kashmir Kazi opines that rape in Kashmir is a cultural weapon of war and the rape of [[Kashmiris|Kashmiri]] women by Indian security forces, in the context of a predominantly Hindu state repressing a Muslim minority population, functions as a tool of subordinating Kashmiri men and the Kashmiri community at large.Kazi, Seema. "[http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf Rape, Impunity and Justice in Kashmir.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118224034/http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf |date=2016-11-18 }}" ''Socio-Legal Rev.'' 10 (2014): 27. She also states that rape is used to demoralize the Kashmiri resistance and that there have been documented cases of soldiers confessing that they were ordered to rape women.Kazi, Seema. "[http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf Rape, Impunity and Justice in Kashmir] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118224034/http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf |date=2016-11-18 }}." ''Socio-Legal Rev.'' 10 (2014): 29.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=f9xB4JKOfvYC&pg=PA229 | title = Gender, Power, and Military Occupations: Asia Pacific and the Middle East since 1945 | first = | date = 27 April 2012 | publisher = Taylor & Francis | year = | isbn = 978-1-136-33934-9 | location = | pages = 229– | quote = These record a pattern of rape by soldiers who often claim to be following orders. | author1 = Christine De Matos | author2 = Rowena Ward }} Professor William Baker stated at the 52nd United Nations Commission on Human Rights that rape in Kashmir was not the result of a few undisciplined soldiers but an active strategy of the security forces to humiliate and intimidate the Kashmiri population.Ranjan, Amit. "[http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0049085715589471 A Gender Critique of AFSPA: Security for Whom?]." ''Social Change'' 45.3 (2015): 447. He cited as evidence his interviews with several rape victims who were raped by soldiers in front of their families, including husbands and children.Kazi, Seema (2014). [http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf "Rape, Impunity And Justice in Kashmir"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118224034/http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf |date=18 November 2016 }} (PDF). ''Socio-Legal Review''. '''10''': 28. An [[Amnesty International]] report in 1992 stated that rape in Kashmir was a systematic attempt to humiliate the local population during counter-insurgency operations.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Rz4bJ3ejsisC&pg=PA47 | title = The Kashmir Question: Retrospect and Prospect | date = 1 March 2004 | publisher = Routledge | isbn = 978-1-135-75658-1 | pages = 47– | first = Sumit | last = Ganguly }} Dr Maiti, a professor of political science at Burdwan University, has denounced the use of rape as an instrument of Indian oppression against the Kashmiri population, where the majority of victims are civilians.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=L3m6zHRdPWIC&pg=PA143 | title = Feminism, Literature and Rape Narratives: Violence and Violation | date = 6 August 2012 | publisher = Routledge | isbn = 978-1-136-61584-9 | pages = 143– | author1 = Sorcha Gunne | author2 = Zoe Brigley Thompson }} During some interviews of soldiers on why they raped local Kashmiri women, some responded that Kashmiri women were beautiful. Others said it was a non-family station. In one case, a soldier replied that he raped a Kashmiri woman out of revenge because "their men did exactly the same to the women of his community''.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=P11RrRzbDyoC&pg=PA114 | title = In the Valley of Mist: Kashmir's long war: one family's extraordinary story | date = 15 December 2010 | publisher = Ebury Publishing | Ritu | publisher = EQUATIONS | year = | isbn = | location = | pages = 131– }} === Extent === A study in 2008 by [[Médecins Sans Frontières]] concluded that Kashmiri women are among the worst sufferers of sexual violence in the world, with 11.6% of respondents, out of a total 510 people in the survey, saying they had been sexually abused.{{Cite book | url = publisher = Springer | year = | isbn = 9788132224259 | location = | pages = 85 | language = en }} The study also found that the number of people who had witnessed a rape in Kashmir was far higher than rapes.[https://web.archive.org/web/20131108061947/http://www.artsenzondergrenzen.nl/pdf/KASHMIRFINALVERSION221106.pdf "Médecins Sans Frontières – Kashmir: Violence and Health"] (PDF).
