''Socio-Legal Rev.'' 10 (2014): 22–23. According to scholars Rawwida Baksh and Wendy Harcourt, the high rate of sexual violence in Kashmir is little known internationally. Scholar Dara Kay Cohen lists the conflict in Kashmir among the worst of the so-called mass rape wars including Bosnia and Rwanda.Cohen, Dara Kay. "[https://cisac.fsi.stanford.edu/sites/default/files/Cohen_APSR.pdf Explaining rape during civil war: Cross-national evidence (1980–2009).] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150824175503/http://cisac.fsi.stanford.edu/sites/default/files/Cohen_APSR.pdf |date=2015-08-24 }}" ''American Political Science Review'' 107.03 (2013): 467. According to Human Rights Watch:[https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF "Rape in Kashmir: A Crime of War"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904012347/http://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF |date=4 September 2012 }} (PDF). ''Asia Watch & Physicians for Human Rights A Division of Human Rights Watch''. '''5''' (9): 3.
There are no reliable statistics on the number of rapes committed by security forces in Kashmir. Human rights groups have documented many cases since 1990, but because many of the incidents have occurred in remote villages, it is impossible to confirm any precise number. There can be no doubt that the use of rape is common and routinely goes unpunished.
Indian security forces reportedly gang-raped 882 women in 1992 alone.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=k05FtHAc50AC&pg=PA27 | title = Shattered Lives: Sexual Violence During the Rwandan Genocide and Its Aftermath | publisher = Human Rights Watch | year = 1996 | isbn = 978-1-56432-208-1 | pages = 27– | author1 = Binaifer Nowrojee | author2 = Human Rights Watch/Africa | author3 = Fédération internationale des droits de l'homme }} Humanitarian Law Project/International Educational Development verified more than 200 war rapes in the Valley and Doda district in January 1994 alone.{{Cite web | url = http://www.guidetoaction.org/parker/kash3.html | title = Kashmir Report – Part III | website = ''guidetoaction.org'' | access-date = 8 May 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20161028145342/http://www.guidetoaction.org/parker/kash3.html | archive-date = 28 October 2016 | dead-url = no | df = }} Many cases are not reported because of the shame and stigma associated with rape in Kashmir.Kazi, Seema. "[http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf Rape, Impunity and Justice in Kashmir] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118224034/http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf |date=2016-11-18 }}." ''Socio-Legal Rev.'' 10 (2014): 20. Human rights groups state that 150 top officers, of the rank of major or above, have participated in torture as well as sexual violence and that the Indian government was covering up such acts.{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/dec/16/wikileaks-cables-indian-torture-kashmir#comments | title = WikiLeaks cables: India accused of systematic use of torture in Kashmir | last = Burke | first = Jason | date = 16 December 2010 | work = The Guardian }}{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/12/indian-forces-kashmir-accused-human-rights-abuses-coverup | title = Indian forces in Kashmir accused of human rights abuses cover-up | last = Burke | first = Jason | date = 11 September 2015 | work = The Guardian }} In 2016, Kashmiri human rights activist and lawyer [[Parvez Imroz]] has said that a vast majority of cases of sexual harassment by Indian forces in Kashmir go unreported.{{Cite news | url = https://tribune.com.pk/story/1266096/sexual-abuse-kashmiri-women-hands-indian-security-forces/ | title = Sexual abuse of Kashmiri women at the hands of Indian security forces – The Express Tribune | date = 17 December 2016 | work = The Express Tribune | access-date = 5 May 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20161219151710/http://tribune.com.pk/story/1266096/sexual-abuse-kashmiri-women-hands-indian-security-forces/ | archive-date = 19 December 2016 | dead-url = no | df = }} Rape by security forces has notably occurred in areas of militant presence or activity.Kazi, Seema. "[http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf Rape, Impunity and Justice in Kashmir.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118224034/http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf |date=2016-11-18 }}" ''Socio-Legal Rev.'' 10 (2014): 23. It has also happened to women from the [[Gurjar|Gujjar]] community, who live on the periphery of Kashmiri society. According to journalist Freny Manecksha, who tried to document conflict-related rapes in Kashmir in 2012–2013, their remote location has made them even more vulnerable to sexual violence.{{Cite web | url = http://www.dailyo.in/politics/kashmir-women-in-conflict-sexual-assault/story/1/16948.html | title = How does a Kashmiri woman tell the world her story of rape and sexual violence by security forces? | last = Excerpted from: Behold, I Shine: Narratives of Kashmir's Women and Children, by Freny Manecksha; Rupa Publications India. | website = dailyo.in | access-date = 5 May 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170504102914/http://www.dailyo.in/politics/kashmir-women-in-conflict-sexual-assault/story/1/16948.html | archive-date = 4 May 2017 | dead-url = no | df = }} === Aftermath === Assaulted women continue to suffer severe physical and emotional consequences. Women and their male relatives suffer 'collective shaming' as their ''izzat'' (honour) is deemed to be lost. The men are seen to have failed to protect the honour of their mothers, wives and daughters. In conservative societies sexual assaults and the accompanying forced impregnations affect a man's reputation. According to Molen and Bal, "the authorities have deliberately inflicted collective dishonor—and in fact defeat—through appropriating Kashmiri men's control of women's ''izzat.''''Van Der Molen, Thomas, and Ellen Bal. "[http://www.berghahnjournals.com/view/journals/focaal/2011/60/focaal600108.xml Staging "small, Small Incidents": Dissent, Gender, and Militarization among Young People in Kashmir] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170115121339/http://www.berghahnjournals.com/view/journals/focaal/2011/60/focaal600108.xml |date=15 January 2017 }}." ''Focaal Journal of Global and Historical Anthropology ''60 (2011): 93–107. According to Hafsa Kanjwal in SAGAR research journal of University of Texas Austin, that since Kashmiri society misplaces the blame of rape on the victim, women suffer from more psychological burdens and the victims internalize the concepts of shame and impurity attached to them. This feeling often leads to not just depression but also a breakdown in marriages, breakup of families and sometimes even suicide.Kanjwal, Hafsa. "[https://static1.squarespace.com/static/5195078de4b0af15cc42c774/t/51bfba89e4b0356bbe298c39/1371519625770/Sagar-XX.pdf Women in Kashmir: A Feminist Autoethnography] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180326124047/https://static1.squarespace.com/static/5195078de4b0af15cc42c774/t/51bfba89e4b0356bbe298c39/1371519625770/Sagar-XX.pdf |date=2018-03-26 }}." ''SAGAR South Asia Graduate Research Journal'' 20 (2011): 57–61. An example would be the case of a 16-year-old girl, Hameeda, who was sexually assaulted by an Indian army official in 2004 and was for years labeled as a "spoiled good" and rejected by her relatives. Her efforts to seek compensation eventually led to the breakdown of her abusive marriage and she subsequently developed chronic depression and internalized the shame projected onto her by her community.{{Cite web | url = http://old.himalmag.com/vacancy/5218-autonomy-under-siege.html | title = Autonomy under siege | last = Kshetri | first = Indra Dhoj | website = Himal Mag | access-date = 9 May 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170704011706/http://old.himalmag.com/vacancy/5218-autonomy-under-siege.html | archive-date = 4 July 2017 | dead-url = no | df = }} Molen and Bal state that there is a tendency in Kashmir to refuse marrying anyone from a village where rape has occurred. In the villages of Kunan Poshpora, some women were rejected by their husbands after being raped by Indian soldiers. At the behest of militants, some husbands did take back their wives but habitually abused them. One such woman told interviewers that she had begged her husband to 'forgive her' but her husband still considered her as defiled by another man. There were also cases of mother-son relationships breaking down. The rapes have also cast a stigma on other women from the rape victims' families, even if they themselves were not raped. Boys are also reported to have taunted the rape victims. Women who were pregnant at the time of their rape either miscarried or delivered deformed children.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=s0anDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT96 | title = Speaking Peace: Women's Voices from Kashmir | date = 28 March 2014 | publisher = Zubaan | isbn = 978-93-83074-70-9 | pages = 96– | author = Urvashi Butalia }} Journalists [[Eric Margolis (journalist)|Eric Margolis]] and Isaac Zolton have reported that some women who were raped by Indian soldiers subsequently fled from Indian administered Kashmir to Azad Kashmir.Eric Margolis (23 November 2004). [https://books.google.com/books?id=FQGUAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA80 ''War at the Top of the World: The Struggle for Afghanistan, Kashmir and Tibet''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170420054352/https://books.google.com/books?id=FQGUAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA80 |date=20 April 2017 }}. Routledge. pp. 80–. {{ISBN|978-1-135-95559-5}}.Istvan, Zoltan (13 March 2003). [http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2003/03/0313_030313_tvpakirefugees_2.html "Refugee Crisis Worsening in Western Kashmir"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170205214223/http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2003/03/0313_030313_tvpakirefugees_2.html |date=5 February 2017 }}. ''National Geographic''. Retrieved 15 January 2017. Studies have shown that nationalist resistance in Kashmir has been heightened because of sexual assaults and other atrocities Kashmiri women have experienced, primarily at the hands of Indian security forces.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=gTptAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA156 | title = Islam in the Modern World | author = Jeffrey T. Kenney | first = | date = 15 August 2013 | publisher = Routledge | year = | isbn = 978-1-135-00795-9 | location = | pages = 156– | quote = Studies on women's lives in contemporary Kashmir show how nationalist resistance has been heightened due to the sexual assaults, displacements and loss of life suffered by Kashmiri women, primarily at the hands of Indian security forces. }} === Reactions === Human Rights Watch stated in its 1993 report that, when confronted with the evidence of rape, Indian authorities have denied the charges. The report says they have either attempted to question the integrity of the witnesses or discredit the testimony of physicians, without ordering a full inquiry. Commissioner in charge of magistrates for Kashmir, [[Wajahat Habibullah]], chose to resign after India denied the charges in 1991. In 1993, Lt. General D. S. R. Sahni, General Officer Commanding in Chief of the Northern Command, when asked about the charges of rape by the security forces in Kashmir, has alleged that the militants "trump up" charges of rape against the forces. He said, "A soldier conducting an operation at the dead of night is unlikely to think of rape when he is not even certain if he will return alive." According to Kazi, the Indian media has ''displayed unseemly haste in exonerating security forces'' from rape allegations.Kazi, Seema. "[http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf Rape, Impunity and Justice in Kashmir] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118224034/http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf |date=2016-11-18 }}." ''Socio-Legal Rev.'' 10 (2014): 38–39. In 2016, JNU student union president [[Kanhaiya Kumar]] became the centre of controversy after speaking out on the rape of women in Kashmir by Indian security forces. The [[Bharatiya Janata Party|BJP]] youth wing filed a complaint against him, calling him 'anti-national'.{{Cite news | url = http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/in-kashmir-women-are-raped-by-security-personnel-says-kanhaiya/ | title = In Kashmir, women are raped by security personnel: Kanhaiya Kumar | date = 9 March 2016 | work = The Indian Express | access-date = 19 April 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170420143219/http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/in-kashmir-women-are-raped-by-security-personnel-says-kanhaiya/ | archive-date = 20 April 2017 | dead-url = no | df = }} According to the report of Human Rights Watch, the common use of rape by Indian security forces in the conflict drew little international condemnation, despite reports in the international press and by Indian human rights groups.[https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF "Rape in Kashmir: A Crime of War"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904012347/http://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF |date=4 September 2012 }} (PDF). ''Asia Watch & Physicians for Human Rights A Division of Human Rights Watch''. '''5''' (9): 2. According to scholar Amit Ranjan, the Indian state has always sided with the perpetrators and not the rape victimsRanjan, Amit. "A [http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0049085715589471 Gender Critique of AFSPA: Security for Whom?]." ''Social Change'' 45.3 (2015): 446. and Indian society is generally not disturbed by rapes in Kashmir due to Kashmiri Muslims being considered the 'other'.Ranjan, Amit. "[http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0049085715589471 A Gender Critique of AFSPA: Security for Whom?]." ''Social Change'' 45.3 (2015): 450. ''Against such a background, it is difficult to garner solidarity over the issue of rapes in India....The feeling of otherness is strong in Indian society, which is socially, culturally and religiously based on the practice of discrimination against the outsider....Muslims, especially from Kashmir, in the popular imagination, are seen as the ‘other’, so if anything untoward happens in these areas, it does not disturb the popular definition of ‘security’.'' At the same time, Ranjan says that the Kashmir Valley's disputed status between India and Pakistan has given it the advantage of some international attention. Former Pakistani Prime Minister, [[Benazir Bhutto]], in her address to the [[Fourth World Conference on Women]] at Beijing in 1995, called the use of rape as a weapon of war in Jammu and Kashmir ''reprehensible'' and ''depraved''.{{Cite web | url = https://www.un.org/esa/gopher-data/conf/fwcw/conf/gov/950904202603.txt | title = 95-09-04: Statement by Pakistan, HE Mohtarma Benazir Bhutto | website = | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170421002443/http://www.un.org/esa/gopher-data/conf/fwcw/conf/gov/950904202603.txt | archive-date = 21 April 2017 | dead-url = no | df = }} Feminist commentators are critical of the way Kashmiri men have addressed the issue of rape. According to Kazi, Kashmiri men feel helpless and bewildered at the rape of their women. But Kazi also complains that while [[Yasin Malik]] of the [[Jammu Kashmir Liberation Front|Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front]] acknowledged the assaults by the Indian Army on Kashmiri women, he failed to address the torture and stigma which Kashmiri society then imposes on the rape victims.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=vE_RDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT192 | title = Undoing Impunity: Speech after Sexual Violence | date = 28 November 2016 | publisher = Zubaan | isbn = 978-93-85932-15-1 | pages = 192– | author = V. Geetha }} According to journalist Syed Junaid Hashmi, both separatists and mainstream political parties in Kashmir have ignored the rape victims. Hashmi says that the state governments order inquiries which turn out inconclusive while those guilty are rewarded for fighting militancy. Separatists address the plight of the victims by saying, 'they have lost their honour for a greater cause'. Separatist leader Shahidul Islam commented, "I know by merely giving statements, honour lost by our daughters, sisters and mothers cannot be restored. They expected a lot more from the separatist leadership than what it has been doing, unfortunately we failed in pursuing the cause of our women vigorously."{{Cite web | url = http://www.countercurrents.org/kashmir-hashmi310307.htm | title = Conflict Rape Victims: Abandoned And Forgotten | last = Hashmi | first = Syed Junaid | date = 31 March 2007 | website = Counter Currents | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100613050951/http://countercurrents.org/kashmir-hashmi310307.htm | archive-date = 13 June 2010 | dead-url = no }} === Prosecution === In 1994, due to the international pressure, some court-martials of soldiers accused of rape were made public by the Indian government. In one such case, two soldiers were sentenced to twelve year imprisonment, on 29 July 1994, for raping a village girl in Kashmir. However, many documented cases of rape were refused to be prosecuted by the authorities.{{Cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=hDtXKy85XdgC&pg=PA129#v=onepage&q&f=false | title = Human Rights | last = Kumar | first = Anuradha | publisher = Sarup & Sons | year = 2002 | isbn = 9788176253222 | location = New Delhi | pages = 129- | language = en | chapter = Rape by Security Forces: The Pattern of Impunity }}{{Cite web | url = https://www.hrw.org/legacy/about/projects/womrep/General-42.htm | title = Rape by Security Forces: The Pattern of Impunity | publisher = Human Rights Watch | access-date = 1 May 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171012104533/https://www.hrw.org/legacy/about/projects/womrep/General-42.htm | archive-date = 12 October 2017 | dead-url = no | df = }} According to Kazi, of all the human rights violations in Kashmir, rape has drawn the least investigations and prosecutions.Kazi, Seema. "[http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf Rape, Impunity and Justice in Kashmir] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118224034/http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf |date=2016-11-18 }}." ''Socio-Legal Rev.'' 10 (2014): 25–26. In the case of the February 1991 [[Kunan Poshpora incident|mass rapes in Kunan Poshpora]], ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that the 'Indian Government issued a statement saying that the sexual assaults never took place'.{{Cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/07/world/india-moves-against-kashmir-rebels.html | title = India Moves Against Kashmir Rebels | last = Crossette | first = Barbara | date = 7 April 1991 | work = The New York Times | access-date = 1 May 2017 | issn = 0362-4331 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170228053016/http://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/07/world/india-moves-against-kashmir-rebels.html | archive-date = 28 February 2017 | dead-url = no | df = }} Human Rights Watch also highlighted the fact in its 1993 report that despite the evidence of widespread sexual violence perpetrated by the Indian army and paramilitary forces, few of the incidents were ever investigated by the authorities and no prosecution of alleged rapists ever occurred. According to the 1996 HRW report, in many cases these incidents "are never investigated by judicial and medical authorities". According to Kazi, this indicates tolerance, if not official consent, of the State to such crimes. According to Mathur, the Indian government provides legal immunity to its personnel who are accused of rape.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=PeYdCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT63 | title = The Human Toll of the Kashmir Conflict: Grief and Courage in a South Asian Borderland | date = 1 February 2016 | publisher = Palgrave Macmillan US | isbn = 978-1-137-54622-7 | pages = 63– | author = Shubh Mathur }} [[Inger Skjelsbæk|Skhjelsbaek]] states that the denial of rape by Indian authorities is systematic and the lack of prosecution allows acts of sexual violence to be perpetrated with impunity in Kashmir. Scholars Christine De Matos and Rowena Ward have observed that the official cover-ups follow a pattern of labeling the victims as 'militant sympathisers', questioning the honesty of their claims and persecuting human rights activists and medical personnel who try to assist the rape victims. According to scholars Om Prakash Dwivedi and V. G. Julie Rajan, the [[Armed Forces (Special Powers) Act|Armed Forces Special Powers Act]] (AFSPA) has enabled the Indian military and security personnel to commit war crimes with impunity.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=6NCjCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA11 | title = Human Rights in Postcolonial India | date = 26 February 2016 | publisher = Routledge | isbn = 978-1-317-31012-9 | pages = 11– | author1 = Om Prakash Dwivedi | author2 = V. G. Julie Rajan }} The Indian military was given special powers under AFSPA in Kashmir in July 1990. Human rights groups criticize this law, stating it gives immunity to armed forces personnel who have committed crimes.Egyesült, Államok (2008). ''Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 2007''. House, Committee on Foreign Affairs, and Senate, Committee on Foreign Relations. p. 2195. {{ISBN|9780160813993}}. The Army sources maintain that "any move to revoke AFSPA in Jammu and Kashmir would be detrimental to the security of the Valley and would provide a boost to the terrorists."{{Cite news | url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Army-opposes-Omars-plans-to-revoke-AFSPA-Report/articleshow/4197012.cms | title = Army opposes Omar's plans to revoke AFSPA: Report – Times of India | work = The Times of India | access-date = 6 May 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171012072106/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Army-opposes-Omars-plans-to-revoke-AFSPA-Report/articleshow/4197012.cms | archive-date = 12 October 2017 | dead-url = no | df = }} As per AFSPA, Kashmiris who need to go to a civilian court to press charges against any security force personnel for human rights violations are required to first seek the permission of the Indian government. According to Kazi, such permission is 'never forthcoming'. The AFSPA legislation has been described as "hated" and "draconian'' by members of [[Jammu & Kashmir Human Rights Commission|Kashmir's State Human Rights Commission]].Kazi, Seema (2014). [http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf "Rape, Impunity And Justice in Kashmir"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118224034/http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf |date=2016-11-18 }} (PDF). ''Socio-Legal Review''. '''10''': 30. The local judiciary in Kashmir is unable to function normally because of the privileges granted to the security forces.Kazi, Seema. "[http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf Rape, Impunity and Justice in Kashmir] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118224034/http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf |date=18 November 2016 }}." ''Socio-Legal Rev.'' 10 (2014): 33.Ranjan, Amit. "A Gender Critique of AFSPA: Security for Whom?." ''Social Change'' 45.3 (2015): 440–457. According to Human Rights Watch, the military courts in India, in general, were proved to be incompetent to deal with cases of serious human rights abuses and were responsible in covering up evidence and protecting the involved officers. Amnesty International in its report in 2015, titled ''"Denied"-Failures in Accountability in Jammu and Kashmir'', says, "...with respect to investigations, an inquiry that is conducted by the same authority accused of the crime raises serious questions about the independence and impartiality of those proceedings", adding that according to the international law, an independent authority that is not involved in the alleged violations has to investigate such crimes.{{Cite web | url = http://kashmirreader.com/2016/09/03/96-complaints-against-army-rejected-by-goi-under-colonial-afspa-amnesty/ | title = 96% complaints against army rejected by GoI under ‘colonial’ AFSPA: Amnesty | last = Correspondent | first = Reader | date = 3 September 2016 | website = Kashmir Reader | access-date = 1 May 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170804103846/http://kashmirreader.com/2016/09/03/96-complaints-against-army-rejected-by-goi-under-colonial-afspa-amnesty/ | archive-date = 4 August 2017 | dead-url = no | df = }} [[Khurram Parvez]] remarks that women fear reprisals from the Army to file the cases of rape. He says, "this is because there are cases in which when rape was reported, members of their families were attacked or prosecuted." He also states that it would be technically very difficult to prove rape, since the incidents happen in the areas which are completely under the Army's control.{{Cite news | url = https://scroll.in/article/812010/do-you-need-700000-soldiers-to-fight-150-militants-kashmiri-rights-activist-khurram-parvez | title = 'Do you need 700,000 soldiers to fight 150 militants?': Kashmiri rights activist Khurram Parvez | last = Ashraf | first = Ajaz | work = Scroll.in | access-date = 21 April 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170113152649/https://scroll.in/article/812010/do-you-need-700000-soldiers-to-fight-150-militants-kashmiri-rights-activist-khurram-parvez | archive-date = 13 January 2017 | dead-url = no | df = }} Dwivedi and Rajan point out that India has been able to commit crimes against humanity, such as mass rape, with impunity in Kashmir because of its alliance with permanent members in the [[United Nations Security Council]], such as the [[United States|US]], and also because it is not part of the [[International Criminal Court]] (ICC). India refuses to join the ICC by contending that its own judicial system is competent enough to address war crimes. However, law expert Usha Ramanathan labels this argument misleading.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=6NCjCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA11 | title = Human Rights in Postcolonial India | date = 26 February 2016 | publisher = Routledge | isbn = 978-1-317-31012-9 | pages = 11– | author1 = Om Prakash Dwivedi | author2 = V. G. Julie Rajan }} In 2013, 50 women filed a [[Public interest litigation in India|public interest litigation]] (PIL) in the [[Jammu and Kashmir High Court]] in order to reopen investigations of the alleged mass rapes of February 1991 in Kunan Poshpora.{{Cite news | url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/PIL-seeks-reopening-of-1991-Kashmir-mass-rapes/articleshow/19794622.cms?referral=PM | title = PIL seeks reopening of 1991 Kashmir ‘mass rapes’ | last = Pandit | first = M. Saleem | date = 30 April 2013 | work = The Times of India | access-date = 1 May 2017 }}{{Cite news | url = http://www.womenundersiegeproject.org/blog/entry/the-long-struggle-against-systematic-rape-in-conflict-ridden-kashmir | title = The long struggle against systematic rape in conflict-ridden Kashmir | last = Pervez | first = Ayesha | date = 21 May 2013 | work = Women Under Siege | access-date = 1 May 2017 | publisher = Women's Media Center | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170115050629/http://www.womenundersiegeproject.org/blog/entry/the-long-struggle-against-systematic-rape-in-conflict-ridden-kashmir | archive-date = 15 January 2017 | dead-url = no }} == Rape by militants (post-1988) == {{See also|Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir| Exodus of Kashmiri Hindus}} According to the 1993 Human Rights Watch report, rape by militants is less common but has increased in frequency over the years.{{Cite journal | title = Rape in Kashmir: A Crime of War | url = https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF | journal = Asia Watch & Physicians for Human Rights A Division of Human Rights Watch | volume = 5 | issue = 9 | page = 4|= | access-date = 21 July 2012 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120904012347/http://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF | archive-date = 4 September 2012 | dead-url = no | df = }} A 2010 US state department report blamed separatist insurgents in Kashmir and other parts of the country of committing several serious abuses, including the killing of security personnel as well as civilians, and of engaging in widespread torture, rape, beheadings, kidnapping, and extortion.{{cite web | url = https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2010/sca/154480.htm | title = 2010 Human Rights Reports: India | publisher = State.gov | accessdate = 10 March 2012 }} Some incidents of rape by militants appear to have been motivated by the fact that the victims or their families are accused of being informers or of being opposed to the militants or supporters of rival militant groups. In 1989, attacks on Pandits escalated and Muslim insurgents selectively raped, tortured and killed Kashmiri Pandits, burnt their temples, idols and holy books. The Pandits fled en masse from the state after which their houses were burnt by militants and their artwork and sculptures were destroyed.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=67CWswHay3QC&pg=PA77 | title = Burning books and leveling libraries: extremist violence and cultural destruction | last = Knuth | first = Rebecca | publisher = Greenwood Publishing Group | year = 2006 | isbn = 978-0-275-99007-7 | pages = 77–79 | accessdate = 15 March 2012 }} While cases of systematic rape of Kashmiri Muslim women by the Indian military are well documented, the details and scale of sexual violence against Kashmiri Pandit women remain yet to be researched. In the meantime, some Pandit organisations have used the exaggerated narratives of gang rape by Muslims for their propaganda.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=1wB2DQAAQBAJ&pg=PT305 | title = Conflicted Democracies and Gendered Violence: Internal Conflict and Social Upheaval in India | date = 4 November 2016 | publisher = Zubaan | isbn = 978-93-85932-11-3 | pages = 305– | author1 = Angana P. Chatterji | author2 = Shashi Buluswar | author3 = Mallika Kaur }} According to Human Rights Watch, despite threats by Islamist groups to women since 1990, reports of rape by militants were rare in the early years of the conflict. Since 1991, reports of rape by Islamic militants have increased. In some cases, women have been raped and then killed after being abducted by rival militant groups and held as hostages for their male relatives. In other cases, members of armed militant groups have abducted women after threatening to shoot the rest of the family unless she is handed over to a militant leader. Local people sometimes refer to these abductions and rapes as "forced marriages".{{Cite journal | title = Rape in Kashmir: A Crime of War | url = https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF | journal = Asia Watch & Physicians for Human Rights A Division of Human Rights Watch | volume = 5 | issue = 9 | page = 15|= | access-date = 21 July 2012 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120904012347/http://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF | archive-date = 4 September 2012 | dead-url = no | df = }} In 1992, a case of rape and murder by militants attracted publicity, partly because the incident provoked street protests condemning the militants for the crimes.{{Cite journal | title = Rape in Kashmir: A Crime of War | url = https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF | journal = Asia Watch & Physicians for Human Rights A Division of Human Rights Watch | volume = 5 | issue = 9 | page = 16–17|= | access-date = 21 July 2012 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120904012347/http://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF | archive-date = 4 September 2012 | dead-url = no | df = }} According to the Human Rights Watch, the rape victims of militants suffer ostracism and there is a "code of silence and fear" that prevents people from reporting such abuse. It says that the investigation of cases of rape by militants is difficult because many Kashmiris are reluctant to discuss it for the fear of violent reprisals.[https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA937.PDF The Human Rights Crisis in Kashmir] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180803161402/https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA937.PDF |date=3 August 2018 }}. Asia Watch, a division of [[Human Rights Watch]]. Lat. Retrieved 10 March 2012. Also published as a book: {{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=X0QQx5ObGysC&pg=PA154 | title = The Human rights crisis in Kashmir: a pattern of impunity | publisher = Human Rights Watch | year = 1993 | isbn = 978-1-56432-104-6 | page = 154 | author1 = Asia Watch Committee (U.S.) | author2 = Human Rights Watch (Organization) | author3 = Physicians for Human Rights (U.S.) | accessdate = 10 March 2012 }} The increase in number of rape cases has resulted in an increased number of abortions, leading in one case to murder of a doctor. The doctor was accused of being an informer by the Islamic militant groups [[Hizbul Mujahideen]] and Al Jehad. == Reported cases == === Indian security forces === * Jamir Qadeem (1990): On 26 June 1990, a twenty-four-year-old woman from Jamir Qadeem was raped during a search of her neighbourhood by the BSF. Police in Sopore registered a case against the BSF in July of that year.Kazi, Seema. "[http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf Rape, Impunity and Justice in Kashmir] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118224034/http://www.sociolegalreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Rape-Impunity-and-Justice-in-Kashmir.pdf |date=2016-11-18 }}." ''Socio-Legal Rev.'' 10 (2014): 21–23. * Anantnag (1990) * Chhanpora (1990): On 7 March, CRPF raided several houses in the Chhanpora locality of Srinagar. During the raids a number of women were raped. The 'Committee for Initiative in Kashmir' which visited the Valley between 12 and 16 March 1990 interviewed the victims. Rape victim Noora (24) was forcefully dragged out of her kitchen by 20 men from the CRPF and raped, along with her sister-in-law Zaina. The rape victims also witnessed two minor girls being molested.{{Cite book | url = http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in/bitstream/10603/129070/18/12_chapter%205.pdf | title = CHAPTER-V PROBLEM OF HUMAN RIGHTS IN JAMMU AND KASHMIR | last = | first = | publisher = | year = | isbn = | location = | pages = 224 | access-date = 19 April 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170420045916/http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in/bitstream/10603/129070/18/12_chapter%205.pdf | archive-date = 20 April 2017 | dead-url = no | df = }} * Panzgam (1990) * Trehgam (1990) * Barbar Shah (1991): A mentally ill old woman was raped by security forces in Srinagar.Bhat, Aashaq Hussain, and R. Moorthy. [http://oaji.net/articles/2016/1170-1479315533.pdf "Impact of Security Provisions in Kashmir] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170420050927/http://oaji.net/articles/2016/1170-1479315533.pdf |date=20 April 2017 }}." (2016). * [[Kunan Poshpora incident|Kunan Poshpora]] (1991): On 23 February 1991, a unit of the [[Indian army]] launched a search and interrogation operation in the twin villages of Kunan Poshpora, in the Valley's Kupwara district. Soldiers repeatedly gang-raped many women, with estimates of the number of victims ranging from 23 to 100. * Pazipora-Ballipora (1991): On 20 August 1991, soldiers carried out mass rape in this hamlet, which is only a few kilometres away from Kunan Poshpora. The number of rape victims in this case varied between eight and fifteen or more. * Chak Saidpora (1992): On 10 October 1992, an army unit of the 22nd Grenadiers entered the village of Chak Saidapora. Several army soldiers gang-raped between six and nine women, including an 11-year-old girl and a 60-year-old woman.[https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF "Rape in Kashmir: A Crime of War"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904012347/http://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF |date=4 September 2012 }} (PDF). ''Asia Watch & Physicians for Human Rights A Division of Human Rights Watch''. '''5''' (9): 8. * Haran (1992): On 20 July 1992 women were raped during an army search operation. One victim, interviewed by Asia Watch and PHR, reported being gang-raped by two soldiers in turns. Another victim in the same incident was raped by a Sikh soldier while another stood guard.[https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF "Rape in Kashmir: A Crime of War"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904012347/http://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF |date=4 September 2012 }} (PDF). ''Asia Watch & Physicians for Human Rights A Division of Human Rights Watch''. '''5''' (9): 12. * Gurihakhar (1992): On 1 October 1992, after killing ten people in the hamlet of Bakhikar, BSF forces entered the nearby village of Gurihakhar and raped women. One woman, interviewed by Asia Watch, tried to hide her daughter's identity as a rape victim by describing herself as the rape victim, to protect her daughter from public humiliation.[https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF "Rape in Kashmir: A Crime of War"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904012347/http://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/INDIA935.PDF |date=4 September 2012 }} (PDF). ''Asia Watch & Physicians for Human Rights A Division of Human Rights Watch''. '''5''' (9): 13. * Bijbehara (1993): Before the Bijbehara massacre there was a large incident of molestation and gang rape in Bijbehara, which elders hushed up due to fear it would bring shame to the families of rape victims. Later, in August, army men raped a woman in Gadhangipora, on the outskirts of Bijbehara town, in retaliation for an attack by militants.{{Cite web | url = http://www.countercurrents.org/kashmir-shibli281006.htm | title = The Massacre of a Town By Murtaza Shibli | website = ''countercurrents.org'' | access-date = 8 May 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160303234143/http://www.countercurrents.org/kashmir-shibli281006.htm | archive-date = 3 March 2016 | dead-url = no | df = }} * Hyhama (1994): On 17 June 1994, seven women were raped by troops of Rashtriya Rifles, including two officers Major Ramesh and Raj Kumar in the village Hyhama. * Sheikhpora Incident (1994): A 60-year-old woman was raped while men of her family were locked away. * Kangan (1994): A woman and her 12-year-old daughter were raped by Indian security forces at Theno Budapathary. * Wurwun (1995): On 30 December 1995, soldiers from the Rashtriya Rifles entered a house in Wurwun village, district Pulwama, and sexually assaulted and attempted to rape three women. * Narbal Pingalgom (1997): A girl was raped in Pulwama in November 1997. * Srinagar (1997): On 13 April 1997, Indian troops stripped naked and gang raped twelve young Kashmiri girls near Srinagar.{{cite book | last1 = Van Praagh | first1 = David | title = Greater Game: India's Race with Destiny and China | date = 2003 | publisher = [[McGill-Queen's University Press]] | isbn = 978-0-7735-2588-7 | page = 390 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=TbpU0HngYhoC&pg=PA390 | accessdate = 15 August 2017 }} * Wavoosa (1997): On 22 April 1997, several Indian armed forces personnel entered the house of a 32-year-old woman in the village of Wavoosa. They molested her 12-year-old daughter and raped three other daughters, aged 14, 16 and 18. Another woman was beaten for preventing the rape of her daughters by soldiers.[https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/asa20/024/1997/en/ "India: High Time to Put an End to Impunity in Jammu and Kashmir"] (PDF). 15 May 1997. Archived from [https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/asa20/024/1997/en/ the original] (PDF) on 29 October 2013. Retrieved 8 January 2010. * Doda (1998): A fifty-year-old resident of the village Ludna in Doda district told Human Rights Watch that on 5 October 1998 the Eighth Rashtriya Rifles came to her house, took her and beat her. She was then raped by a captain who was a Hindu and said to her: "You are Muslims, and you will all be treated like this."{{Cite web | url = https://www.hrw.org/reports/1999/kashmir/doda.htm#P187_42784 | title = Under Siege: Doda and the Border Districts | publisher = Human Rights Watch | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20161118223915/https://www.hrw.org/reports/1999/kashmir/doda.htm#P187_42784 | archive-date = 18 November 2016 | dead-url = no | df = }} * Bihota (2000): On 29 October 2000, there was a cordon and search operation in Bihota by the 15 Bihar Regiment. during which one woman was picked up and taken away to a camp. The following day twenty women went a long with a few men to get the woman released. However, the women were detained for four to five hours and sexually assaulted. * Pahalgam (2002) * Zachaldara (2004) * Zero Bridge (2004): Four security personnel raped a 21-year-old woman in a guest house on 28 October. * Handwara incident (2004): A mother and her daughter were raped in Baderpayeen, Handwara on 6 November. According to [[Khurram Parvez]], programme coordinator of the Jammu and Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, officers implied that this should not be an issue since the alleged rapist was a Muslim, Major Rahman Hussain. He was later convicted for transgression into civilian property instead of rape. * [[2009 Shopian rape and murder case|Shopian]] (2009): Two women, Asiya and Nelofar Jan, were allegedly abducted, raped and murdered by Indian troops between 29 and 30 May at Bongam in Kashmir's [[Shopian district]]. * Gujjardara-Manzgam (2011) === Militants === * In March 1990, the wife of a BSF inspector was kidnapped, tortured and gang-raped for many days. Then her body with broken limbs was abandoned on a road.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=pS5uAAAAMAAJ | title = The Lost Rebellion | date = January 1999 | publisher = Penguin Books | isbn = 978-0-14-027846-0 | author = Manoj Joshi }}{{rp|64}} * On 14 April 1990, a Kashmiri Pandit nurse from the [[Sher-i-Kashmir Institute of Medical Sciences|Soura Medical College Hospital]] in [[Srinagar]] was gang-raped and then beaten to death. [[Jammu Kashmir Liberation Front]] (JKLF) took responsibility for the crime, accusing the woman of informing the police about the presence of militants in the hospital.{{cite web | url = http://www.rediff.com/news/2005/jan/19kanch.htm | title = 19/01/90: When Kashmiri Pandits fled Islamic terror | date = 19 January 2005 | publisher = rediff | accessdate = 10 March 2012 }} * On 6 June 1990, a lab assistant at the Government Girls High School Trehgam, was kidnapped and gang raped for many days. Then she was sliced at a [[sawmill]].{{cite book | title = Speaking peace: women's voices from Kashmir | publisher = Zed Books | year = 2002 | isbn = 978-1-84277-209-6 | page = 187 | author = Urvashi Butalia }} * Another women was abducted with her husband in Sopore. She was gang-raped for a number of days before the both were killed in November 1990.{{cite book | title = Uncivil wars: pathology of terrorism in India | publisher = HarperCollins | isbn = 978-81-7223-251-1 | page = 381 | author1 = Ved Marwah | author2 = Centre for Policy Research (New Delhi, India) }} * On 5 May 1990, a Muslim teenage girl was tortured for two days, gang raped and shot dead by [[Farooq Ahmed Dar]] of the [[JKLF]].{{cite web | title = It's Jihad in Kashmir; Deal With It As Such | url = https://swarajyamag.com/politics/its-jihad-in-kashmir-deal-with-it-as-such }}{{cite book | last1 = Tikoo | first1 = Colonel Tej K. | title = Kashmir: Its Aborigines and Their Exodus | publisher = Lancer Publishers LLC | isbn = 978-1-935501-58-9 | page = 434 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iuURFTHTU0EC | language = en }} * On 13 August 1990, a teacher in the Education Department, was gang raped in her house in the presence of her family and then killed.{{cite book | last1 = Dhar | first1 = D. N. | title = Kashmir, a Kaleidoscopic View | publisher = Kanishka Publishers, Distributors | isbn = 9788173917301 | page = 152 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=p0NuAAAAMAAJ&q | language = en }} * On 30 March 1992, armed militants demanded food and shelter from the family of the retired truck driver in Nai Sadak, Kralkhud. The family complied, but the militants raped his daughter. When he and his wife tried to stop them, he was shot dead. His elderly wife was also raped. Then both the women were also shot dead. * Journalist Prakriiti Gupta writes that there have been many cases of militants raping the young girls by forcing them into temporary marriages ([[Nikah mut‘ah|mutah]] in Islamic law) – these ceremonies are called "command marriages".{{cite news | url = http://archive.deccanherald.com/Deccanherald/feb242006/she1749442006223.asp | title = Married to brutality | date = 25 February 2006 | work = Deccan Herald | accessdate = 10 March 2012 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140315172145/http://archive.deccanherald.com/Deccanherald/feb242006/she1749442006223.asp | archive-date = 15 March 2014 | deadurl = yes | df = }} * In 2005, a 14-year-old Gujjar girl was abducted from Lurkoti village by the Lashkar-e-Taiba militants, and forced to marry one of them. [[File:Ldlv.jpg|thumb|300x300px|Exterior of Little Darlings strip club in [[Las Vegas|Las Vegas, Nevada]] owned by [[Déjà Vu (company)|Déjà Vu]]]]
'''Strip clubs''' are venues where [[strippers]] provide [[adult entertainment]], predominantly in the form of [[striptease]] or other [[Erotic dancing|erotic]] or exotic dances. Strip clubs typically adopt a [[nightclub]] or [[Bar (establishment)|bar]] style, and can also adopt a [[theatre]] or [[cabaret]]-style. American-style strip clubs began to appear outside [[North America]] after [[World War II]], arriving in [[Asia]] in the late 1980s and Europe in the 1978,<ref name="Shteir 2004"/> where they competed against the local English and French styles of striptease and erotic performances.
As of 2005, the size of the global strip club [[industry]] was [[estimated]] to be US$75 billion.<ref name="Jeffreys 2009"/> In 2002, the size of the U.S. strip club industry was estimated to be US$3.1 billion, generating 19% of the total gross revenue in [[legal]] [[adult entertainment]].<ref name="Lewis Purdue 2002"/> [[SEC filing]]s and state liquor control records available at that time indicated that there were at least 2,500 strip clubs in the United States,<ref name="Lewis Purdue 2002"/> and since that time, the number of clubs in the U.S. has grown. Profitability of strip clubs, as with other service-oriented businesses, is largely driven by location and customer spending habits. The better [[wikt:appointment#Noun|appointed]] a club is, in terms of its quality of facilities, equipment, furniture, and other elements, the more likely customers are to encounter cover charges and fees for premium features such as VIP rooms.<ref name="Frank 2002"/> The popularity of a given club is an indicator of its quality, as is the [[word-of-mouth]] among customers who have visited a cross section of clubs in different regions.
The strip club as an outlet for [[wikt:salacious|salacious]] entertainment is a recurrent theme in [[popular culture]].<ref name="Boles and Garbin 1974">{{cite journal | last1 = Boles | first1 = J. | last2 = Garbin | first2 = A. P. | year = 1974 | title = The Strip Club and the Customer-Stripper Patterns of Interaction | journal = Sociology and Social Research | volume = 58 | pages = 136–144}}</ref> In some media, these clubs are portrayed primarily as gathering places of [[vice]] and ill [[reputation|repute]]. Clubs themselves and various aspects of the business are highlighted in these references. "Top Strip Club" lists in some media have demonstrated that U.S.-style striptease is a global phenomenon and that it has also become a culturally accepted form of entertainment, despite its scrutiny in legal circles and popular media. Popular Internet sites for strip club enthusiasts also have lists calculated from the inputs of site visitors. The legal status of strip clubs has evolved over the course of time, with national and local laws becoming progressively more liberal on the issue around the world, although some countries (such as Iceland) have implemented strict limits and bans.<ref name="IcelandBan 2010"/> Strip clubs are frequent targets of litigation around the world, and the sex industry, which includes strip clubs, is a hot button issue in popular culture and politics. Some clubs have been linked to [[organized crime]].<ref name="TriBizJo 2007"/>
== History == {{Main|Striptease#History}}
[[File:1720 Der spanische teutsche und niederlaendische Krieg p238.png|thumb|right|upright|1720 depiction of a striptease event from ''La Guerre D'Espagne''.<ref>Image from ''Der spanische, teutsche, und niederländische Krieg oder: des Marquis von ... curieuser Lebens-Lauff'', vol. 2 (Franckfurt/ Leipzig, 1720), p.238</ref> |alt=refer to caption]]
The term "striptease" was first recorded in 1938, though "stripping", in the sense of women removing clothing to sexually excite men, seems to go back at least 400 years. For example, in [[Thomas Otway]]'s comedy ''The Soldier's Fortune'' (1681) a character says: "Be sure they be lewd, drunken, ''stripping'' whores".<ref>Robert Hendrickson (1997) ''QPB Encyclopedia of Word and Phrase Origins''. New York, Facts on File, Inc: 227</ref> Its combination with music seems to be as old. A conclusive description and visualization can be found in the 1720 German translation of the French ''La Guerre D'Espagne'' (Cologne: Pierre Marteau, 1707), where a [[galant]] party of high aristocrats and opera singers has resorted to a small château where they entertain themselves with hunting, play and music in a three-day turn:
{{Quotation|The third day, dedicated to ball and dance, was used for the finest entertainment to divert the men; their eyes were given the opportunity to see all the pleasures nature could offer; and if the pleasant aspects of a well shaped young lady are able to arouse the mind, one can say that our princes enjoyed all the delicacies of love. The dancers, to please their lovers the more, dropped their clothes and danced, totally naked, the nicest [[Entree (ballet)|entrées]] and [[ballet]]s; one of the princes directed the delightful music, and only the lovers were allowed to watch the performances.<ref>The German text reads "Am dritten Tag, so zum Ball und Tantz bestimmt war, spielte man eine der artigsten Kurtzweil, die Herren zu divertieren; Sie hatten ein solches Spectacul, welches ihren Augen alle Schönheit der Natur vorstellte: und wann die Annehmlichkeiten eines wohlgewachsenen Mädgens fähig sind, die Gemüther zu rühren, so kan man sagen, daß unsere Printzen alle Niedlichkeiten der Liebe genossen. Die Tänzerinnen, um ihren Amant desto besser zu gefallen, zohen ihre Kleider ab, und tantzten gantz nackend die schönsten Entrèen und Ballets; einer von den Printzen dirigirte dann diese entzückende Music, und stunde die Schaubühne niemand als diesen Verliebten offen.", ''Der spanische, teutsche, und niederländische Krieg oder: des Marquis von ... curieuser Lebens-Lauff'', Bd. 2 (Franckfurt/ Leipzig, 1720), S.238, recapitulated in Olaf Simons, ''Marteaus Europa oder der Roman, bevor er Literatur wurde'' (Amsterdam: Rodopi, 2001), p.617-635.</ref>}}
Other possible influences on modern stripping were the dances of the [[Ghawazee]] "discovered" and seized upon by French colonists in 19th century North Africa and [[Egypt]]. The erotic [[dance of the bee]], performed by a woman known as [[Kuchuk Hanem]], was witnessed and described by the French novelist [[Gustave Flaubert]]. In this dance the performer disrobes as she searches for an imaginary bee trapped within her garments. It is likely that the women performing these dances did not do so in an indigenous context, but rather, responded to the commercial climate for this type of entertainment.<ref name="Parramore 2008">{{cite book | title = Reading the Sphinx: Ancient Egypt in Nineteenth-Century Literary Culture | url = https://books.google.com/?id=21oWAQAAIAAJ | year = 2008 | publisher = Macmillan | isbn = 978-0-230-60328-8 | page = 132 | last1 = Parramore | first1 = Lynn}}</ref>
[[Middle Eastern]] [[belly dance]], also known as oriental dancing, was popularized in the United States after its introduction on the [[Midway (fair)|Midway]] at the [[World's Columbian Exposition|1893 World's Fair]] in [[Chicago]] by a dancer known as [[Little Egypt (dancer)|Little Egypt]].<ref name="Carlton 1994">{{cite book | title = Looking for Little Egypt | url = https://books.google.com/?id=FkgUAQAAIAAJ | year = 1994 | publisher = IDD Books | isbn = 978-0-9623998-1-7 | page = 14 | last1 = Carlton | first1 = Donna}}</ref>
=== European tradition === In France during the late 19th century, Parisian shows such as the [[Moulin Rouge]] and [[Folies Bergère]] were featuring attractive, scantily clad, dancing women and [[tableaux vivants]].<ref name="Cavendish SexAndSociety 2009">{{cite book | title = Sex and Society, Volume 1 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=aVDZchwkIMEC | year = 2009 | publisher = Marshall Cavendish Corporation | isbn = 978-0-7614-7906-2 | pages = 208–209 | last1 = Cavendish | first1 = Marshall}}</ref> In this environment, an act featuring a woman slowly removing her clothes in a vain search for a [[flea]] crawling on her body was seen in 1895 and possibly filmed in 1897 by the first female director, [[Alice Guy]].<ref name="Shteir 2004">{{cite book | last = Shteir | first = Rachel | title = Striptease: The Untold History of the Girlie Show | year = 2004 | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = New York | isbn = 978-0-19-512750-8 | pages = 31, 39, 263–266, 350}}</ref><ref name="Wallenchinsky Almanac 1978">{{cite book | title = The People's Almanac No. 2, Issue 2 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=mEdNAAAAYAAJ | year = 1978 | publisher = Marshall Cavendish Corporation | isbn = 978-0-688-03372-9 | last1 = Wallechinsky | last2 = Wallace | first1 = David | first2 = Irving}}</ref> This routine, ''Le coucher d'Yvette'', inspired "French acts" in theaters and brothels in other parts of the world, seen in the U.S. city of New York as early as 1878.<ref name="Shteir 2004"/> The first public act of striptease in modern times is credited to Parisian theater in 1894.<ref name="Patinkin 2008">{{cite book | title = No Legs, No Jokes, No Chance": a history of the American musical theater | url = https://books.google.com/?id=pGfDMaE4C5EC | year = 2008 | publisher = Northwestern University Press | isbn = 978-0-8101-1994-9 | page = 61 | last1 = Patinkin | first1 = Sheldon}}</ref>
In 1905, Dutch dancer [[Mata Hari]], later shot as a spy by the French authorities during World War I, was an overnight success from the debut of her act at the [[Musée Guimet]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crimelibrary.com/terrorists_spies/spies/hari/5.html |work=Crime Library |title=Mata Hari is Born |first=Denise |last=Noe |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150210044610/http://www.crimelibrary.com/terrorists_spies/spies/hari/5.html |archivedate=2015-02-10}}</ref> The most celebrated segment of her act was her progressive shedding of clothing until she wore just a jeweled [[Brassiere|bra]] and some ornaments over her arms and head.<ref name="MediaMatrix 2006">{{cite web | url = http://www.worldofbiography.com/9241-Mata%20Hari/life.htm | title = Mata Hari Life{{snd}}World of Biography | author = | year = 2006 | website = | publisher = Media Matrix | accessdate = 2010-07-05}}</ref> Another landmark performance was the appearance at the Moulin Rouge in 1907 of an actress called Germaine Aymos who entered dressed only in three very small shells.<ref name="Stratton 2000">{{cite book | title = The Desirable Body: cultural fetishism and the erotics of consumption | url = https://books.google.com/?id=X9EsiufsCpkC | year = 2000 | publisher = University of Illinois Press | isbn = 978-0-252-06951-2 | page = 100 | last1 = Stratton | first1 = John}}</ref> In the 1930s, the famous [[Josephine Baker]] danced semi-nude in the ''danse sauvage'' at the Folies and other such performances were provided at the Tabarin.<ref name="LondonTheatre 1988">{{cite book | title = London theatre record | url = https://books.google.com/?id=aVDZchwkIMEC | volume = 7 | year = 1988 | publisher = University of Michigan | isbn = 978-0-7614-7906-2 | page = 404 | issue = 1–13}}</ref> These shows were notable for their sophisticated choreography and for often dressing the girls in glitzy sequins and feathers. By the 1960s "fully nude" shows were provided at such places as [[Crazy Horse (cabaret)|Le Crazy Horse Saloon]].<ref name="Richard Wortley 1976">Richard Wortley (1976) ''A Pictorial History of Striptease'': 11, 29–53.</ref>
[[File:Windmill-Theatre.jpg|thumb|left|Exterior of the [[Windmill Theatre]] in [[Westminster]], [[London, England]]. |alt=refer to caption]]
In Britain in the 1930s, [[Laura Henderson]] began presenting nude shows at the [[Windmill Theatre]] in London. At that time, British law prohibited naked girls from moving. To avoid the prohibition, the models appeared in stationary tableaux vivants.<ref>Vivien Goldsmith, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/3648187/Windmill-always-nude-but-never-rude.html "Windmill: always nude but never rude"], ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'', 24 November 2005</ref> The Windmill girls also toured other London and provincial theatres, sometimes using ingenious devices such as rotating ropes to move their bodies round, though strictly speaking, staying within the letter of the law by not moving of their own volition.<ref name="Weaver Monster 2001">{{cite book | author = Tom Weaver | title = I Was a Monster Movie Maker: Conversations With 22 Sf and Horror Filmmakers | url = https://books.google.com/?id=Hx1gobckUGEC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 2001 | publisher = McFarland & Company | isbn = 978-0-7864-1000-2}}</ref> Another example of ways that the shows stayed within the law was the [[fan dance]], in which a naked dancer's body was concealed by her fans and those of her attendants, until the end of her act in when she posed naked for a brief interval whilst standing still.<ref name="Weaver Monster 2001"/>
In 1942, [[Phyllis Dixey]] formed her own company of girls and rented the [[Whitehall Theatre]] in London to put on a review called The Whitehall Follies.<ref>{{cite book | author = Roy Hudd |author2=Philip Hindin | title = Roy Hudd's cavalcade of variety acts: a who was who of light entertainment, 1945–60 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=iydaAAAAMAAJ | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 1997 | publisher = Robson Book Ltd | isbn = 978-1-86105-115-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author = Alfred Shaughnessy | title = Both ends of the candle | url = https://books.google.com/?id=rcXpAAAAMAAJ | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 1979 | isbn = 978-0-86072-018-8}}</ref> By the 1950s touring striptease acts were used to attract audiences to the dying music halls. Paul Raymond started his touring shows in 1951 and later leased the Doric Ballroom in Soho; opening his private members club, the [[Raymond Revuebar]] in 1958. This was the first of the private striptease members' clubs in Britain.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/paul-raymond-the-king-of-the-soho-sex-trade-dies-aged-82-790864.html | location = London | work = The Independent | title = Paul Raymond, the king of the Soho sex trade, dies aged 82 | first = Amol | last = Rajan | date = 2008-03-04}}</ref>
Changes in the law in the 1960s, brought about a boom of strip clubs in [[Soho]] with 'fully nude' dancing and audience participation.<ref>Goldstein, Murray (2005) ''Naked Jungle{{snd}}Soho Stripped Bare''. Silverback Press</ref> Pubs were also used as venues, most particularly in the [[East End]], with a concentration of such venues in the district of [[Shoreditch]]. This pub striptease seems mainly to have evolved from topless go-go dancing.<ref name="It Started With Theresa">{{cite book | title = In the Beginning There was Theresa | url = https://books.google.com/?id=jivMPoquDfAC | year = 2006 | publisher = Lulu.com | isbn = 978-1-4116-5178-4 | page = 5 | last1 = Martland | first1 = Bill}}</ref> Though often a target of local authority harassment, some of these pubs survive to the present day. An interesting custom in these pubs is that the strippers walk 'round and collect money from customers in a beer jug before each individual performance. This custom appears to have originated in the late 1970s when topless go-go dancers first started collecting money from the audience as the fee for going "fully nude".<ref name="It Started With Theresa"/> Private dances of a more raunchy nature are sometimes available in a separate area of the pub.<ref>{{cite book|title=Baby Oil and Ice: Striptease in East London|author1=Lara Clifton|author2=Sarah Ainslie|author3=Julie Cook|date=2002|publisher=The Do-Not Press|isbn=978-1899344857}}</ref>
=== American tradition === [[File:Condor Club.jpg|thumb|Historical marker at the original [[Condor Club]] in [[San Francisco|San Francisco, California]]. Today, the club is owned by [[Déjà Vu (company)|Deja Vu]]. |alt=refer to caption]]
In America, striptease started in [[traveling carnival]]s and [[American burlesque|burlesque]] theatres, and featured famous strippers such as [[Gypsy Rose Lee]] and [[Sally Rand]]. The [[vaudeville]] [[trapeze artist]] [[Charmion]] performed a "disrobing" act onstage as early as 1896, which was captured in the 1901 [[Thomas Edison|Edison]] film, ''Trapeze Disrobing Act''. Another milestone for modern American striptease was the possibly legendary show at [[Minsky's Burlesque]] in April 1925: [[The Night They Raided Minsky's]]. The Minsky brothers brought burlesque to New York's [[42nd Street (Manhattan)|42nd Street]]. However, the burlesque theatres there were prohibited from having striptease performances in a legal ruling of 1937, leading to the later decline of these "[[grindhouse]]s" (named after the bump 'n grind entertainment on offer) into venues for exploitation cinema.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newvictory.org/About/About_Building.aspx|website=The New Victory Cinema|title=Theater History|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref> The concept of "strippers" as we know it today with the pole dance has been popularized 8n the united states in 1972. British columbia followed the lead around 1978.
Widespread bans on striptease had a direct influence on the creation of the strip [[clip joint]] and the exotic dancer as known today.<ref name="Shteir 2004"/> Bans still exist; enforced now mostly at the local [[municipal]] level. American-style striptease began to appear outside North America in the post-World War II era and is now practiced widely around the world.<ref name="Shteir 2004"/>
The 1960s saw a revival of striptease in the form of topless [[go-go dancing]]. Topless dancing was banned in certain parts of the country, similar to the bans on striptease, but it eventually merged with the older tradition of burlesque dancing.<ref name="Shteir 2004"/> [[Carol Doda]] of the [[Condor Club|Condor Night Club]] in the [[North Beach, San Francisco, California|North Beach]] section of San Francisco is credited with being the first [[Toplessness|topless]] go-go dancer.<ref name="CondorClub">''Nudity, Noise Pay Off in Bay Area Night Clubs'', [[Los Angeles Times]], February 14, 1965, Page G5.</ref> The club opened in 1964 and Doda's première topless dance occurred on the evening of June 19 of that year.<ref name=hole>''California Solons May Bring End To Go-Go-Girl Shows in State'', Panama City News, September 15, 1969, Page 12A.</ref><ref name=hole/><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-22039191_ITM | title = Naked Profits | accessdate = 2007-07-30 | work = [[The New Yorker]] | date = 2004-07-12}}</ref> The large lit sign in front of the club featured a picture of her with red lights on her [[breasts]]. The club went "bottomless" on September 3, 1969; launching the trend of explicit "[[full nudity]]" in American striptease dancing.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.answers.com/topic/1964?cat=technology | title = World Chronology: 1964 | accessdate = 2007-07-30 | work = Answers.com}}</ref> It was Doda's brand of dancing which is credited with the move from striptease to stripping.<ref name="DiNardo Gilded 2007">{{cite book | author = Kelly DiNardo | title = Gilded Lili: Lili St. Cyr and the Striptease Mystique | url = https://books.google.com/?id=qQcbAQAAIAAJ | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2007-12-31 | publisher = Back Stage Books | isbn = 978-0-8230-8889-8}}</ref>
San Francisco is also the location of the notorious [[Mitchell Brothers O'Farrell Theatre]]. Originally an [[X-rated]] movie theater, this striptease club pioneered [[lap dancing]] in 1970, and was a major force in popularizing it in strip clubs on a nationwide and eventually worldwide basis.<ref name="sfweekly">[http://www.sfweekly.com/2004-09-08/news/lap-victory/ Lap Victory. How a DA's decision to drop [[prostitution]] charges against lap dancers will change the sexual culture of S.F.{{snd}}and, perhaps, the country.] ''[[SF Weekly]]'', 8 September 2004</ref> A further development in the American tradition took place with the emergence of upscale "gentlemen's clubs" in the early 1990s in large cities such as New York.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = A Brief History of The "Gentlemen's Club"|url = http://www.eroticmuseumvegas.com/a-brief-history-of-the-gentlemens-club/|website = www.eroticmuseumvegas.com|accessdate = 2015-08-25}}</ref> [[Scores New York]] was the first major gentlemen’s club, with "a gorgeous interior, high-end food and drinks, and of course stunningly beautiful women in sexy gowns. The main job of a stripper is to entertain and keep the clients on dreaming while being a semi "psychologist".The person who performs a striptease is commonly known as a "[[stripper]]" or exotic dancer. Restrictions on venues may be through venue licensing requirements and constraints and a wide variety of national and local laws. These laws vary considerably around the world, and even between different parts of the same country.
Striptease involves a slow, sensuous undressing. The stripper may prolong the undressing by making sure that the sensual build up has been properly done using techniques such as the wearing of actual [[clothes]] or putting clothes or hands in front of just undressed body parts such as the [[breast]]s or [[genitalia]] in a sensual and playful manner. Unlike in burlesque theater, the modern popular form of strip theater can minimize the interaction of customer and dancer, reducing the importance of ''tease'' in the performance in favor of speed to undress.<ref name="Roach Stripping 2007"/> Most clubs have a dancer rotation where each dancer in turn will perform for one or more songs in a fixed sequence which repeats during a shift.<ref name="WCP Archibalds 2009"/> Less formal clubs will have dancers take turns when a stage becomes empty or have a free flow of entertainers where the stage has any number of entertainers who wander off and on at will.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://news.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne%2BNews/Malaysia/Story/A1Story20090528-144373.html | title = Dancers who strip to lure more customers | publisher = News.asiaone.com | date = 2009-05-28 | accessdate = 2010-08-13}}</ref> Featured entertainers are not usually part of the rotation and they generally have set times when they will perform that are advertised throughout the shift.<ref name="Roach Stripping 2007"/> If a [[DJ]] is present, he or she will emcee the rotation and typically announce the current dancer(s) on stage and possibly whom to expect in future sets.

=== Customer service === {{Main|Customer service}}
Strip clubs are profit-oriented businesses like [[restaurant]]s and other [[retail]] establishments. Performers and staff are the primary customer service representatives in the club environment. Dancers are their primary vehicle to entice customers to spend time and money in the establishment.<ref name="Wosick-Correa 2008"/>
==== Interaction ==== [[File:Models in Break Area at Miami Eroticaxxx 2009.jpg|thumb|left|Performers [[Theater (structure)#On and off stage|backstage]] tending to their props away from the audience. |alt=refer to caption]] Dancers continually interact with the customers in the club. They walk around and solicit drinks and lap dances, usually scanning the club floor to find the most lucrative customer to greet. The dancer qualifies a customer by sizing up their [[Human physical appearance|appearance]] and personal characteristics. Once the dancer identifies a suitable customer, she approaches, and attempts to establish a social relationship. Interaction can also be initiated by customers.<ref name="Wosick-Correa 2008"/> Clubs generate revenue by cover charges, selling drinks, and other means. Dancers make most of their income from giving [[lap dance]]s or VIP dances, where regulations allow. Otherwise, customer tips, at the stage, are a dancer's primary form of income.<ref name="Wosick-Correa 2008"/> Dancers are entertaining the customers in exchange for money and employing all of the resources at their disposal to do so. They sell the fantasy of sex, but do not typically follow through with the act.<ref name="Bernard 2003"/>
Interviews with strippers have revealed that the [[customer]]s are generally viewed as "[[Gullibility|suckers]]" for giving the dancers money just for their physical attraction.<ref name="Bell, Sloan, and Stickling 1998"/> Dancers, in an attempt to acquire a tip or monetary reward, may be selling more than just attractiveness and fantasy. They portray feelings of intimacy and emotional connectedness for their customers and most of the time these portrayals are overstated or false.<ref name="Pasko 2002">{{cite journal | last1 = Pasko | first1 = Lisa | year = 2002 | title = Naked Power: The Practice of Stripping as a Confidence Game | journal = Sexualities | volume = 5 | issue = 1 | page = 66 | doi=10.1177/1363460702005001003}}</ref> The stage persona is different from who they are backstage, even if it does mirror aspects of their true personality.<ref name="Bernard 2003"/> Within the context of the strip club, dancers might sometimes give the impression that they are revealing private (or ''[[Theater (structure)#On and off stage|backstage]]'') information to customers in order to play a [[confidence game]] for increased profit.<ref name="Wosick-Correa 2008"/> Dancers use props such as make-up, clothing, costumes, and appealing fragrances to complete their character and maintain their "[[Persona|front]]" while in the club. Customers rarely, if ever, see the preparation of these props, since they are denied access to the backstage of a dancer's performance space by the layout of the club.<ref name="Wosick-Correa 2008"/> A customer often wants a dancer to "drop the act", which makes them feel special and desired.<ref name="Frank 2002"/><ref name="Ronai and Ellis 1989"/> This [[girlfriend experience]] can involve increased intimacy up to and including sex acts.<ref name="google1"/><ref>{{cite book | author = Valentine Selena | title = How to Date an Exotic Dancer: For Men Who Prefer Extraordinary Women | url = https://books.google.com/?id=v1v8KPXGFRAC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = July 2004 | publisher = Island Waves, LLC | isbn = 978-0-9753088-0-6}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author = Kerr Fuffle |author2=Roscoe Spanks | title = Paying for Sex: The Gentlemen's Guide to Web Porn, Strip Clubs, Prostitutes & Escorts Without Humiliation, Job Loss, Bankruptcy, Infection, Bloodshed Or | url = https://books.google.com/?id=tOMGJkP0xt8C | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = December 2003 | publisher = Trafford | isbn = 978-1-4120-1348-2}}</ref> Dancers are commonly aware of this customer [[Desire (emotion)|desire]] for increased confidence, and may allow the ''impression'' that a customer is seeing their true selves. In reality, it is often just part of the act with little to no emotional attachment for the dancer.<ref name="Frank 2002"/>
