== Facilities == [[File:Main Stage Montys in Victoria, BC CAN.jpg|right|thumb|Performer on the main stage of Monty's Showroom Pub at [[Victoria, British Columbia]], Canada. |alt=refer to caption]]
Most strip clubs are located in buildings that are converted bars, [[restaurant]]s, or warehouses, or had industrial uses. The original layout of the building will affect the physical layout of a club. The more money that has been invested in a facility, the more it resembles a dedicated club.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/12/christopher-sturman_n_4256792.html|title=Inside of a Strip Club|newspaper=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-22|date=2013-11-12}}</ref>{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} Regardless of the [[floorplan]], as [[interactive theatre|interactive theater]], there are features every strip club will have. They include: [[Strip club#Performers|performers (strippers)]], a [[Strip club#Floor and seating|floor area]] where the customers will congregate, and some form of [[Strip club#Main stage|staging]] for the striptease performance.<ref name="WCP Archibalds 2009">{{cite web | url = http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/blogs/citydesk/2009/02/19/strip-club-way-less-depressing-than-the-rest-of-dc/ | title = Strip Club: Way Less Depressing Than The Rest of D.C.! | accessdate = 2010-06-06 | work = Washington City Paper | date = 2009-02-19 | last1 = Hess | first1 = Amanda}}</ref>
Higher-end gentlemen's clubs have features that cost millions of dollars to install and maintain.<ref name="Sapphire Sale 2006">{{cite web | url = http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jan-24-Tue-2006/business/5504641.html | title = SAPPHIRE SOLD : Strip club bids bring $80 million | accessdate = 2010-06-05 | work = Las Vegas Review-Journal | date = 2006-01-24}}</ref>
=== General admission areas === The floor area is open for [[general admission]]. A customer is free to wander around the club, except for employee areas and premium lounges.<ref name="Bremer 2005">{{cite book | editor = Egan, R. Danielle |editor2=Frank, K. |editor3=Johnson, M. L. | title = Flesh for Fantasy: Producing and Consuming Exotic Dance | year = 2005 | publisher = Thunder's Mouth Press, Avalon Publishing Group | location = New York, U.S. | isbn = 978-1-56025-721-9 | chapter = The Grind | last1 = Bremer | first1 = Susan}}</ref><ref name="Wosick-Correa 2008"/> To access premium lounges (sometimes called VIP, champagne, other lounges), a customer would normally be charged a fee above the cover charge. In some cases, the employee and premium lounges are dual use. For example, a manager's office might also double as the VIP room.<ref>{{cite book | author = Jordan Belfort | title = The Wolf of Wall Street | url = https://books.google.com/?id=LT0eLPH74wkC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2007-08-13 | publisher = Bantam | isbn = 978-0-553-80546-8}}</ref>
All clubs are configured differently. A small club can have a single room, with an [[Stage (theatre)#Created and found spaces|improvised stage]] for the striptease show. Many clubs have more than the basic [[amenities]]. Larger clubs have clearer designations of areas. The different areas within a club could be separated by a physical step, [[wikt:built-in|built-in]] railing, platforms and levels, doorways, distinct rooms, and entirely separate floors, and they can also be formed by different carpeting, placement of seating, or physical [[wikt:implement#Noun|implements]] such as a rope or other physical marker.
==== Floor and seating ==== [[File:Strip Club Customers Seated at Tip Rail.jpg|left|thumb|upright|Customers seated by the tip rail at Club Live in [[Scheveningen]], [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]]. |alt=refer to caption]]
Most entertainment takes place in the main floor area, and this is where performers and staff can interact with patrons. Customers get comfortable in this area and from their observations, they decide which club services they will use. The main stage is visible from the main floor, and the main bar is accessible, if one is present. Patrons can usually select from open seating and some clubs will have staff to assist with seating. If premium seating is provided, club staff will usually manage access to those areas.<ref name="AskMen HowTo 2002">{{cite web | url = http://www.askmen.com/money/how_to_60/60_how_to.html | title = How To: Behave In Strip Clubs | accessdate = 2010-06-06 | date = 2002-10-23 | work = AskMen.com | last1 = Richer | first1 = Steve}}</ref> Depending on the day, time and staffing levels, accessibility of the general admission areas may vary. Larger clubs will rope off or otherwise close sections of the club to customers unless the size of the crowd warrants use of the space. Larger clubs could have multiple floor, bar, seating, and staging areas which are managed in a similar manner.
==== Main stage ==== {{Main|Main_stage#Strip_clubs|l1=Main stage}} A [[main stage]] is where a featured performer will dance as part of a rotation.<ref name="WCP Archibalds 2009"/> In most clubs the main stage is a dominant feature of the layout and the center of activity.<ref name="Frank 2002"/> A common type of strip club main stage is the [[thrust stage]], also known as a [[Runway (fashion)|runway]] stage,<ref name="Liepe-Levinson StripShow 2002"/> but the other major forms are also used regularly. [[Theatre in the round]] is also a popular form of strip club staging for the main stage. During each set of one or more songs, the current performer will dance on stage. A dancer collects tips from customers either while on stage or while mingling with the audience after her performance. A customary tip (where customers can do so at the stage) is a dollar [[paper currency|bill]] folded lengthwise and placed in the dancer's [[garter (stockings)|garter]] from the ''tip rail''.<ref name="Roach Stripping 2007">{{cite book | author = Catherine M. Roach | title = Stripping, Sex, and Popular Culture | url = https://books.google.com/?id=uqd25KYuLiwC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 2007 | publisher = Berg Publishers | isbn = 978-1-84520-129-6}}</ref><ref name="WCP Archibalds 2009"/> The area of the tip rail is equivalent to the [[Apron stage|apron]] in traditional theatre. It is referred to in slang as "ringside", "gynecology row", "pervert row", and other names.<ref name="Roach Stripping 2007"/><ref>{{cite book | last = Scott | first = David | title = Behind the G-String | year = 2003 | publisher = McFarland & Company | location = Jefferson | isbn = 978-0-7864-1849-7 | pages = 10, 147}}</ref>
Many stages have actual railing built on or around the stage to function as the tip railing, in addition to indicating where customers should position themselves relative to the [[performance]] zone. Customers take turns tipping the dancer.<ref name="WCP Archibalds 2009"/> They may also line up to tip popular performers. If physical railing is not present, the tip rail is the edge of stage or defined performance area. Other common tip methods are to insert the dollar into the stripper's [[Cleavage (breasts)|cleavage]] from the hand or mouth, to simply place it or toss it on stage, or to crumple bills into a ball shape and throw them in the entertainer's direction.<ref name="Maxi Mounds">{{cite book | author = Maxi Mounds | title = The Maxi Mounds Guide to the World of Exotic Dancing | url = https://books.google.com/?id=qb-Nsr7JrT4C | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2004-01-15 | publisher = Perpetual Summer Pub | isbn = 978-0-9734333-1-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title = Tailhook 91: Events at the 35th Annual Tailhook Symposium | url = https://books.google.com/?id=CzltjN1pX8cC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 1993-01-31 | publisher = DIANE Publishing | isbn = 978-0-7881-0117-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author = Jim Norton | title = Happy Endings: The Tales of a Meaty-Breasted Zilch | url = https://books.google.com/?id=-10GnYZ7yXkC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2007-07-10 | publisher = Simon and Schuster | isbn = 978-1-4169-5022-6}}</ref> Each club and dancer has different tolerance levels for customer interaction, including tipping. Some clubs have multiple stages on the premises. Tipping etiquette varies between countries and cultures.<ref>{{cite book | author = Ann Marie Sabath |author2=Brandon Toropov | title = International Business Etiquette: What You Need to Know to Conduct Business Abroad with Charm and Savvy. Asia & the Pacific Rim | url = https://books.google.com/?id=M9Z3EAqBbIoC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = December 2002 | publisher = Authors Choice Press | isbn = 978-0-595-24801-8}}</ref> In Eastern European and Asian clubs it is customary to agree on payment upfront for a certain amount of time or dances, for stage performances and any private sessions.<ref name="AsiaOne Pay 2009">{{cite web|url=http://www.relax.com.sg/relax/news/245454/Pay%252C_or_perform.html |title=Pay, or perform in sex show |last1=Tay |first1=Dawn |date=2009-09-04 |work=AsiaOne |publisher=Singapore Press Holdings Ltd |accessdate=2010-07-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100828200337/http://www.relax.com.sg/relax/news/245454/Pay%2C_or_perform.html |archivedate=2010-08-28 |df= }}</ref><ref name="AskMen Top10Clubs 2008"/>
==== Optional staging ==== Satellite staging includes one or more areas where a stripper can perform other than a main stage and private dances.<ref name="Liepe-Levinson StripShow 2002">{{cite book | author = Katherine Liepe-Levinson | title = Strip Show: Performances of Gender and Desire | url = https://books.google.com/?id=dV8_mGp_89gC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 2002 | publisher = Psychology Press | isbn = 978-0-415-17381-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author = T. Denean Sharpley-Whiting | title = Pimps Up, Ho's Down: Hip Hop's Hold on Young Black Women | url = https://books.google.com/?id=1Q7EvbA2wIoC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 2007 | publisher = New York University Press | isbn = 978-0-8147-4014-9}}</ref> Larger clubs can have elaborate staging layouts with multiple stage areas distributed around a club and multiple dancers rotating between them per song. Some strip clubs consider ad-hoc performances on satellite stages, paid for by a customer on a per song basis, a form of ''private dance''. Rules at the satellite stages on the main floor tend to be the same as the [[Strip club#Main stage|main stage]]. In some cases, the layout is significantly different allowing more or less access to the customer. If a satellite stage is located in a [[Strip club#Premium access zones|premium access zone]], access to the dancer could be considerably greater since the higher level of service can include a less restrictive policy than enforced on the [[Strip club#Floor and seating|main floor]]. [[Lap dance]], [[peep show]], and lingerie modeling clubs might only have satellite stages with [[pay to play]] entertainment options on their premises.
Novelty acts (such as shower shows, [[Fire dancing#Modern developments in fire performance|fire shows]], and [[Mud wrestling#Variations|oil wrestling]]) can be presented on dedicated stages, temporary staging on the floor, or on the main stage itself depending on the club.<ref name="Holsopple 1998">{{cite web|url=http://www.object.org.uk/files/Strip_club_study%20Holsopple.pdf |title=Stripclubs According to Strippers: Exposing Workplace Sexual Violence |accessdate=2010-06-21 |work=The Freedom and Justice Center for Prostitution Resources |year=1998 |last1=Holsopple |first1=Kelly |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320163143/http://www.object.org.uk/files/Strip_club_study%20Holsopple.pdf |archivedate=2012-03-20 |df= }}</ref><ref name="AP StripFire 2008">{{cite news | url = http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,348049,00.html | title = Louisiana Stripper Burned in Flame-Blowing Dance Routine | accessdate = 2010-06-21 | agency = Associated Press | date = 2008-04-08 | last1 = | first1 = | work = Fox News}}</ref><ref name="Chillico OilWrestleZoning 2010">{{cite web|url=http://www.chillicothegazette.com/article/20100607/NEWS01/6060301/Chillicothe-open-for-adult-business- |title=Chillicothe open for adult business? |accessdate=2010-06-21 |work=Chillicothe Gazette |date=2010-06-07 |last1=Genson |first1=Loren |last2=Ison |first2=Jona |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100610233913/http://www.chillicothegazette.com/article/20100607/NEWS01/6060301/Chillicothe-open-for-adult-business- |archivedate=June 10, 2010 }}</ref> The main stage, if used, must be prepared and possibly covered to prevent damage, as accidents and injuries have been reported during these types of striptease performances.<ref name="WorldNow StripFire 2008">{{cite web | url = http://www.ksla.com/global/story.asp?s=8122160 | title = Shreveport Fire Dept. Will Investigate Deja Vu Adult Club After Dancer Burned | accessdate = 2010-06-21 | work = WorldNow and KSLA | date = 2008-04-04 | last1 = Childers | first1 = Fred}}</ref> When dangerous materials such as fire are used as props a [[license|permit]] may be required to be compliant with [[local ordinance]]s.<ref name="WorldNow StripFire 2008"/> Novelty acts are typically performed by feature dancers or by select house dancers during a featured performance. Shower shows require special equipment, so they are more likely to have a dedicated stage in the club with house dancers performing in the show. Optional staging can be present on the main floor or in dedicated rooms throughout larger clubs.<ref name="AskMen HowTo 2002"/>
==== Bars and counters ==== {{Main|Bar (counter)}} [[File:SR Van Nuys Bar.jpg|right|thumb|The main bar of [[Spearmint Rhino]] [[Van Nuys]] in [[Los Angeles, California]], U.S. with built-in stage. Main stage in background.|alt=refer to caption]]
A full bar is the primary service mechanism for clubs that offer [[alcoholic beverage]]s. In many clubs the main bar is the second most dominant element on the floor after the main stage,<ref name="KFBB 2009"/> and in some cases the main (or satellite) stage is built into the bar. Clubs can derive large percentages of their income from drink purchases. For both Rick's Cabaret and VCGH, Inc., service revenues were the single largest revenue source, with sales of alcoholic beverages second. VCGH earned 18% more and RICK 27.5% more in service revenue than alcohol sales. The amounts are closer when food ''and'' merchandise sales are considered, with RICK reporting a smaller gap between the two revenue sources relative to VCGH.<ref name="VCGH 2009 10-K"/><ref name="RICK 2009 10-K"/> Upscale clubs that offer food can have [[wikt:free-standing|free-standing]] or [[wikt:built-in|built-in]] bars for [[buffet]] service. Otherwise, food orders might be taken at the main bar or by waitstaff.
Consumption of alcohol is often facilitated via direct sales in strip clubs where such sales are legal, appropriately [[zoning|zoned]], and [[Liquor license|licensed]].<ref name="books.google.com">{{cite book | author = Alan Markovitz |author2=Thomas Stevens | title = Topless Prophet: The True Story of America's Most Successful Gentleman's Club Entrepreneur | url = https://books.google.com/?id=bM6gcaL3uCAC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2009-10-01 | publisher = Greenleaf Book Group | isbn = 978-0-9840855-0-7}}</ref> Some clubs that are not licensed to serve alcohol will work around the restriction by implementing a [[BYOB|bring your own beverage (BYOB)]] policy and a [[juice bar]]. Juice bars have the appointments of full bars but only serve non-alcoholic beverages such as water, [[fruit juice]], and flavored [[carbonated beverage]]s. Such a bar could double as a service counter for the storage of BYOB material and offer ice and mixing services to create mixed drinks using the customer-purchased ingredients. Where [[waitstaff]] are present, they may serve as an extension of the bar service; providing and refreshing drinks while maintaining the cleanliness of the seating areas.
==== Other floor areas ==== Many clubs have a lobby area where the cover charge, if any, is collected by a doorman or doorwoman and security personnel can do a quick check of prospective customers as they enter the facility.<ref name="KDH 2010">{{cite web|url=http://www.kdhnews.com/news/story.aspx?s=41159 |title=Teen girl employed by Killeen strip club |accessdate=2010-06-06 |work=Killeen Daily Herald |date=2010-04-30 |last1=O'Brien |first1=Victor |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101123150036/http://kdhnews.com/news/story.aspx?s=41159 |archivedate=2010-11-23 |df= }}</ref> [[Game]]s are also a common feature of strip clubs. [[Arcade game|Arcade]] and [[gambling]] machines are popular features, as are [[pool tables]]. Some clubs also have dedicated areas of the main floor dedicated to performing ''private dance'' services.<ref name="StPeteTimes 2007">{{cite web | url = http://www.sptimes.com/2007/12/27/Hernando/Patron_dies_in_privat.shtml | title = Patron dies in private room of strip club | accessdate = 2010-06-05 | work = St. Petersburg Times | date = 2007-12-27}}</ref>
=== Premium access zones ===
Access to certain parts of a strip club can require payment of an additional fee,<ref name="AskMen HowTo 2002"/> or can be by invitation. These areas offer features that are not present in the general admission areas. This approach might allow a club to offer different types and standards of services in the various areas, or to comply with local laws. In this setting, [[very important person|VIP]]s such as high rollers or persons of a wider popular celebrity, may receive complimentary services according to their reputation with the club personnel.<ref name="ESPN GoldClub 2007"/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Apr-13-Thu-2006/news/6846312.html | title = News – Ex-strip club manager describes bribes | publisher = reviewjournal.com | date = 2006-04-13 | accessdate = 2010-08-13}}</ref>
''VIP seating'' adjacent to the main floor is often more comfortable. For example, arm chairs or couches may be provided, and may include booths with service tables. The area typically has a clear line of sight to the main stage. Reserve seating gives a customer a sense of importance and demonstrates prestige.<ref>{{cite book | author = Katherine Frank | title = G-Strings and Sympathy: Strip Club Regulars and Male Desire | url = https://books.google.com/?id=AJdAErefhWgC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = December 2002 | publisher = Duke University Press Books | isbn = 978-0-8223-2972-5}}</ref> In higher-end clubs, [[VIP]] seating might include balconies and other overlooks, which might also include smaller stages for a private dance if the customer wishes,<ref name="Frank 2002"/> at an additional fee. VIP seating can also act as lap dance booths, where a higher lap dance price would apply than in the general area.<ref name="AskMen HowTo 2002"/>
''VIP rooms'' are partitioned areas in a club that are typically enclosed by fixed walls and can have doors that close completely. For such rooms that do not offer solid doors, there is usually some type of blind system with [[Bead stringing|stringed beads]], [[curtain]]s, or other screening implements. Couch rooms, private dance rooms,<ref name="StPeteTimes 2007"/> and lounges are also forms of VIP zones.<ref name="AskMen HowTo 2002"/> VIP rooms have seating that is more plush than the general admission zones and the VIP seating adjacent to the main floor. Often, purchase of access to the room includes customer time with the dancer(s) of their choice. Some rooms are outfitted with props and appliances, such as showers, hot tubs, and various types of bedding.<ref name="AskMen HowTo 2002"/>
A ''champagne room'' (also called a ''champagne lounge'', or ''champagne court'') is a specialized VIP Room service offered by gentlemen's clubs where a customer can purchase time (usually in half-hour increments) with an exotic dancer in a private room on the premises. Depending on the quality of the club, these rooms, which are typically away from the hustle and bustle of the main club, are generally well decorated and usually appointed with a private bar. Clubs sell [[Champagne (wine)|champagne]] by the glass or by the bottle for both the dancer and the customer. Some clubs also offer food and/or [[cigar]] service. News media outlets have reported incidents of champagne room charges into the tens and hundreds of thousands of U.S. dollars for a single visit.<ref name="SmokingGun 2005">{{cite web | url = http://www.thesmokinggun.com/archive/1021051scores1.html/ | title = Exec Sued Over $241,000 Strip Club Tab | accessdate = 2010-06-05 | work = The Smoking Gun | date = 2005-10-21}}</ref>
=== Limited access zones === Portions of the club used only for the [[Business operations|operation]] and [[Janitor|maintenance]] typically have access restricted to staff and performers.<ref name="Wosick-Correa 2008">{{cite journal|last1=Wosick-Correa |first1=Kassia R. |last2=Joseph |first2=L. B. |year=2008 |title=Sexy Ladies Sexing Ladies: Women as Consumers in Strip Clubs |journal=Journal of Sex Research |volume=45 |issue=3 |pages=201–216 |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2372/is_3_45/ai_n29470391/ |pmid=18686149 |doi=10.1080/00224490801987432 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100604015220/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2372/is_3_45/ai_n29470391/ |archivedate=2010-06-04 |df= }}</ref> These include (but are not limited to) management offices, employee booths, performer [[dressing room]]s, and service areas, such as the kitchen and behind the bar. This business practice does not differ significantly from what is seen in other customer service businesses such as [[retail store]]s and [[restaurant]]s. More frequently seen are entry booths, where security staff monitor customers entering and leaving the club and collect the [[cover charge]], and the [[DJ]] booth, where the DJ operates.<ref>{{cite book | author = SPIN Media LLC | title = SPIN | url = https://books.google.com/?id=BhhSYcXeTVoC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = November 2004 | publisher = SPIN Media LLC}}</ref> The DJ booth contains sound, lighting, and other equipment which is used to "orchestrate the crowd" by adjusting the club environment, and is equivalent to a [[control room]] in a traditional [[theater]].<ref>{{cite book | author = Catherine M. Roach | title = Stripping, Sex, and Popular Culture | url = https://books.google.com/?id=uqd25KYuLiwC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2008-05-30 | publisher = Berg Publishers | isbn = 978-1-84520-129-6}}</ref>
Dancers use dressing rooms to prepare for performances, rest between performances, and stow any of their belongings not secured by other means.<ref name="Wosick-Correa 2008"/> It is customary for disputes between club [[personnel]] to be handled off the floor and out of sight of patrons. Dressing rooms are commonly used for performer-only mediation, though this could shift into other areas of discussion if management is involved. Clubs are experimenting with granting greater access to restricted areas via technology.<ref name="Carnes Compulsive 2007"/> The service includes a live view into part of the backstage dressing room and paid access enables the website user to interact live with dancers at the club. Security of club [[asset]]s and personnel are a primary driver for limiting access to these zones. If [[Closed-circuit television|surveillance equipment]] for the club and grounds is present on site, the monitoring locations for the [[Audio-visual|audio/video]] [[Video feed|feed]]s will be directed to management.<ref>{{cite book | author = George Ritzer | title = McDonaldization: The Reader | url = https://books.google.com/?id=4hjoJUXiwqgC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2009-11-17 | publisher = SAGE Publications, Incorporated | isbn = 978-1-4129-7582-7}}</ref> In less frequent cases such feeds could also be accessed from off-site.<ref>{{cite magazine | url = https://www.phillymag.com/articles/2006/10/13/philadelphia-magazine-naked-ambition/ | title = Naked Ambition | magazine = Philadelphia Magazine | date = 13 October 2006 | accessdate = 12 September 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.newstimes.com/news/article/Danbury-strip-club-owner-pleads-guilty-to-tax-258218.php | title = Danbury strip club owner pleads guilty to tax evasion | publisher = NewsTimes | date = 2009-11-19 | accessdate = 2010-08-13}}</ref>
== Performers and staff ==
=== Performers === {{Main|Stripper}} [[File:Exotic Dancer On Stage 002.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Stripper]] performing on stage at Cabaret Kalesa in [[Rio de Janeiro, Brazil]]. |alt=refer to caption]]
Performers are called ''strippers'', ''exotic dancers'', just ''dancers'', or ''entertainers''. Strippers are the primary draw for any club. Dancers effectively entertaining customers are the key to generating revenue by keeping customers on site and enticing them to be repeat visitors.<ref name="books.google.com"/> The image of strippers (as known today) evolved through the late [[Striptease#1960s-1970s|1960s and 1970s]] in the U.S. and international cultures that embraced [[Americanized]] striptease; introduced into popular culture by the genre-defining performances of [[Carol Doda]].<ref>{{cite book | author = Mick Sinclair | title = San Francisco: a cultural and literary history | url = https://books.google.com/?id=4395AAAAMAAJ | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 2004 | publisher = Interlink Pub Group Inc | isbn = 978-1-56656-489-2}}</ref> By the 1980s, the pole dancing and highly explicit imagery associated with today's performers was widely accepted and frequently portrayed in film, television, and theater. ''House dancers'' work for a particular club or [[franchising|franchise]].<ref name="WP House 2009">{{cite news | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/03/12/AR2010031202154.html | title = Exotic dancer uses labor law to sue D.C. club over wages | accessdate = 2010-06-06 | work = Washington StripOlympics 1996">{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/08/us/dancers-follow-the-olympic-flame-and-the-money-to-atlanta-s-stripclubs.html?pagewanted=1 | title = Dancers Follow the Olympic Flame, and the Money, to Atlanta's StripClubs | accessdate = 2010-07-03 | work = New York Times | date = 1996-07-08 | last1 = Applebome | first1 = Peter}}</ref><ref name="google1">{{cite book https://books.google.com/?id=HB9XE7QlsawC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2003-05-27 | publisher = Touchstone | isbn = 978-0-7432-4562-3}}</ref> [[Pornographic film actor|Porn stars]] will often ==== Work environments ==== In some localities strippers are required to obtain permits to work in adult entertainment.<ref name="ALC 24K 2009"/> During a bikini performance, both [[breasts]] and [[Genital#Genitals|genital]] areas typically remain covered by revealing attire, while dancers provide services and entertainment. Go-go dancers will retain their tops and bottoms for the duration of their performance. A female stripper whose [[torso|upper body]] is exposed, but whose genital areas remain obscured during a performance, is said to be [[Toplessness|topless]]. Strippers who uncover the genital areas along with other clothing during a performance are said to be dancing fully nude. The fully nude practice is banned in many jurisdictions,<ref name="StPete Bikini 2010"/> but many dancers work around these [[Regulation|constraint]]s by selective uncovering of the [[vulva]], [[anus]], or both, for short periods of time, followed by immediate replacement of the clothing.<ref>{{cite book | author = A. W. Stencell | title = Girl Show: Into the Canvas World of Bump and Grind | url = https://books.google.com/?id=dXIZbIKMUesC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 1999 | publisher = Ecw Press | isbn = 978-1-55022-371-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Erskine | first = Michael | url = http://www.commercialappeal.com/news/2007/dec/16/dolls-is-still-open-despite-lawsuits/ | title = Exotic dance club is still open despite lawsuits | publisher = The Commercial Appeal | accessdate = 2010-08-13}}</ref> Not all strippers are comfortable dancing topless or fully nude.<ref>{{cite book | author = Bernadette Barton | title = Stripped: Inside the Lives of Exotic Dancers | url = https://books.google.com/?id=Cg5CU_UP06UC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 2006 | publisher = NYU Press | isbn = 978-0-8147-9933-8}}</ref>
Strippers can sometimes be contracted for performances outside the strip club environment.<ref name="google1"/> Strippers with ready access to the Internet away from work have also adopted [[social media]] and [[social networks|networks]] as a less intrusive way of maintaining direct connections with customers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/pcworld/20100716/tc_pcworld/refreshedmyspacedesperatelyseeksusers |title=Refreshed MySpace Desperately Seeks Users |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date=2010-07-17 |accessdate=2010-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100720150932/http://news.yahoo.com/s/pcworld/20100716/tc_pcworld/refreshedmyspacedesperatelyseeksusers |archivedate=July 20, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Jenn Shreve |url=https://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2006/04/70675 |title=MySpace Faces a Perp Problem |publisher=Wired.com |date=2006-04-18 |accessdate=2010-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100809112612/http://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2006/04/70675 |archivedate=2010-08-09 |df= }}</ref> Others use the internet to generate revenue by performing via [[webcam]], recording premium content, or running their own subscriber-based web site.<ref>{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/?id=54varRsWk9MC&pg=PA12&dq=strippers+webcam#v=onepage&q=strippers%20webcam&f=false | title = The Trade in Human Beings: Oral and ... | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | isbn = 978-0-215-53021-9 | year = 2009| last1 = Committee | first1 = Great Britain: Parliament: House of Commons: Home Affairs }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author = Jacki Willson | title = The Happy Stripper: Pleasures and Politics of the New Burlesque | url = https://books.google.com/?id=BTiP4-1O0bUC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2008-01-08 | publisher = I. B. Tauris | isbn = 978-1-84511-318-6}}</ref> [[Online]] erotic content is pervasive and generally classified as [[pornography]].<ref>{{cite book | author = Pamela Paul | title = Pornified: How Pornography Is Damaging Our Lives, Our Relationships, and Our Families | url = https://books.google.com/?id=xhB-wrR4LuAC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2006-08-08 | publisher = St. Martin's Griffin | isbn = 978-0-8050-8132-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author = Ann C. Bishop | title = Pop-Porn: Pornography in American Culture | url = https://books.google.com/?id=xKbsYHyShI8C | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 2007 | publisher = Praeger Pub Text | isbn = 978-0-275-99920-9}}</ref> Much like activities inside the club, different dancers have different comfort levels for services they provide during private parties.<ref name="google1"/> Aside from advertising for striptease services outside the club, an unknown percentage of strippers also work in other aspects of the [[sex industry]]. This can include erotic and [[nude photography|nude modeling]], [[pornography]], [[Escort agency|escorting]], and in some cases [[prostitution]]. Outside the U.S., the use of strip clubs to facilitate sex-for-hire is much more common and stripping in those settings is viewed as [[advertising]] for [[sexually oriented business]] that will be performed in either private areas of the club or off-premises.<ref name="Shteir 2004"/><ref name="EuroSex Zurich 2007"/>
==== Social interaction ==== Research suggests that exotic dancing can pay well, but often at significant cost to the stripper.<ref name="Ronai and Ellis 1989">{{cite journal | last1 = Ronai | first1 = C. R. | last2 = Ellis | first2 = C. | year = 1989 | title = Turn-ons for money: Interactional strategies of the table dancer | journal = Journal of Contemporary Ethnography | volume = 118 | issue = 3 | pages = 271–298 | doi=10.1177/089124189018003002}}</ref> One reason for this is the negative stigma associated with exotic dancing. Not all dancers are affected equally. Some dancers manage this stigma by dividing "the social world" and only revealing part of their identity.<ref name="Thompson and Harred 1992">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1080/01639625.1992.9967914 | last1 = Thompson | first1 = W. E. | last2 = Harred | first2 = J. L. | year = 1989 | title = Topless dancers: Managing stigma in a deviant occupation | journal = Deviant Behavior | volume = 13 | pages = 291–311 | issue = 3}}</ref> By revealing only a part of themselves, strippers may avoid being characterized by the stigmatizing attributes associated with exotic dancing.<ref name="Bernard 2003"/> Outside the club, dancers are indistinguishable by [[Human physical appearance|appearance]] from the [[Demographic analysis#Population Composition|general population]] and no more likely to be the targets of acts like [[violent crime]] than are other women.<ref name="Kelvin 2007">{{cite book | last = Kelvin | first = T. A. | title = Headless Man in Topless Bar: Studies of 725 Cases of Strip Club Related Criminal Homicides | year = 2007 | publisher = Dog Ear Publishing | location = Indianapolis, Indiana, U.S. | isbn = 978-1-59858-324-3}}</ref> Inside the club, [[personal boundaries]] are frequently crossed between strippers, customers, and other club staff. Research indicates that at some point every dancer has felt [[Exploitation of labour|exploited]] by customers, management, or other dancers. The most common complaint from dancers is being portrayed as an object or instrument, rather than as a person.<ref name="Boles and Garbin 1974"/><ref name="McGaghy and Skipper 1969">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1525/sp.1969.17.2.03a00100 | last1 = McCaghy | first1 = C.H. | last2 = Skipper | first2 = J.K. | year = 1969 | title = Lesbian behavior as an adaptation to the occupation of stripping | journal = Social Problems | volume = 17 | pages = 262–270 | issue = 2}}</ref> While dancers feel this exploitation and are affected by it, they also admit that they exploit their customers.<ref name="Bell, Sloan, and Stickling 1998">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1177/088610999801300306 | last1 = Bell | first1 = H. | last2 = Sloan | first2 = L. | last3 = Stickling | first3 = C. | year = 1998 | title = Exploiter or Exploited: Topless Dancers Reflect on their Experiences | journal = Affilia: Journal of Women and Social World | volume = 13 | pages = 352–365 | issue = 3}}</ref>
=== Primary staff === Additional club staff almost always includes a club manager, as dancer-run clubs are rare. One or more [[managers]] are responsible for day-to-day operations on behalf of the club owner.<ref name="WSJ ClubMgr 2009">{{cite news | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB123447503728679243 | title = A Reporter Faces the Naked Truth | accessdate = 2010-06-06 | work = Wall Street Journal | date = 2009-02-13 | last1 = Helliker | first1 = Kevin}}</ref> Managerial responsibilities include money handling, inventory, and hiring and firing of employee staff and contractors. The manager role can be split between a general manager and one or more floor managers.<ref name="ALC 24K 2009">{{cite web | last = Matteucci | first = Megan | url = http://www.ajc.com/news/atlanta/police-strip-club-offered-170255.html | title = Police: Strip club offered drugs, sex | publisher = ajc.com | date = 2009-10-22 | accessdate = 2010-08-13}}</ref> If a [[Bartop|bar]] is present, one or more dedicated [[bartenders]] might be employed to assist customers by preparing their drinks or by storing drinks that customers bring into [[BYOB]] clubs.<ref name="CBS unsexy 2010"/> In some localities bartenders are required to have an individual permit to serve alcohol.<ref name="ALC 24K 2009"/> House moms monitor dancers on behalf of the management. A house mom can be particularly beneficial where staff is otherwise male, given her potential to relate to female dancers in a way that male members of staff may not be able to.<ref name="Westword Housemom 2003">{{cite web | url = http://www.westword.com/2003-07-10/news/bare-necessities/ | title = Bare Necessities<!--was subtitle in article? : Sometimes a girl—even an almost-naked girl—just needs a mom --> | accessdate = 2010-06-06 | work = Denver Westword | date = 2003-07-10 | last1 = Chotzinoff | first1 = Robin}}</ref> Not every club will have a house mom.
[[File:Strip Club Bouncer San Francisco.jpg|left|thumb|upright|A [[bouncer (doorman)|bouncer]] in front of Crazy Horse Gentlemen's Club in San Francisco, California, U.S. |alt=refer to caption]]
[[Bouncer (doorman)|Bouncers]] are security personnel. They are typically relatively large and physically strong males, who enforce club policy and maintain order in and around the premises.<ref name="MRJ bouncers 2009">{{cite web | url = http://www.myrecordjournal.com/latestnews/article_aff367a6-f7bd-5a24-8a1f-77b9a017f012.html | title = Bouncers react to killings | accessdate = 2010-04-29 | work = Record-Journal | date = 2009-05-16 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140305071218/http://www.myrecordjournal.com/latestnews/article_aff367a6-f7bd-5a24-8a1f-77b9a017f012.html | archivedate = 2014-03-05 | df = }}</ref> In some cases, on-duty law enforcement may be on site if a club is viewed by authorities as a location with a high enough crime risk.<ref name="CHI police 2009">{{cite news | url = http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/chi-071205cops-day2-htmlstory,0,1689283.htmlstory | title = When off-duty police fire their weapons | accessdate = 2010-04-29 | work = Chicago Tribune | date = 2009-12-06}}</ref> More commonly, privately hired security (including off-duty police) are contracted to guard the premises.<ref name="WASHPO irvings 2009">{{cite news | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/01/24/AR2008012403213.html | title = Man, 25, Killed Outside Strip Club in Capitol Heights | accessdate = 2010-04-29 | work = Washington Post | date = 2008-01-25 | first = Hamil R. | last = Harris}}</ref> Bouncers can also double as doormen or [[Disc jockeys]] (DJs); serving as hosts and maintaining the flow of entertainment and even cuing music for the dance sets.<ref name="LVRJ DJ 2006">{{cite web | url = http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Mar-27-Mon-2006/living/6470868.html | title = STRIP CLUB DJ: Land of a Thousand Dances | accessdate = 2010-06-06 | work = Las Vegas Review-Journal | date = 2006-03-27 | last1 = Levitan | first1 = Corey}}</ref> Where a DJ is not present, music may be provided via either a [[jukebox]] or sometimes live musicians.
=== Ancillary staff === Strip clubs have a variety of configurations and staffing needs. Some clubs employ a host to [[emcee]] the show, in addition to a DJ. Hosts are more common in busier clubs or shifts, and during special, such as amateur night and featured acts. If the club charges a fee for entry, specialized personnel may work the door to collect the cover. A common practice is to employ young women, which are known in the industry as door girls, for this function.<ref name="KDH 2010"/> In certain areas, [[Doorman (profession)|doormen]] working outside the strip club will act as "[[hype man|hype men]]" enticing people to enter and sample the show and services.<ref name="LVRJ Norm 2008">{{cite web | url = http://www.lvrj.com/news/15834017.html | title = Feds take a look at LV cash flow | accessdate = 2010-06-06 | work = Las Vegas Review-Journal | date = 2008-02-01 | last1 = Clarke | first1 = Norm}}</ref> [[The Block (Baltimore)|The Block]] in [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]] has aggressive doormen stationed at nearly every entrance, only feet apart in a highly concentrated area of clubs.<ref name="FLStar 1994">{{cite web | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1298&dat=19940618&id=OucyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mwcGAAAAIBAJ&pg=6405,3729418 | title = This is God's House | accessdate = 2010-06-06 | work = The Free Lance-Star | date = 1994-06-18 | last1 = Schneider | first1 = Michael}}</ref> [[Broadway (San Francisco)|Broadway]] in San Francisco, [[California]] has fewer clubs clustered together, but practices similar activities with their doormen.<ref name="Kelvin 2007"/><ref>{{cite book | author = John T. Lescroart | title = The First Law | url = https://books.google.com/?id=2AHe_Q1JbQ4C | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 1940-01-14 | publisher = Signet | isbn = 978-0-451-21022-7}}</ref>
[[Waitstaff]] are also employed to assist with providing drinks, and in some cases meals, to customers on the main floor and others areas of the club.<ref name="Waitress sues club 2009">{{cite web | url = http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/front/6421397.html | title = EEOC says age bias behind firing of strip-club waitress | accessdate = 2010-06-05 | work = Houston Chronicle | date = 2010-05-13 | last1 = Sixel | first1 = L. M.}}</ref> Shooter girls are specialized waitstaff that carry pre-prepared drinks in shot glasses, that customers can conveniently purchase.<ref name="AZ ShotGirl 2009">{{cite web | url = http://www.azcentral.com/ent/pop/articles/0112shotgirls0112-CR.html | title = Shot girls gone wild: heating up the fight for your drink dollar | accessdate = 2010-06-06 | work = azcentral.com | date = 2006-01-10 | last1 = Charnas | first1 = Dan}}</ref> Depending on the local ordinances, these shots may involve some erotic part of the body of the shooter girl, typically her [[Cleavage (breasts)|cleavage]], in the delivery.<ref name="Maxi Mounds"/><ref>{{cite book | last=Oppliger | first=Patrice | author-link = Patrice Oppliger | title = Girls gone skank: the sexualization of girls in American culture | year = 2008 | publisher = McFarland and Company Inc., Publishers | location = Jefferson, North Carolina | isbn = 9780786435227 }}</ref> If a club has a policy of setting a drink minimum per visit or per hour, the floor staff also assists in enforcing those rules. Dancers may also be required to generate a certain number of drink purchases per shift and as part of their rounds, the waitstaff may ask customers if they would like to buy a drink for the dancer seated with them.<ref name="Liepe-Levinson StripShow 2002"/><ref>{{cite book | author = New York Media, LLC | title = New York Magazine | url = https://books.google.com/?id=7eQCAAAAMBAJ | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 1995-09-25 | publisher = New York Media, LLC}}</ref> If a [[kitchen]] is present and if premium fare is offered, the club may also employ a [[chef]] to prepare and cook food items.
Parking lot attendants can include people who simply coordinate where to park and how much to pay or they may also include formal [[parking valet|valet]]s, who will park a vehicle and keep track of the driver's keys while he or she is in the club.<ref name="WCP Valet 2010">{{cite web | url = http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/blogs/citydesk/2010/03/23/our-morning-roundup-ward-5-gets-a-strip-club/ | title = Our Morning Roundup: Ward 5 Gets A Strip Club | accessdate = 2010-06-06 | date = 2010-03-23 | work = Washington City Paper | last1 = Cherkis | first1 = Jason}}</ref> Some clubs require paid or valet parking to be used if keeping cars on the premises, to generate revenue and help regulate patron behavior. [[Bathroom attendant]]s monitor the restrooms on behalf of management; primarily watching for policy violations and potential liability concerns.<ref name="BBC 2008">{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/7335315.stm | title = Who'd be a toilet attendant? | accessdate = 2008-08-05 | work = BBC News Magazine | date = 2008-04-09 | last1 = Cook | first1 = Daniel}}</ref> In strip clubs, policy enforcement can range from watching for drug use, sex, fighting, and other activities the club would prefer to see done off the premises. The attendant will also attempt to keep the restroom area clean, assist with the washing of hands, and if available, provide by request an assortment of cologne, mints, and other disposable items.<ref name="BBC 2008"/>
== Business and operations == As a global industry, strip clubs are booming.<ref name="Jeffreys 2009"/> As of 2009, there were between 3,500 and 4,000 strip clubs in the United States alone.<ref name="VCGH 2009 10-K">{{cite web | url = https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1172852/000095012310024255/d71477e10vk.htm | title = VCG Holding Group, Inc. 2009 10-K | accessdate = 2010-05-07 | work = VCGH | date = 2010-03-12}}</ref> More money is spent in the U.S. in strip clubs than is spent on [[theater]], [[opera]], [[ballet]], [[jazz]] and [[classical music]] concerts combined.<ref name="Schlosser 1997">{{cite web | url = http://www.milligan.edu/communications/Library/Articles1/USNewsPorn.htm | title = The Business of Pornography | accessdate = 2010-07-03 | author = Schlosser, Eric | date = 1997-02-10 | publisher = [[U.S. News & World Report]] | authorlink = Eric Schlosser}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,4153718,00.html | title = A rough trade | accessdate = 2009-04-10 | author = [[Martin Amis]] | date = 2001-03-17 | publisher = [[guardian.co.uk]] | location = London}}</ref> Some clubs have hundreds of entertainers appear on stage within a single year.<ref name="HouChron 2007">''[http://chron.com/disp/story.mpl/front/4717463.html City plans crackdown on some sex businesses]'' – ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'', 2007</ref>
=== Global industry === [[File:Strip Club Signage.jpg|right|thumb|alt=Neon Dancers|Neon "Girls Girls Girls" sign on the front of club Burlesque with nude dancers in outline ([[North Hollywood]], Los Angeles, California, U.S.) |alt=refer to caption]]

In 2002, the size of the U.S. industry was estimated to be US$3.1 billion, spanning 2,500 clubs and generating 19% of the total gross in [[legal]] [[adult entertainment]] revenue.<ref name="Lewis Purdue 2002">{{cite book | last = Purdue | first = Lewis | title = EroticaBiz: How Sex Shaped the Internet | url = https://books.google.com/?id=9n4NVyCNkZQC | year = 2002 | publisher = IUniverse | isbn = 978-0-595-25612-9 | pages = 23–24}}</ref> The U.S. market for strip clubs was estimated to be as large as US$15 billion in 2005.<ref name="Hanna PolicyPlan 2005">{{cite journal|doi=10.1177/0885412205277071 |last1=Hanna |first1=Judith L. |year=2005 |title=Adult Entertainment Exotic Dance: A Guide for Planners and Policy Makers |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823180157/http://www.woodhullfoundation.org/content/otherpublications/JPL11-05-116-134.pdf |archivedate=2007-08-23 |df= }}</ref> That same year the U.S. state of [[California]] alone accounted for US$1 billion in revenue,<ref name="FreeSpeech WhitePaper 2005">{{cite web | url = http://www.docstoc.com/docs/6117965/Free-Speech-Coalition-WHITE-PAPER-A-Report-on-the | title = A Report on the Adult Entertainment Industry | accessdate = 2010-07-03 | work = Free Speech Coalition | estimated 300,000 women worked as strippers in the U.S., across 3,000 clubs.<ref name="Jeffreys 2009"/> An industry insider in 2008 estimated the U.S. strip club market at close to US$2 billion,<ref name="Naked Profits RICK 2008">{{cite web|url=http://www.equitiesmagazine.com/article_ricks.php |title=Naked Profits: Rick's Cabaret |accessdate=2010-05-07 |work=Equities Magazine |date=March 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100103004209/http://equitiesmagazine.com/article_ricks.php |archivedate=2010-01-03 |df= }}</ref> basing that estimate on [[Adult Video News|Adult
