Since then, the number of clubs in the U.S. has grown to approximately 4,000 by 2010.<ref name="VCGH 2009 10-K"/>
In Britain the number of strip clubs rose over 1,000 percent between 1997 and 2010. In 2008 alone, a strip club opened there almost every week.<ref name="Metro NewLaws 2010">{{cite web | url = http://www.metro.co.uk/lifestyle/816320-strip-clubs-may-die-out-if-new-lap-dancing-laws-come-into-place | title = Strip clubs 'may die out' if new lap-dancing laws come into place | accessdate = 2010-06-11 | work = Metro.co.uk | date = 2010-03-11 | last1 = Scott | first1 = Lisa}}</ref> One factor in the proliferation of British strip clubs is Britain's [[Licensing Act 2003|2003 Licensing Act]], which introduced the one-size-fits-all premises licence, which meant that strip clubs in Britain no longer had to receive special permission for nudity.<ref name="Guardian DancerObject 2010">{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/mar/19/gender.uk/ | title = The reality of lap-dancing, by a former dancer | accessdate = 2010-06-11 | work = The Guardian | date = 2008-03-19 | last1 = Bell | first1 = Rachel | location = London}}</ref> In 2005, revenues for the UK strip club industry, one of the fastest growing sectors of its leisure industry, were estimated to be UK£300 million.<ref name="Jeffreys 2009"/> Revenues for 2006 in [[Scotland]] alone accounted for UK£20 million of the UK total.<ref name="Jeffreys 2009"/>
==== Markets and ownership ==== American-style striptease, closely associated with contemporary clubs around the world, began to appear outside North America in the post-World War II era, emerging in Asian performances during the late 1940s and in European theaters by 1950.<ref name="Shteir 2004"/> A contemporary example, the American [[Spearmint Rhino]] chain, has clubs located in the UK, Russia, and Australia, as well as the United States. In 2003, the company's London location reportedly made UK£3 per minute.<ref name="Jeffreys 2009"/> Strip clubs offering American striptease and other adult entertainment services have been established on six of seven continents (all except Antarctica),<ref name="Jeffreys 2009"/><ref>{{cite book | author = Birgit Beumers | title = Pop Culture Russia!: Media, Arts, And Lifestyle | url = https://books.google.com/?id=Hix8AyteLN8C | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 2005 | publisher = Abc-clio | isbn = 978-1-85109-459-2}}</ref> and the demand for these types of business is soaring in economically developing nations.<ref>{{cite book | author = Larry J. Siegel | title = Introduction to Criminal Justice | url = https://books.google.com/?id=p5-Dx4h6obEC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2009-01-05 | publisher = Wadsworth Publishing Company | isbn = 978-0-495-59977-7}}</ref> Most adult entertainment companies, which include strip clubs, are in [[privately held]] ownership.<ref>{{cite book | author = Gerrie Lim | title = In Lu$t We Trust: Adventures in Adult Cinema | url = https://books.google.com/?id=UX1Oc-tqlLkC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2006-09-15 | publisher = Monsoon Books Pte Limited | isbn = 978-981-05-5302-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author = James A. Inciardi |author2=Hilary L. Surratt |author3=Paulo R. Telles | title = Sex, Drugs, And Hiv/aids in Brazil | url = https://books.google.com/?id=dSVgAAAAMAAJ | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 2000 | publisher = Westview Press | isbn = 978-0-8133-3424-0}}</ref>
Two strip club companies are publicly traded in U.S. financial markets and listed on [[NASDAQ]]: VCG Holding Corp. (VCGH) and Rick's Cabaret International, Inc. (RICK). In February 2010, the two clubs agreed in principle to merge, with [[Rick's Cabaret]] acquiring VCG Holding. The estimated purchase price, according to the statement of intent, was for the [[Mergers and acquisitions|acquisition]] using RICK stock to be at a value of US$2.20 to US$3.80 per share.<ref name="RICK buys VCGH 2010">{{cite web | url = http://blogs.barrons.com/stockstowatchtoday/2010/02/16/strip-club-wedding-rick-buys-vcgh/ | title = Strip Club Wedding: RICK Buys VCGH | accessdate = 2010-05-07 | work = Barron's.com | date = 2006-02-16}}</ref> The US$45 million deal fell through after the statement of intent expired on March 31, 2010, with Rick's Cabaret unable to enter into a definitive merger agreement to acquire all of VCG's outstanding stock.<ref name="RICK deal off with VCGH 2010">{{cite news | url = http://denver.bizjournals.com/denver/stories/2010/03/29/daily42.html/ | title = Rick's Cabaret deal to buy strip-club company VCG Holdings is off | accessdate = 2010-06-05 | work = Denver Business Journal | date = 2010-04-01}}</ref> A third publicly traded company, Scores Holding Company, Inc. (SCRH), licenses its brand to strip club operators but does not own or operate any club properties itself.<ref name="SCRH 2009 10-K">{{cite web | url = https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/831489/000114420410020479/v181059_10k.htm | title = Scores Holding Company, Inc. 2009 10-K | accessdate = 2010-05-07 | work = SCRH | date = 2010-04-15}}</ref> Publicly reported earning statements for U.S. companies operating strip clubs have not provided guidance on how they define their market segment, non-public competitors, or overall industry revenue.<ref name="VCGH 2009 10-K"/><ref name="RICK 2009 10-K"/><ref name="SCRH 2009 10-K"/>
The largest operator of strip clubs internationally is [[Déjà Vu (company)|Déjà Vu]], which has over 130 locations worldwide.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}}
==== Financial trends ==== [[File:The Block.JPG|thumb|right|upright|Street view of strip clubs on [[The Block (Baltimore)|The Block]] in [[Baltimore, Maryland]], U.S. |alt=refer to caption]]
The rapid expansion of the strip club industry observed in the 2000s occurred primarily in the Western world.<ref name="Jeffreys 2009"/> Far from its heyday in the 1980s and 1990s, Japan's sex industry has been in a protracted slump in the first decade of the 21st century, as the overall economy experienced a recession.<ref name="TapeiTimes 2002"/> Its hostess and strip bars (those which had not closed outright) felt the impact of dwindling [[expense account|corporate spending accounts]], leading to increased competition (and reduced boundaries) for remaining patrons.<ref name="TapeiTimes 2002">{{cite web | url = http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/bizfocus/archives/2002/02/25/125390 | title = Japan's recession hits sex clubs | accessdate = 2010-07-03 | work = Agence France-Presse (AFP) | date = 2002-02-25 | last1 = AFP, Tokyo | first1 =}}</ref> Profitability of strip clubs, as with other service-oriented businesses, is largely driven by location and customer spending habits.<ref name="WSJ Slump 2009">{{cite news | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB124467942901904435 | title = Some Gentlemen's Clubs Strip Down Upscale Offerings as Business Slumps | accessdate = 2010-06-06 | work = Wall Street Journal | date = 2009-06-11 | last1 = Hudson | first1 = Kirk}}</ref> Clubs closely proximate to [[Wall Street]] in [[NYC|New York]], [[New York (state)|New York]] are notorious for hosting meetings with financial industry power brokers, among other business heavyweights, which are frequently [[expense account|expensed]] on company bankrolls.<ref name="Execs Strip Meet 2006">{{cite news | url = https://www.usatoday.com/money/companies/management/2006-03-22-strip-clubs-usat_x.htm | title = Should business execs meet at strip clubs? | accessdate = 2010-05-07 | work = USA Today | date = 2006-03-22 | first1 = Jayne | last1 = O'Donnell}}</ref> Since clubs located in urban areas or business centers have caused concerns over traffic and social issues, some club owners with common interests in close proximity have shared representation without consolidating their businesses.<ref name="BaltoCityPaper AroundTheBlock 2000">{{cite web|url=http://www.citypaper.com/news/story.asp?id=3625 |title=Around the Block: The Colorful Past, Controversial Present, and Uncertain Future of Baltimore's Red-Light District |accessdate=2010-07-18 |work=Baltimore City Paper |date=2000-02-02 |last1=Smith |first1=Van |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091212185610/http://www.citypaper.com/news/story.asp?id=3625 |archivedate=2009-12-12 |df= }}</ref> After numerous incidents during the 1990s with local and state government, Downtown Entertainment Inc. was formed in 2000 to represent the interests of business owners on The Block in [[Baltimore, Maryland]].<ref name="BaltoCityPaper AroundTheBlock 2000"/>
Strip clubs which practice [[Generally Accepted Accounting Principles| Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP)]] typically report negative [[working capital]], where [[current liabilities]] exceed [[current assets]]. Clubs receive immediate [[cash]] [[payment]] for [[sales]], while [[inventories]], [[accrued expense]]s, and other current liabilities normally carry longer [[Payment schedule|payment terms]]. The practice is believed to increase [[Net profit|net cash]] provided by [[Business operations|operating activities]].<ref name="VCGH 2009 10-K"/> Service revenues include entertainer payments to perform at clubs, customer admission fees, customer payments for tabs and tip charges, dance dollar payments, and suite rental fees.<ref name="VCGH 2009 10-K"/> The economic downturn, which accelerated in 2008, impacted clubs at all levels, and even higher-end gentlemen's clubs in some parts of the U.S. and elsewhere adjusted their [[business practice]]s to compensate for reduced revenues.<ref name="WSJ Slump 2009"/>
=== Business practices === Strip clubs can operate at all hours, depending on regulations and revenue. It is a common business practice to have a reduced door charge or no entry fee at all during daytime. Clubs that are open for more than just the nighttime hours may incorporate a staggered or [[shift work]] [[Schedule (workplace)|schedule]] for their entertainers and staff. External factors, such as location and public perception, have some impact on business, but the essential draw of the strip club is the live entertainment.<ref>{{cite book | author = Jill Nagle | title = Whores and Other Feminists | url = https://books.google.com/?id=WBDRYi9B3TwC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 1997 | publisher = Psychology Press | isbn = 978-0-415-91822-0}}</ref> Because of negative perceptions of the adult entertainment industry, many clubs engage in public displays of charity to generate goodwill. VCGH clubs, in order to be good corporate citizens, actively sponsor and participate in local charitable events and contribute to local charities.<ref name="VCGH 2009 10-K"/> Some clubs also register their business entities using benign names, so that they appear to be businesses unrelated to the sex industry on receipts and financial statements, and as a means of discretion.<ref name="Jeffreys 2009"/> Cameras (including camera phones) and other recording devices are often banned from strip clubs to "protect the identity of the women working there and to spare the blushes of men caught on film attending the club".<ref name="BBC CamBan 2003">{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/2916353.stm | title = Furtive phone photography spurs ban | accessdate = 2010-07-05 | work = BBC News | date = 2003-04-04}}</ref>
Among clubs, there is a variety of different ways to deliver entertainment, and fee structures commonly differ between clubs. A [[cover charge]] (entry fee also known as a ''door charge'') is customary at many clubs,<ref name="BNC bucks 1996">{{cite web | url = http://www.allbusiness.com/north-america/united-states-north-carolina/591865-1.html | title = Bucks naked: here's the bottom line on running a topless club | accessdate = 2010-05-07 | work = Business North Carolina | date = 1996-04-01}}</ref> the amount of which can vary by factors such as day of visit, [[time of day]], [[gender]], and other factors. To make the charge more acceptable to customers, some clubs include bonus items in the admission price, such as [[drink ticket]]s that can be redeemed once inside. Some clubs also have drink fees tied to interaction with performers.<ref name="AskMen HowTo 2002"/> The bigger the drink, the longer the time permitted with the dancer. This practice is more common in European strip clubs and African or Asian [[hostess club]]s.<ref>{{cite book | author = Wanjohi Kibicho | title = Sex Tourism in Africa: Kenya's Booming Industry | url = https://books.google.com/?id=044mTY1ExgEC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2009-11-06 | publisher = Ashgate Publishing, Ltd. | isbn = 978-0-7546-7460-3}}</ref> Champagne Room pricing (where time with an exotic dancer in a private room on the premises can be purchased) is a variation on that same theme.
==== Operations ==== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Tipping bellydancer.jpg|right|thumb|A customer [[Tip (gratuity)|tipping]] a dancer via the waistband of her outfit after a dance. |alt=A customer places US$ dollar tips into a dancer's outfit after her dance]] -->
In the U.S., striptease dancers are generally classified as [[independent contractor]]s. A few smaller strip clubs may pay a weekly [[wage]] but, in most cases, a dancer's income is derived entirely from tips and other fees, which they collect from customers. In most clubs, dancers must pay a "stage fee" or "house fee" to work a given shift.<ref name="BNC bucks 1996"/> In these cases, strippers receive payment in the form of [[Tip (gratuity)|tips]] and payment for specific services offered by the club (such as [[lap dances]]). Many clubs also take a percentage of fees charged for each private dance. It is also customary{{snd}}and often required in the United States{{snd}}for dancers to pay a "tip out", usually at the end of their shift, to the supporting staff, such as [[DJ]]s, house moms, [[make-up artist]]s, [[waiting staff|server]]s, [[bartender]]s, and [[bouncer (doorman)|bouncer]]s. This can be a set fee or a percentage of money earned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stripper-faq.org/money.htm|title=stripper-faq: making money|author=Kiko Wu|date=2000|work=stripper-faq.org|accessdate=27 November 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20170125075706/http://www.stripper-faq.org/money.htm |archive-date=25 January 2017}}</ref> For the customer, the [[fee]] structure of a club is determined by management [[policy]].
In many smaller clubs, multiple staff roles are filled by the same person, such as a bartender and manager. In extreme cases, one person fills all the support functions within a club.<ref>{{cite book | author = T A Kevlin | title = Headless Man in Topless Bar: Studies of 725 Cases of Strip Club Related Criminal Homicides | url = https://books.google.com/?id=UOlvBffVlt8C | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = April 2007 | publisher = Dog Ear Pub Llc | isbn = 978-1-59858-324-3}}</ref> Some clubs hire attractive women onto the staff, as bartenders and shot girls, to complement the strippers. They can also double as stage and lap dance entertainers, depending on the club. The positions of paid staff are discretionary. Turnover can be frequent, but standard employment laws do apply and have been enforced through the courts and other regulatory means.<ref name="Frank 2002"/><ref name="WP House 2009"/> A highly publicized 2010 case in the United States concerned a pregnant bartender in New York. She alleged that Cafe Royale in [[Farmingdale, New York]] [[discriminate]]d against her because pregnancy is "unsexy".<ref name="CBS unsexy 2010">{{cite news | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-20000146-504083.html | title = Strip Club Bartender Jennifer Paviglianiti Says She was Demoted Because of "Unsexy" Pregnancy | accessdate = 2010-04-29 | work = CBS News | date = 2010-03-08 | first = Kealan | last = Oliver}}</ref> Hiring of staff and performers in the United States is almost always voluntary on the part of the club and worker. Some strip clubs have hosted job fairs to address staffing needs.<ref name="CNN JobFair 2009">{{cite news | url = http://www.cnn.com/2009/US/03/19/strip.club.job.fair/ | title = Strip club fair offers solution to skimpy job market | accessdate = 2010-06-19 | work = CNN.com | date = 2009-03-19 | last1 = Trevino | first1 = Monica}}</ref> While not a common practice in the United States, globally, women are regularly compelled into working as strippers with the knowledge of club management.<ref name="Ebbe 2008"/>
==== Marketing ==== The ability to attract first-time patrons is critical to a nightclub's success. As such, promotions, advertising, and special offers are the typical means to market a nightclub. Marketing strategies for strip clubs include attracting new customers, increasing the frequency of visits by existing customers, and establishing a higher level of name recognition. Target markets can include the business-convention traveler, local professionals, and business people.<ref name="VCGH 2009 10-K"/> College students are also a secondary target market.<ref name="VCGH 2009 10-K"/> Advertising is essential for strip clubs, but local regulations and public reaction can make it challenging. For this reason, clubs around the world advertise on the World Wide Web. Advertising can include discount passes, virtual club tours, and dancer schedules.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.strip-magazine.com/mmagazine/new_welcome.php?subaction=showfull&id=1133443219&archive=&start_from=&ucat=7&category=7 |title=Strip scene gossip for December|publisher=Strip-magazine.com |accessdate=2010-08-13 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20061118053547/http://www.strip-magazine.com/mmagazine/new_welcome.php?subaction=showfull&id=1133443219&archive=&start_from=&ucat=7&category=7 |archive-date= 18 November 2006}}</ref>
U.S. company VCGH, Inc. uses a variety of highly targeted methods to reach its customers, including local radio, billboard trucks, Internet, newspaper and magazine advertisements, and professional sporting events. Its advertising and marketing expenses decreased by approximately 3.9% to US$2,805,260 from US$2,921,327 over the year ended December 31, 2008. Advertising and marketing expenses were approximately 5.1% of their total revenues in 2009 and 2008. The decrease was attributed to a shift in advertising, including using billboard trucks for mobile advertising versus leasing fixed billboard signs.<ref name="VCGH 2009 10-K"/> By contrast, in public filings with the U.S. [[Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC), Rick's Cabaret International reported an increase in its advertising budget from US$2,231,005 in 2008 to US$8,091,745 in 2009, growing from 3.9% to 10.8% of total annual revenue.<ref name="RICK 2009 10-K">{{cite web | url = https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/935419/000114036109029530/form10k.htm | title = Rick's Cabaret International, Inc. 2009 10-K | accessdate = 2010-06-16 | work = VCGH | date = 2009-12-17}}</ref>
In the U.S. city of [[Seattle, Washington]], the city's [[Major League Baseball]] franchise, the [[Seattle Mariners]], initially sued in [[King County Superior Court]] to try to prevent Dreamgirls cabaret from opening. The team's attorneys argued that the strip club's existence would adversely affect families that visit the stadium. The suit was dropped after the Mariners reached a compromise which included limits on [[outdoor advertising]], window displays, and signs. The compromise specified that the clubs video screens would only show text on kids days at the stadium, and not images of strippers. In May 2010, there was public controversy because the club showed strippers on its large electronic display on "kids' day". Dreamgirls claimed that it is the team's responsibility to tell them when such a display is prohibited.<ref name="MyNorthwest 2010">{{cite web|url=http://mynorthwest.com/?nid=11&sid=313187 |title=Families outraged over strip club advertising on Kids Day |accessdate=2010-06-16 |work=MyNorthwest.com (Bonneville International) |date=2010-04-23 |last1=Shaprio |first1=Brian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100428223541/http://www.mynorthwest.com/?nid=11&sid=313187 |archivedate=2010-04-28 |df= }}</ref>
Elite Cabaret, a [[Tempe, Arizona|Tempe]] city strip club, filed suit in 2007 against the City of Tempe in federal court. In the settlement that was reached, the two sides ended the legal wrangle amidst a host of stipulations. One clause is aimed at preventing the racy image promoted by strip clubs. The club is not allowed to depict the human body on the exterior of its building. Signs cannot say "nude", "topless", "girls" or similar words. The sign can only have the bar's name and terms like "cabaret" or "gentlemen's club".<ref name="LawyersAndSettlements.com 2007">{{cite web | url = http://www.lawyersandsettlements.com/case/tempe-strip-club-ordinance.html | title = Settlements and Verdicts: Elite Cabaret | accessdate = 2010-06-16 | work = Online Legal Media | date = 2007-08-31 | last1 = | first1 =}}</ref> Strip club advertising and its associated controversy are not limited to the United States. In South Africa, well-known strip club chain Teazers generated media coverage and official complaints to the [[Advertising Standards Authority of South Africa]] (ASA) over its suggestive billboards.<ref name="News24 BillStorm 2009">{{cite web | url = http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Storm-over-Teazers-billboard-20090930 | title = Storm over Teazers billboard | accessdate = 2010-07-01 | work = News24.com | date = 2009-09-30 | last1 = Fourie | first1 = Magdel}}</ref><ref name="News24 BillDegrade 2009">{{cite web | url = http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Teazers-billboard-degrading-20080514 | title = Teazers billboard 'degrading' | accessdate = 2010-07-01 | work = News24.com | date = 2008-05-14 | last1 = South African Press Association | first1 =}}</ref><ref name="TimesLive 20K 2009">{{cite web | url = http://www.timeslive.co.za/news/article134335.ece | title = Teazers boss: R20,000 not a guilty payment | accessdate = 2010-07-01 | work = Times Live (AVUSA, Inc.) | date = 2009-10-01 | last1 = Sabela | first1 = Zanele}}</ref><ref name="MailGuard HailBullets 2010">{{cite web | url = http://www.mg.co.za/article/2010-05-04-stripclub-owner-dies-in-hail-of-bullets | title = Strip-club owner dies in hail of bullets | accessdate = 2010-07-01 | work = Mail & Guardian Online | date = 2010-05-04 | last1 = South African Press Association | first1 =}}</ref>
== Law and politics == {{Globalize/Anglosphere|date=February 2013}} {{Main|Legal status of striptease}} The legal status of strip clubs has evolved over the course of time, with national and local laws becoming progressively more liberal on the issue around the world, although some countries (such as Iceland) have implemented strict limits and bans.<ref name="IcelandBan 2010">{{cite web | url = http://icelandreview.com/icelandreview/daily_news/?cat_id=16567&ew_0_a_id=359882 | title = Legislation Bans Stripping in Iceland | accessdate = 2010-06-06 | work = Iceland Review | date = 2010-03-24}}</ref> Strip clubs are frequent targets of litigation around the world, and the sex industry, which includes strip clubs, is a hot button issue in popular culture and politics. Some clubs have been linked to [[organized crime]],<ref name="TriBizJo 2007">{{cite news | url = http://triangle.bizjournals.com/triangle/stories/2007/12/17/story11.html | title = Strip club's ownership shift creates furor over payments | accessdate = 2010-05-07 | work = Triangle Business Journal | date = 2007-12-14 | first = Chris | last = Coletta}}</ref> which has been known to use legitimate business as fronts for its illegal operations.
=== United States and the Americas === With the [[Law of the United States|legal system]] of the U.S. based on [[common law]], motivations for lawsuits can range from legitimate legal grounds to cases filed with the intent of shaping [[case law]] to favor the [[socio-political]] aims of [[Advocacy group|special interest groups]]. Clubs around the country have personnel and clientele that are purported to engage in not only sex acts on the premises,<ref name="KFBB 2009"/> but also drug use and other criminalized activities. Incidents of such activity vary widely. Their prevalence is dependent on regional differences in the attitudes of management, entertainers, customers, and law enforcement.<ref name="BuffNews Whipple 2010"/><ref>{{cite book | author = Barry Barry Michael Dank | author2 = Roberto Refinetti, PH. D. | title = The Politics of Sexuality | url = https://books.google.com/?id=ztORMQEACAAJ | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2000-02-23 | publisher = Transaction Publishers | isbn = 978-0-7658-0651-2}}</ref> Strip clubs are obligated to enforce age limits for entry to the clubs and consumption of alcohol.<ref name="ALC 24K 2009"/> If a club is found to have served a person under the age of 21 alcohol it can have its liquor license suspended or rescinded for repeated violations.<ref name="ALC 24K 2009"/> Licenses can also be lost due to evidence of drug use in the club.<ref name="BuffNews Whipple 2010">{{cite web | author=Dan Herbeck | url = http://www.buffalonews.com/2010/06/27/1096106/strip-club-owner-professes-legitimacy.html | title = Strip club owner professes legitimacy | publisher = The Buffalo News | date = 2010-08-03 | accessdate = 2010-08-13}}</ref> Club owners have closed their businesses as a result of losing a liquor license.<ref name="BuffNews Whipple 2010"/>
A widely cited U.S. local ordinance is San Diego (California) Municipal Code 33.3610,<ref name="SD code 2000">{{cite web | url = http://docs.sandiego.gov/municode/MuniCodeChapter03/Ch03Art03Division36.pdf | title = San Diego Municipal Code: Chapter 3: Business Regulations, Business Taxes, Permits and Licenses: Division 36: Nude Entertainment Business | accessdate = 2010-05-02 | work = City of San Diego | date = November 2000}}</ref> specific and strict in response to allegations of corruption among local officials,<ref name="SD uniontrib 2005">{{cite web | url = http://legacy.signonsandiego.com/news/metro/probe/20050719-9999-1n19council.html | title = More bad news? What else is new? | accessdate = 2010-05-02 | work = San Diego Union-Tribune | date = 2005-06-19}}</ref> which included contacts in the nude entertainment industry. Among its provisions is the "six-foot rule", copied by other municipalities in requiring that dancers maintain a six-foot distance from patrons while performing. ''Fully nude'' clubs may be subject to additional requirements, such as restrictions on alcohol sales and ''no-touch rules'' between customers and dancers.<ref>[http://www.firstamendmentcenter.org/speech/adultent/topic.aspx?topic=nude_dancing Nude Dancing] {{webarchive|url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20041222014629/http://www.firstamendmentcenter.org/speech/adultent/topic.aspx?topic=nude_dancing |date=2004-12-22 }} (from the [[First Amendment Center]] website)</ref> To circumvent these rules, two "separate" bars{{snd}}one topless and one fully nude{{snd}}may open adjacent to one another. In a small number of states and jurisdictions where it is legal for alcohol to be consumed but not sold, some clubs still allow customers to [[byob|bring their own beverages]].
Still other rules forbid "full nudity" in certain districts, which can vary among different areas within the same town. Some parts of the U.S. have laws forbidding the exposure of female [[nipple]]s or even [[areola]]s, thus requiring female dancers to cover these with [[pasties]]. These laws are not, however, known to be applied to the exposure of male nipples. Managers, dancers, and other club workers can be cited or arrested by local or federal authorities for violating nudity, drug, and other violations.<ref name="BuffNews Whipple 2010"/> In February 2010, the U.S. city of [[Detroit, Michigan]] banned fully exposed breasts in its strip clubs, following the example of [[Houston, Texas]], which began enforcing a similar ordinance in 2008.<ref name="VicTimes 2008">{{cite web|url=http://www.canada.com/victoriatimescolonist/story.html?k=71554&id=38135a7b-209a-41ef-a325-80435be65732 |title=Houston topless clubs lose case, may respond to Supreme Court with pasties |accessdate=2010-05-05 |work=Victoria Times |date=2008-03-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212210544/http://www.canada.com/victoriatimescolonist/story.html?k=71554&id=38135a7b-209a-41ef-a325-80435be65732 |archivedate=2012-02-12 |df= }}</ref> The Detroit city council has since softened the rules; eliminating the requirement for pasties but keeping other restrictions.<ref name="ClickOnDet 2010">{{cite web|url=http://www.clickondetroit.com/news/22628122/detail.html |title=Detroit Passes New Strip Club Rules |accessdate=2010-05-05 |work=ClickOn Detroit |date=2010-02-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609032414/http://www.clickondetroit.com/news/22628122/detail.html |archivedate=2011-06-09 |df= }}</ref> Both municipalities were reputed to have suffered rampant occurrences of illicit activities, including [[prostitution]], all linked to striptease establishments within their cities' limits.<ref name="SmokingGun 2008">{{cite web | url = http://www.thesmokinggun.com/archive/years/2008/0602081harris1.html | title = Another Houston Strip Club Raided | accessdate = 2010-05-05 | work = The Smoking Gun | date = 2008-06-02}}</ref><ref name="KissDetroit 2009">{{cite web|url=https://kissdetroit.com/10251/detroitcitycounciltovoteonstripclubrestrictions/ |title=Detroit City Council To Vote on Strip Club Restrictions |accessdate=2010-05-05 |work=The Smoking Gun |date=2009-11-11 }}</ref> Detroit has also drawn attention from the federal government for incidents of [[human trafficking]] in its strip clubs.<ref name="VOA Trafficking 2010">{{cite web | url = http://www1.voanews.com/policy/editorials/Working-To-End-Human-Trafficking-93446434.html?refresh=1 | title = Working To End Human Trafficking | accessdate = 2010-06-19 | work = Voice of America News | date = 2008-05-12 | last1 = | first1 =}}</ref> In 2010, the state of Missouri passed a law similar to that of Houston and Detroit, banning full nudity in strip clubs across the state.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.newspressnow.com/news/article_7da45fe6-62ac-5110-ad97-c65d11811d8a.html |title= Nixon Bans Full Nudity, Alcohol At Missouri Strip Clubs |date= Jun 26, 2010 |publisher= [[St. Joseph News-Press]] }}</ref>
Strip clubs have also received attention in the Americas outside the United States. There have been several attempts to amend the [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[Immigration and Refugee Protection Act]] (IRPA), passed in 2001. The 2009 version of the bill (Bill C-45: An Act to amend the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act) contained provisions intended to tighten the issuing of [[tourist visa|visa]]s to exotic dancers, to combat [[human trafficking]].<ref name="Guardian Amend 2009">{{cite web | url = http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/LegislativeSummaries/Bills_ls.asp?lang=E&ls=c45&source=library_prb&Parl=40&Ses=2 | title = Bill C-45: An Act to amend the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act | accessdate = 2010-06-11 | work = The Guardian | date = 2009-08-25 | last1 = Harrold | first1 = Daphne Keevil}}</ref> In August 2009, the city of Rio de Janeiro, while bidding for the 2014 World Cup, shut down one of its most notorious clubs, the Help discothèque. There were plans to bulldoze the club and "replace it with a music-themed museum" with US firm [[Diller Scofidio + Renfro]] as architects, backed by Rio's governor [[Sergio Cabral]] who was also backing the [[2016 Summer Olympics]] bid.<ref name="Guardian RioClose 2009">{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/aug/17/rio-help-nightclub-closure | title = Rio nightclub closure leaves prostitutes Helpless | accessdate = 2010-07-05 | work = Guardian.co.uk | date = 2009-08-17 | last1 = Phillips | first1 = Tom | location = London}}</ref> In November 2009, officials in Rio de Janeiro threatened to sue American comedian [[Robin Williams]] for disparaging comments made on a [[late-night talk show]]. One of his comments on its Olympics bid, "Rio sent 50 strippers and a pound of blow. It wasn't really fair, you know?" was replayed several times on news shows in Brazil and prompted a public response from its mayor. The Olympic Committee for Rio had its lawyers investigate whether there were grounds for a lawsuit, but no charges were filed.<ref name="NBC RioSue 2009">{{cite web | url = http://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local-beat/Rio-Looks-to-Sue-Robin-Williams-for-Olympic-Comment-78246597.html#ixzz0sq8PJgKo | title = Rio Looks to Sue Robin Williams for Olympic Comment | accessdate = 2010-07-05 | work = The Guardian | date = 2009-12-01 | last1 = Greiner | first1 = Andrew}}</ref>
=== United Kingdom === In 2009, the United Kingdom passed the [[Policing and Crime Act 2009|Policing and Crime Act]] following concerns about an increase in the number of strip clubs in the country. Any strip clubs where live entertainment takes place more than 11 times a year must apply for a [[License|licence]] from their [[local authorities]].<ref name="Echo NewLaws 2010">{{cite web|url=http://www.echo-news.co.uk/news/8212913.Tough_new_rules_on_strip_club_openings/|title=Tough new rules on strip club openings|accessdate=2010-06-11|work=Echo| date=2008-06-11 |last1=Orbach |first1=Max}}</ref> Such clubs are routinely opposed by those who feel that these 'lower the tone' of particular neighbourhoods. The legislation caused a reduction in the number of relevant premises, from about 350 in the early 2000s to fewer than 200, across the [[UK]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sevlicensing.wordpress.com |title=SEV licensing|accessdate=18 December 2015}}</ref> In 2014, the East London Strippers Collective was formed to improve working conditions in strip clubs. Their concerns included poorly-maintained working environments, exploitative business practises including the levying of fees, commission and fines, and a lack of employment protection and job security.<ref>{{cite news|title=We're a group of strippers working to improve our employment conditions - and we want your support, rather than your sympathy|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/were-a-group-of-strippers-working-to-improve-our-employment-conditions-and-we-want-your-support-a6695241.html|newspaper=The Independent|author1=Stacey Clare|author2=Billy Laser|date=15 October 2015|accessdate=6 April 2016}}</ref>
=== Rest of Europe === The [[Ireland|Irish]] government had, at one time, special visa categories for 'entertainers,' which enabled the trafficking of women for strip clubs and prostitution.<ref name="Jeffreys 2009"/>
In 2001, the former immigration chief in [[Cyprus]] was found guilty of accepting bribes to issue work permits to foreign women (in this case from [[Ukraine]]), to work as strippers in clubs, with some forced into prostitution.<ref name="Finckenauer 2008">{{cite book | title = The prediction and control of organized crime: the experience of post-Soviet Ukraine | url = https://books.google.com/?id=fcUH3dKPYUIC | year = 2008 | publisher = Transaction Publishers | isbn = 978-0-7658-0562-1 | last1 = Finckenauer | last2 = Schrock | first1 = James O. | first2 = Jennifer L.}}</ref> Throughout the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy, Canada, and the Netherlands, studies have shown that Russian individuals and organized crime groups are importing women from Russia, Ukraine, the Baltic States, and Central Europe into the Russian sex industry to work in stripping, prostitution, peep and show club services, and massage and escort services, among others.<ref name="Ebbe 2008">{{cite book | title = Global trafficking in women and children | url = https://books.google.com/?id=9jTt5yJ1Qz8C | year = 2008 | publisher = CRC Press | isbn = 978-1-4200-5943-4 | last1 = Ebbe | last2 = Das | first1 = Obi N. Ignatius | first2 = Dilip K.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author = Melissa Farley, PhD | title = Prostitution, Trafficking and Traumatic Stress | url = https://books.google.com/?id=e7qyVMwVL_MC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 2003 | publisher = Psychology Press | isbn = 978-0-7890-2379-7}}</ref>
In March 2010, [[Iceland]] outlawed [[strip club ban in Iceland|striptease]].<ref name="IcelandBan 2010"/> [[Jóhanna Sigurðardóttir]], Iceland's prime minister, said: "The Nordic countries are leading the way on women's equality, recognizing women as equal citizens rather than commodities for sale."<ref name="Salon Iceland 2010">{{cite web | url = http://www.salon.com/life/broadsheet/2010/03/26/iceland_bans_stripping_strip_clubs | title = Iceland's stripping ban: Does the country's move to shut down strip clubs really make it the most "female-friendly on the planet"? | accessdate = 2010-05-07 | work = Salon.com | date = 2010-03-26 | last1 = Clark-Flory | first1 = Tracy}}</ref> The politician behind the bill, [[Kolbrún Halldórsdóttir]], said: "It is not acceptable that women or people in general are a product to be sold."<ref name="Salon Iceland 2010"/>
=== Rest of the world === Outside the United States, views on strip clubs, and on sexuality in general, can be much more liberal. American striptease, though present, can be treated much differently. Activities which are not legal in most parts of the United States or its territories may be permitted in other parts of the world. Also, ties to [[criminal]] elements (as defined by [[international law]]) can be much more pronounced.
In Eastern Europe and Asia, common incidents of strip club crime involve customers being quoted a price upon entering a club, only to find out later that management expects a much higher payment before customers are permitted to leave. Intimidation and possibly the threat of violence are used to compel customers to comply.<ref name="AsiaOne Pay 2009"/>
The Japanese government, similar to Canada and Ireland, had special visa categories for "entertainers". These enabled the trafficking of women for strip clubs and prostitution.<ref name="Jeffreys 2009">{{cite book | title = The industrial vagina: the political economy of the global sex trade | url = https://books.google.com/?id=qb4EMAEACAAJ | year = 2009 | publisher = Taylor & Francis | isbn = 978-0-415-41233-9 | pages = 86–106 | last1 = Jeffreys | first1 = Sheila}}</ref>
In South Africa, there has been public controversy over incidents of prostitution and violence related to its strip clubs.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.mg.co.za/article/2010-05-28-gigis-pad-no-cleancut-strip-club | title = Gigi's pad 'no clean-cut strip club' | accessdate = 2010-07-05 | work = Mail & Guardian | date = 2010-05-28 | last1 = Rawoot | first1 = Ilham}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.thoughtleader.co.za/amabhungane/2010/05/20/this-is-why-we-write-about-strip-clubs/ | title = This is why we write about strip clubs | accessdate = 2010-07-05 | work = Mail & Guardian | date = 2010-05-20 | last1 = Rawoot | first1 = Ilham}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.mg.co.za/article/2010-05-07-giving-lollylovers-some-stick | title = Giving Lolly-lovers some stick | accessdate = 2010-07-05 | work = Mail & Guardian | date = 2010-05-07 | last1 = Raphaely | first1 = Vanessa}}</ref> In June 2010, 17 customers were arrested, during a raid at a strip club in [[Cape Town]], for committing unspecified illegal acts. 35 Eastern European dancers were also arrested for working at the club without the correct documents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.info.gov.za/speeches/2010/10062809251001.htm |title=Thirty five Eastern European exotic dancers arrested at Arabesque night club to be deported |accessdate=2010-07-05 |work=South African Department of Home Affairs |date=2010-06-26 |last1=Mamoepa |first1=Ronnie |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100701084247/http://www.info.gov.za/speeches/2010/10062809251001.htm |archivedate=2010-07-01 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ewn.co.za/articleprog.aspx?id=42787 |title=17 strip club customers arrested for 'illegal acts' |accessdate=5 July 2010 |work=Eyewitness News (Primedia Broadcasting) |date=27 June 2010 |last1=du Plessis |first1=JP |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815225612/http://ewn.co.za/articleprog.aspx?id=42787 |archivedate=15 August 2011 |df= }}</ref>
In 2008, the [[NSW Bureau of Crime Statistics and Research]] in [[Sydney, Australia]] reported 1,600 people were charged with committing a range of 27 criminal offenses in the state's "[[places of worship]]". Oddly, the figures showed only 282 people were charged with the same offenses in premises classified as [[adult entertainment]] establishments. A breakdown of the statistical figures showed that 85 people were assaulted in places of worship, compared to 66 at adult entertainment locations. Incidents of both sexual assault and harassing and threatening behavior were also greater at places of worship. The report included [[church (building)|churches]], [[synagogues]], [[monasteries]], [[mosques]], [[convents]], [[cathedrals]] and [[chapels]] as places of worship. Premises listed as adult entertainment sites included strip clubs, [[sex shop]]s, [[brothel]]s, [[massage parlor]]s, [[gay club]]s, [[casino|gaming houses]], and [[gambling]] clubs. The bureau's interpretation was that people were just as likely to be assaulted or robbed in the sanctity of a church as they were in sex industry venues.<ref name="Freethinker safer 2008">{{cite web | url = http://freethinker.co.uk/2010/04/12/australians-are-safer-in-strip-joints-gay-clubs-or-brothels-than-in-churches/ | title = Australians are safer in strip joints, gay clubs or brothels than in churches | accessdate = 2010-06-14 | work = The Freethinker | date = 2008-04-12 | last1 = Duke | first1 = Barry}}</ref>
== Cultural impact == [[File:Ground Zero Mosque Strip Club.jpg|thumb|The New York Dolls strip club played a prominent role in the [[Park51]] controversy.]] The strip club as an outlet for salacious entertainment is a recurrent theme in [[popular culture]].<ref name="Boles and Garbin 1974"/> In the media, clubs are portrayed primarily as gathering places of [[vice]] and ill [[reputation|repute]]. Both clubs themselves and various features of the business are highlighted in these references. Comedian [[Chris Rock]] also pokes fun at the champagne room in his spoken word track, "[[No Sex (In the Champagne Room)]]", on his 1999 album, ''[[Bigger & Blacker]]''. [[Wyclef Jean]] later noted Rock's comment in his own reflection on strippers, "[[Perfect Gentleman (Wyclef Jean song)|Perfect Gentleman]]". In 2016, rapper [[Shawty Lo]]'s funeral procession stopped at his favorite strip club, The Blue Flame Lounge in Atlanta, where patrons and mourners honored his casket with a moment of silence.<ref>{{cite web | title = Shawty Lo Final Resting Place Has Tons of T & A | publisher = TMZ | date = October 1, 2016 | url = http://www.tmz.com/2016/10/01/shawty-lo-funeral-strip-club-memorial/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Maas | first = Jennifer | title = Shawty Lo's Funeral Ends With His Hearse Driving To His Fave Strip Club — Watch | publisher = Hollywoodlife | date = October 1, 2016 | url = http://hollywoodlife.com/2016/10/01/shawty-lo-funeral-strip-club-video-watch/}}</ref>
=== Film, television, and theater === The image of strippers as known today evolved through the late [[Striptease#1960s-1970s|1960s and 1970s]] in the U.S. and in international cultures which embraced American striptease.<ref name="DiNardo Gilded 2007"/> By the 1980s, the pole dancing and highly explicit imagery associated with today's performers was widely accepted and frequently portrayed in film, television, and theater.
==== 1980s–1990s ==== In addition to lesser-known videos such as ''[[A Night at the Revuebar]]'' (1983), the 1980s also featured mainstream films involving strippers and their work as part of the central narrative. These included ''[[Flashdance]]'' (1983), which told the story of blue-collar worker Alexandra (Alex) Owens ([[Jennifer Beals]]), who works as an exotic dancer in a [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] bar at night and at a steel mill as a welder during the day.<ref>{{cite book | author = Stanley Green | title = Hollywood Musicals: Year by Year | url = https://books.google.com/?id=XD2xNKSN3E8C | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2000-01-01 | publisher = Hal Leonard Corp | isbn = 978-0-634-00765-1}}</ref> ''[[Blaze (1989 film)|Blaze]]'' (1989) features [[Lolita Davidovitch]] as notorious stripper [[Blaze Starr]]. Starr herself appears in the film in a cameo role. ''[[Exotica (film)|Exotica]]'' (1994), directed by [[Atom Egoyan]], is set in a Canadian lap-dance club, and portrays a man's ([[Bruce Greenwood]]) obsession with a [[student|schoolgirl]] stripper named Christina ([[Mia Kirshner]]). ''[[Showgirls]]'' (1995) was directed by [[Paul Verhoeven]] and starred [[Elizabeth Berkley]] and [[Gina Gershon]]. ''[[Striptease (film)|Striptease]]'' (1996), was an adaptation of the novel starring [[Demi Moore]]. ''[[The Players Club]]'' (1998) starred [[LisaRaye]] as a girl who becomes a stripper to earn enough money to enter college and study journalism.
In ''[[Jekyll & Hyde (musical)|Jekyll and Hyde]]'' (1997), the character of Lucy Harris (originally portrayed by [[Linda Eder]]) works as a [[prostitute]] and stripper in a small London club called The Red Rat, where she meets a multi-dimension man named Doctor Henry Jekyll, who turns into his evil persona Mr. Edward Hyde. Lucy performs the song 'Bring on the Men' during a show at the Red Rat (which was later replaced with 'Good 'n' Evil' in the Broadway production, some claiming 'Bring on the Men' was too 'risqué'.). In ''[[Neighbours]]'' (1985), the character of [[Daphne Clarke|Daphne]] is originally a stripper at Des's bucks party, and eventually goes on to marry him. ''[[Married... with Children]]'' (1987–97) often featured [[Al Bundy]], [[Jefferson D'Arcy]], and the NO MA'AM crew spending a night at the Nudie Bar.<ref>{{cite book | author = Brenton J. Malin | title = American Masculinity Under Clinton: Popular Media And the Nineties "Crisis of Masculinity" | url = https://books.google.com/?id=Ue4N9NnHkDgC | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 2005 | publisher = Peter Lang | isbn = 978-0-8204-6806-8}}</ref> In the six season of ''[[The Sopranos]]'' (1999–2007), business was often conducted at the [[Bada Bing]] strip club.
==== 2000s–present ==== By the 2000s, visits to strip clubs by characters in action movies were a common occurrence.<ref>{{cite book | author = Melvin Burke Donalson | title = Black Directors in Hollywood | url = https://books.google.com/?id=5YWgxVkJmT4C | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | year = 2003 | isbn = 978-0-292-70179-3}}</ref> ''[[Dancing at the Blue Iguana]]'' (2000) is a feature film starring [[Daryl Hannah]]. The female cast of the film researched the film by dancing at strip clubs and created their parts and their storylines to be as realistic as possible. ''[[The Raymond Revuebar the Art of Striptease]]'' (2002) is a documentary, directed by Simon Weitzman. ''[[Los Debutantes]]'' (2003) is a [[Chile]]an film set in a strip-club in [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]]. ''[[Portraits of a Naked Lady Dancer]]'' (2004) is a documentary, directed by Deborah Rowe. In '' [[Closer (2004 film)|Closer]]'' (2004), [[Natalie Portman]] plays Alice, a young stripper just arrived in London from America. ''[[Crazy Horse Le Show]]'' (2004) features dance routines from the Crazy Horse, Paris. ''[[I Know Who Killed Me]]'' (2007) stars [[Lindsay Lohan]] as Dakota Moss, an alluring stripper involved in the machinations of a serial killer, and features a long striptease sequence at a strip club.<ref>{{cite book | author = Outlook Publishing | title = Outlook | url = https://books.google.com/?id=UjEEAAAAMBAJ | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2008-02-18 | publisher = Outlook Publishing}}</ref> In 2009, a DVD called "Crazy Horse Paris" featuring [[Dita Von Teese]] was released. ''[[Barely Phyllis]]'' is a play on [[Phyllis Dixey]] which was first staged at the [[Pomegranate Theatre]], [[Chesterfield]] in 2009. A strip club is prominently featured in the film "[[Megean and Andrew go to a Strip Club]]" (2011) in which the title characters go to a strip club. ''[[Strip Search (TV series)|Stripsearch]]'' (2001–), an ongoing [[Australia]]n [[reality television]] show which centers around the training of male strippers. In ''[[Degrassi: The Next Generation]]'' (2007), in the two-part season 6 finale, titled ''Don't You Want Me'', [[Alex Nunez]] resorts to stripping after her mother and herself do not have enough money to pay the rent on their apartment.
=== Notable locations === One of the most famous strip clubs in the U.S. is on [[New Jersey Route 17|Route 17]] in [[Lodi, New Jersey]]. It was featured on the television show ''[[The Sopranos]]''. The club is actually a go-go bar, serving alcohol with dancers, and it does not offer [[nudity]]. It is called "Satin Dolls" in real life, but is known more universally around the world and in the show as "[[Bada Bing|The Bada Bing]]".<ref name="CBSNews SatinDolls 2007">{{cite news | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/08/20/entertainment/main3184854.shtml | title = "Bada Bing" Auction Sales Go "Bada Boom": HBO Series Memorabilia To Be Auctioned Online | accessdate = 2010-07-06 | work = CBS Interactive Inc. | date = 2007-08-20 | last1 = Castellanos | first1 = Melissa}}</ref> The Gold Club was an [[Atlanta]] adult entertainment club receiving national attention for the indictment of several of its owners, managers, and employees. The Gold Club trial received significant attention because numerous significant professional athletes were called to testify.<ref name="Lewis Purdue 2002"/><ref name="ESPN GoldClub 2007">{{cite web | url = http://proxy.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?id=1237371 | title = Idiot's Guide to Gold Club Trial | accessdate = 2010-07-06 | work = [[Page 2]] | publisher = [[ESPN.com]] | date = 2007-09-27 | first = Bill | last = Simmons | authorlink = Bill Simmons}}</ref> The club was closed after the convictions of its owner plus several managers and employees.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.cnn.com/2001/LAW/08/02/gold.club/index.html |work=CNN |title=Strip club boss cops plea in rackets trial |date=2001-08-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090718212532/http://archives.cnn.com/2001/LAW/08/02/gold.club/index.html |archivedate=2009-07-18 |df= }}</ref>
''[[Sapphire Gentlemen's Club]]'' in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]]<ref>{{cite news | url = http://las-vegas-strip-clubs.com/strip-clubs/sapphires-strip-club-las-vegas/ | work = Sapphires Las Vegas | title = Las Vegas Strip Clubs | date = 2001-08-03}}</ref> has been billed as the world's largest strip club. In 2006 it sold at auction for US$80 million.<ref name="Sapphire Sale 2006"/> [[Tampa, Florida]] is well known for its strip clubs, including the famous ''[[Mons Venus]]''. [[Howard Stern]], a [[radio host]] and [[television personality]], makes frequent mention of 'Rick's Cabaret' which operates in several cities. [[Bangkok]] and [[Pattaya]] in [[Thailand]] are world-famous for their go bars offering a variety of extra services.<ref>{{cite book | author = Paul Gray |author2=Lucy Ridout | title = The Rough Guide to Thailand's Beaches & Islands. | url = https://books.google.com/?id=KYkJkgQ2gA8C | accessdate = 2010-08-13 | date = 2002-01-31 | publisher = Rough Guides Limited | isbn = 978-1-85828-829-1}}</ref>
=== Top clubs === Given the variety of club formats and laws governing the operation of strip clubs around the world, a definitive and objective list of top clubs is not practical. The popularity of a given club is an indicator of its quality, as is the word of mouth among customers who have visited a cross section of clubs in different regions. A 2013 article published by the [[AskMen.com]] portal posted a list of the top 10 strip clubs in the world.<ref name="AskMen Top10Clubs 2008">{{cite web|url=http://uk.askmen.com/top_10/travel/strip-clubs.html | website=www.uk.askmen.com|title=World's Best Strip Clubs|author=Salvatore Mann|accessdate=22 December 2015}}</ref> According to their criteria, which included aesthetics, quality of girls, services, and such, the top clubs at the time were:
# Playhouse Gentleman's Club, [[Warsaw]] # [[Night Flight (night club)|Night Flight]], [[Moscow]] # Larry Flynt's [[Hustler Club]], [[New York City]] # 4 Play Gentlemen's Club, [[Los Angeles]] # [[Spearmint Rhino]], [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] # [[Crazy Horse (cabaret)|Le Crazy Horse]], [[Paris]] # Seventh Heaven, [[Tokyo]] # Temptations, [[Bristol]] # Wanda's, [[Montreal]] # K5 Relax, [[Prague]]
U.S. style striptease remains a global phenomenon and culturally accepted form of entertainment, despite its scrutiny in legal circles and popular media. Over half of clubs still open from the list are located outside the United States. Popular internet sites for strip club enthusiasts also have Top Club lists calculated from input from their online visitors. The Ultimate Strip Club List has a Top 100 Strip Clubs list, generated by analyzing the ratings for all of its clubs as entered by individual reviewers.<ref name="TUSCL top100">{{cite web | url = http://www.tuscl.net/t.php | title = Top 100 Strip Clubs | accessdate = 2010-05-01 | work = The Ultimate Strip Club List (TUSCL) | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100502071020/http://www.tuscl.net/t.php | archivedate = 2010-05-02 | df = }}</ref> Its list regularly includes strip clubs from outside the U.S. and the site details clubs from countries across six continents. The Strip Club Network, calculates its online Strip Club List: Top 100 Clubs, by the total number of views that each club information page has received on their website.<ref name="SCL top100">{{cite web|url=http://www.stripclublist.com/top |title=Strip Club List Top 100 Clubs |accessdate=2010-05-01 |work=Strip Club List (SCL) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100412045009/http://www.stripclublist.com/top100viewed.asp |archivedate=2010-04-12 |df= }}</ref>

{{Infobox book | name = The Darkened Room: Women, Power and Spiritualism in Late Victorian England | image = Alex Owen's Darkened Room.jpg | image_size = 180px | caption = The first edition cover of the book. | author = Alex Owen | country = United Kingdom | language = English | subject = [[History of religion]] | publisher = [[Virago]] | release_date = 1989 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]] & [[Paperback]]) | pages = 307 | isbn = 978-0-86068-567-8 | oclc = }}
'''''The Darkened Room: Women, Power and Spiritualism in Late Victorian England''''' is a historical study into the role played by women in the [[Spiritualism|Spiritualist]] religious movement in England during the latter part of the 19th century. It was written by the British historian Alex Owen and first published in 1989 by [[Virago]], before being republished in 2004 by the [[University of Chicago Press]].
A work of [[feminist history]] which arose from Owen's PhD thesis undertaken at the [[University of Sussex]], ''The Darkened Room'' looks at the role of women in the Spiritualist movement of the period, counterbalancing what Owen perceived as a former focus on the role of men.
==Background==
===Owen and her research=== The basis to ''The Darkened Room'' came from Owen's PhD thesis, undertaken at the [[University of Sussex]]. Exploring "the idea of [[femininity]] as a social construct", she initially planned to focus her thesis on the manner in which Victorian medical science played in reinforcing "a feminine norm", but in doing so came upon the case of Louisa Lowe, a woman who appeared in front of the Parliamentary Select Committee in 1887, claiming that she had been wrongly incarcerated in a mental asylum by her husband because she was a Spiritualist. Fascinated by the relationship between this Spiritualist movement and women in Late Victorian England, she decided to refocus her doctorate on this topic instead.<ref>[[#Owe89|Owen 1989]]. pp. i–ii.</ref>
{{Quote box |width = 30em |border = 1px |align = left |bgcolor = #ACE1AF |fontsize = 85% |title_bg = |title_fnt = |title = |quote = "One of the underpinning themes of this book remains... that of femininity: the way in which spiritualist women were constructed as 'natural' mediums, the 'innate' femininity which allowed women to accede to positions of power but which then trapped them within a limiting self-definition, the transgressive femininity which emerged during some of the more extraordinary séances, and the hostility aroused by the spectacle of femininity gone awry." |salign = right |source = Alex Owen in her Introduction, 1989.<ref>[[#Owe89|Owen 1989]]. p. ii.</ref> }} Highlighting that the majority of scholarly work on the subject of Spiritualism had focused on male members of the religion, she decided to take a feminist approach to the subject by focusing on the women. Deciding to explore "issues of power and subversion", she adopted the definition of "[[Power (philosophy)|power]]" provided by the famous French philosopher [[Michel Foucault]] (1926–1984).<ref>[[#Owe89|Owen 1989]]. pp. ii–iii.</ref> Owen took as her primary source material the published tracts, personal accounts and newsletters of the Late Victorian Spiritualist movement, noting that W.H. Harrison's ''Spiritualist'' and James Burns' ''Human Nature'' and ''Medium Daybreak'' proved to be "the most useful, enlightening and engaging."<ref>[[#Owe89|Owen 1989]]. p. iv.</ref> A non-Spiritualist, Owen admitted that she could not explain many of the accounts of spirits which appeared in the accounts of Spiritualist séances.<ref>[[#Owe89|Owen 1989]]. pp. vi–vii.</ref>
Following the completion of her thesis, Owen moved to the United States, taking up a Research Fellowship at the [[University of California, San Diego]] from 1983 until 1986 and then a position as a Research Associate and Visiting Lecturer in the Women's Program in Religion at the [[Harvard Divinity School]] from 1986 until 1987, funded by the [[Rockefeller Foundation]]. It was while working in these positions that she wrote up her thesis as ''The Darkened Room''.<ref>[[#Owe89|Owen 1989]]. pp. acknowledgments.</ref>
==Reception==
===Press reviews=== ''The Darkened Room'' was reviewed by Dinah Birch for the ''[[London Review of Books]]''. Birch noted that by the 1980s, Spiritualism had been "bundled out of sight, like a batty old aunt at a family gathering", ignoring the importance that it had held in Victorian society. Describing Owen's work as "solid and compelling", she highlighted a number of its arguments. <ref>[[#Bir89|Birch 1989]].</ref>

{{refimprove|date=December 2012}} The '''Trustor affair''' involved the takeover in the summer of 1997 of a Swedish investment company listed on the [[Stockholm Stock Exchange]]. It was initially believed that following the takeover 600 million [[Swedish krona|SEK]] had disappeared from the company's accounts.<ref name=annual>Trustor ABs annual report 1997 {{page needed|date=November 2012}}</ref> Later, when all assets had been accounted for and the company had been liquidated, the shareholders had almost doubled the value of their shares as an indirect result of the [[takeover]]. It is one of the largest [[financial cases]] in [[Swedish people|Swedish]] history.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}}
== Course of events == {{refimprove section|date=August 2012}} In 1997 several individuals including the British lord [[Jonathan Guinness]], [[Lord Moyne]], planned the take over of the Swedish investment company Trustor AB.<ref name="Lindstedt, G. 2000">{{cite book |last=Lindstedt |first=Gunnar |title=Svindlande affärer: historien om Trustor |year=2000 |publisher=DN |location=Stockholm |language=Swedish |isbn=91-7588-359-7}}{{page needed|date=November 2012}}</ref>
Team Moyne had initially identified a couple of companies which matched the criteria making them suitable for takeover, of which Trustor was one. In January 1997 Jisander contacted [[Erik Penser|Erik Penser Fond Commission (EPFC)]]. Mattson and Jisander met with EPFC as representatives for Lord Moyne who was interested in buying a Swedish investment company. Jisander and Mattson presented both proof that they were indeed acting on behalf of Lord Moyne and the criteria for the target company and after a series of discussions Trustor was found to be the best alternative.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite book |title=Trustor - händelser och slutsatser: rapport från en av Stockholms fondbörs tillkallad utredning |series=Stockholms fondbörs skriftserie, 99-0819901-3 ; 22 |year=1998 |publisher=Stockholms fondbörs |location=Stockholm |language=Swedish}}{{page needed|date=November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Lindstedt |first=Gunnar |title=Svindlande affärer: historien om Trustor |year=2000 |publisher=DN |location=Stockholm |language=Swedish |isbn=91-7588-359-7 |page=122}}</ref>
The A-stocks of Trustor were owned by [[Per-Olov Norberg]]. They constituted 17% of the share capital but ranked as 52% of the voting rights. Norberg also happened to be in a need to sell. Norberg wanted to buy these companies at book value.
Lord Moyne was approached by his old friend Peter Mattsson to be part of the Trustor purchase and to be the new Chairman after the takeover. Mattsson and Lord Moyne had already a company together, Mattsson Guinness Securities Ltd, and they had both been connected to the infamous financial “Effex scandal” in Norway in 1993-94.<ref>{{cite book |last=Lindstedt |first=Gunnar |title=Svindlande affärer: historien om Trustor |year=2000 |publisher=DN |location=Stockholm |language=Swedish |isbn=91-7588-359-7 |pages=105-106, 114}}</ref>
During the spring of 1997 negotiations took place, resulting in a deal on May 20 where Lord Moyne would buy the company from Norberg for 241 million SEK. The contract contained two important clauses. First, the contract gave Norberg the right to buy Trustor's stocks in the most valuable company Kanthal, at book value. Second, the contract also gave Moyne a few days respite for the payment, which eliminated the need for a short-term loan.<ref name="Lindstedt, G. 2000"/> At about that time Lord Moyne asked Lindsay Smallbone if he would agree to be CEO after the takeover.
On the 10th of June [[Sandvik]] made an offer to buy [[Kanthal (alloy)|Kanthal]] for 827 million SEK, altering the deal with Norberg. A new deal was reached a few days later where Norberg was compensated for not being able to buy Kanthal. Trustor now had the funds needed in order to complete the plan. On the 13th of June an extra shareholders' meeting was held, where Lord Moyne was appointed president and Lindsay Smallbone CEO.<ref name="Lindstedt, G. 2000"/>
Team Moyne now only had a few days to sort out the payment to Norberg, so on the 18th of June Moyne, Smallbone, Jisander and Mattsson met with two bank officers at [[Barclays Bank]] in London. At the meeting accounts were set for Trustor as well as for Lord Moyne and Jisander and in the following days a total of 730 million SEK was transferred from Trustors account in Swedish [[Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken|SEB]] to Trustor's new account in England.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> 600 million SEK of the money in Trustors account was later transferred to Jisanders account in the same bank of which 585 million was then sent directly to Lord Moyne.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> On the 25th of June the 241 million which had been agreed upon was paid to Per-Olof Norberg.
The 30th of June was the last day for the financial statement and mostly because of the payment to Norberg, Trustor now lacked almost 300 million SEK. Lord Moyne took a loan of 293 million SEK from [[Van Lanschot Bankiers]], based in Luxemburg, and the money was then transferred to Trustors account in the same bank. The following day the money was transferred back to Lord Moyne who then repaid the loan.
On October 31 an article about Trustor, written by Gunnar Lindstedt, was published in ''[[Svenska Dagbladet]]''. In the article Lindstedt wrote about Lord Moyne, Mattson and Smallbone following a meeting with them in London. The same day a preliminary investigation started to look into the [[Takeover|acquisition]] and the group of people behind it. After a discussion with the company the Stockholm stock exchange stopped the trading in Trustor. [[Law enforcement in Sweden#National Economic Crimes Bureau|The Swedish Economic Crime Authority]] made an investigation into all transactions to see how much and where to the money had gone. They later concluded that 478 millions had disappeared from Trustor.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Smallbone arranged for the Luxembourg loan to be frozen and this together with the realisation of undervalued assets meant the value of company increased.
===Aftermath=== The legal aftermath had started and on December 23 [[Stockholm District Court]] decided that a compulsory [[liquidation]] should be carried through. Because of Smallbone and Moyne this was a long process since they wanted a share of the salvage value. However the stocks Moyne bought where distributed among the shareholders. Trustor's assets were sold and in the end of the year there was 1.5 billion SEK to be distributed among the minority shareholders. When trade in the stock was resumed the stock price rose to 58,50 from 34 SEK before the take over.<ref>Trustor Annual report 1997 and 1998</ref> Because of the take over the under valuated assets were sold at market price and their real value recovered by Trustor AB.<ref name="Lindstedt, G. 2000"/>
[[Joachim Posener]] refused to return to Sweden to be questioned and was sought by interpol but was never apprehended. Lord Moyne was declared bankrupt and later prosecuted along with Jisander and Mattson.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dn.se/ekonomi/kritik-mot-dom-i-trustorharvan-1.74057 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130418071809/http://www.dn.se/ekonomi/kritik-mot-dom-i-trustorharvan-1.74057 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-04-18 |newspaper=[[Dagens Nyheter]] |title=Kritik mot dom i Trustorhärvan |trans-title=Criticism against the verdict in the Trustor affair |language=Swedish}}</ref> Moyne was acquitted due to lack of evidence and after appeal so were also Jisander and Mattson. However Jisander was later prosecuted and convicted in 2009 for [[embezzlement]] related to Trustor. He is the only one to be convicted of a crime in connection with the Trustor Affair. There are no longer any open police investigations concerning the Trustor Affair as the statutes of limitations are in effect since June 2007.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thelocal.se/22884/20091026/ |newspaper=[[The Local]] |title=Prison sentence for Trustor fraud upheld |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605113859/http://www.thelocal.se/22884/20091026/ |archivedate=June 5, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.realtid.se/ArticlePages/200910/26/20091026141501_Realtid313/20091026141501_Realtid313.dbp.asp |publisher=Realtid.se |title=Läs domen mot Thomas Jisander |trans-title=Read the verdict against Thomas Jisander |date=26 October 2009 |access-date=23 July 2015 |language=Swedish}}</ref> Smallbone was never prosecuted but was sued in a civil lawsuit by Trustor but this was later abandoned.<ref>[High Court CH1988 T No 1492 Order 17 December 2001]</ref> Separate lawsuits were issued against Jisander, Moyne and Posener.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://wwwc.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/9804/11/trustor4.html |newspaper=[[Aftonbladet]] |title=De är männen bakom skandalen i Trustor |trans-title=They are the men behind the Trustor scandal |date=11 April 1998 |access-date=23 July 2015 |language=Swedish}}</ref> Trustor also started a court case in 1999 against Barclay's Bank for their part in the irregularities.<ref>Trustor Annual Report 1999 and Tustor AB v Barclays bank PLC & Anor (2000)</ref>

{{Infobox ethnic group | group = Ukrainians in Romania | image = [[File:Ucraineni Romania 2002.PNG|250px]] | image_caption = Distribution of Ukrainians in Romania (2002 census) | population = 51,703 (2011 census){{ro icon}} [http://www.recensamantromania.ro/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Comunicat_DATE_PROVIZORII_RPL_2011.pdf "Comunicat de presă privind rezultatele provizorii ale Recensământului Populaţiei şi Locuinţelor – 2011"], at the 2011 census site; accessed February 2, 2012. – 300,000 (estimate) including Moldovans | popplace = northern Romania, in areas close to the Ukrainian border | rels = [[Ukrainian Orthodox Vicariate Sighetu Marmației|Ukrainian Orthodox]],
[[Pentecostal Union of Romania|Pentecostal]] and [[Ukrainian Greek-Catholic Vicariate Rădăuţi|Greek-Catholic]] | langs = mainly [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] and [[Romanian language|Romanian]] | related = }} The '''[[Ukrainians]]''' ({{lang-uk|Українці}}, {{lang-ro|Ucraineni}}) are the third-largest [[Minorities of Romania|ethnic minority]] in [[Romania]]. According to the 2011 Romanian census they number 51,703 people, making up 0.3% of the total population. Ukrainians claim that the number is actually 250,000-300,000."The Ukrainians: Engaging the 'Eastern Diaspora'". By [[Andrew Wilson (historian)|Andrew Wilson]]. (1999). In Charles King, Neil Melvin (Eds.) ''Nations Abroad''. Wesview Press, pp. 103-132. {{ISBN|0-8133-3738-0}} Ukrainians mainly live in northern Romania, in areas close to the Ukrainian border. Over 60% of all Romanian Ukrainians live in [[Maramureş County]] (31,234), where they make up 6.77% of the population. Sizable populations of Ukrainians are also found in [[Suceava County]] (5698 people), [[Timiş County]] (5953), [[Caraş-Severin County]] (2600), [[Satu Mare County]] (1397), [[Tulcea County]] (1317) and [[Arad County]] (1295). Ukrainians make up a majority in seven [[Communes of Romania|communes]] of Maramureş County ([[Bistra, Maramureș|Bistra]], [[Bocicoiu Mare]], [[Poienile de sub Munte]], [[Remeți]], [[Repedea]], [[Rona de Sus]] and [[Ruscova]]) and three in Suceava County ([[Bălcăuți, Suceava|Bălcăuţi]], [[Izvoarele Sucevei]] and [[Ulma, Suceava|Ulma]]), as well as in [[Știuca|Ştiuca, Timiş]] and [[Copăcele|Copăcele, Caraş-Severin]]. According to the 2002 census, 79% of Ukrainians were [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox]], organized into the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Vicariate Sighetu Marmației]]; 10% [[Pentecostal Union of Romania|Pentecostal]]; 2.8% [[Romanian Church United with Rome, Greek-Catholic|Greek-Catholic]], organized into the [[Ukrainian Greek-Catholic Vicariate Rădăuţi]]; 2.1% [[Romanian Union Conference of Seventh-day Adventists|Seventh-day Adventist]]; 1.2% [[Lipovan Orthodox Old-Rite Church|Lipovan Orthodox]] and 2.9% stated they belonged to "another religion".{{ro icon}} [http://www.insse.ro/cms/files/RPL2002INS/vol1/tabele/t51a.pdf Populaţia după etnie şi religie, pe medii], at the 2002 Census official site; accessed January 4, 2010. A second group of Ukrainians in Romania live in the [[Dobruja]] region of the [[Danube Delta]]. These are descendents of [[Zaporozhian Cossacks]] who fled Russian rule in the 18th century. In 1830 they numbered 1,095 families.[http://www.uur.ro/frames.htm Union of Ukrainians in Romania website] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081230193516/http://www.uur.ro/frames.htm |date=2008-12-30 }} Over the years they were joined by other peasants fleeing serfdom in the Russian Empire. In 1992 their descendants numbered four thousand people according to official Romanian statistics,Calculated from statistics for the counties of Tulcea and Constanţa from {{cite web|title=Populaţia după etnie la recensămintele din perioada 1930–2002, pe judete|publisher=Guvernul României — Agenţia Naţională pentru Romi| url=http://www.anr.gov.ro/docs/statistici/statistici/t1.pdf|accessdate=2007-05-02|format=pdf|pages=5–6, 13–14|language=Romanian}} while the local community claims to number 20,000. Known as Rusnaks,{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?AddButton=pages\D\O\Dobrudja.htm |title=Dobrudja |accessdate=December 21, 2006 |work=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |publisher= |pages= }} they continue to pursue the traditional [[Cossack]] lifestyle of hunting and fishing. Other Ukrainians came under the policy of Romanianization following the collapse of Austria-Hungary over the whole of [[Duchy of Bukovina|Bukovina]] and relinquishment of Russian Empire over [[Bessarabia Governorate|Bessarabia]] in 1918; the Romanianization policies brought the closure of the Ukrainian public schools (all such schools were closed until 1928) and the suppression of most of the Ukrainian (Ruthenian) cultural institutions. The very term "Ukrainians" was prohibited from the official usage and some Romanians of disputable Ukrainian ethnicity were rather called the "citizens of Romania who forgot their native language" and were forced to change their last names to Romanian-sounding ones.Oleksandr Derhachov (editor), "Ukrainian Statehood in the Twentieth Century: Historical and Political Analysis", Chapter: "Ukraine in Romanian concepts of the foreign policy", 1996, Kiev {{ISBN|966-543-040-8}} Among those who were Romanianized were descendants of Romanians who were assimilated to Ukrainian society in the past. As an officially recognised ethnic minority, Ukrainians have [[Romanian ethnic minorities parties|one seat]] reserved in the Romanian [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Chamber of Deputies]]. [[Ştefan Tcaciuc]] held the seat from 1990 until his 2005 death, when he was replaced by [[Ştefan Buciuta]]. ==See also== * [[Ukrainian diaspora]] * [[Danubian Sich]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://drive.google.com/open?id=1W0rq63i-FTNp3bN8PAy1z_VD4po&usp=sharing Map of Ukrainian villages in Romania] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070930185528/http://ultimaora.phg.ro/cea_mai_mare_comunitate_de_ucraineni_din_romania_-s9499.html Article about the Ukrainians in Maramureş] {{Ethnic groups in Romania}} {{Ukrainian diaspora}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Romania]] [[Category:Ukrainian diaspora in Romania|Romania]]

{{One source|date=June 2008}} '''Walborg''' and '''Karin Jota''' ([[Floruit]] 1350), were two Swedish women who, according to [[legend]], were appointed officials of the court after the great [[Black Plague]]. If the legend is true, they had a unique position for their time.
The legend says that when the judge of the county of [[Värmland]] reassembled the court, after the great black plague had passed Sweden in 1350, they were two members short. Instead of the stipulated twelve officials, they were only ten left. It was not possible to elect two new men to fill their places, because of the great death numbers of the plague. The judge therefore decided to call upon these two women, Karin Jota from Kallhyttan and Walborg from Nordmarkshyttan, to fill the places of the court to make the number complete. These were not only formal positions; the two women took an active part in the affairs of the court. According to the legend, the judge had great respect for their judgement and wisdom, he often asked for their opinion and advice, and often followed it.
